Goal: Increase museum membership
Performance Measure: Number of museum members
Description: Total number of AAM members: includes general membership up to levels of $3,000 and above, as of the last day of the period.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Records are developed and maintained in our database: Raiser's Edge. This database houses individual membership records including a member's history, gift date history, gift date, membership expiration, and membership category.  The Information Systems staff ( Manager, Associate, and Assistant) enter gifts daily into Raiser's Edge as well provide reports and maintain the database as a whole. The Membership Manager has access to Raiser's Edge to extract reports and add or update biographical information in individual records.  Membership data calculation process concludes 1 week after closing of each month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 2013 Exceeded all attendance and membership goals.

Goal: Increase number of museum visitors
Performance Measure: City cost per visitor
Description: The goal is to determine the cost per visitor based on the funding provided by the City.
Technical Description: The City cost per visitor is calculated by dividing the Revenue (General Funds, Hotel Room Tax, Facility/Maintenance funds) by the total number of visitors to the Museum.

Goal: Increase number of museum visitors
Performance Measure: Number of museum visitors
Description: Number of every museum visitor entering the front door.
Technical Description: Collection Method: At the admission desk of AAM, all visitors (both paid and non-paid) are ticketed.  The visitor data is collected from the computerized ticketing system. Timing:  Daily/Weekly/ Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY13 Annual attendance was the third best since our move to Civic Center in 2003 due to record attendance achieved by the China's Terracotta Warriors exhibition (Feb 22, 2013 - May 27, 2013).

Goal: Provide quality programs on Asian art and culture
Performance Measure: Number of education program participants
Description: Number of education program participants are organized into four categories: on-site school programs (school tours of children, teachers, and chaperones); off-site school programs (docent travels to school to teach a class/workshop); on-site educator program (teacher workshops and resource fairs); off-site educator programs (we do outreach to teachers regarding our programs.
Technical Description: Collection Method: all on-site participants are ticketing through our front door ticketing system: Vista. Off-site participant counts are maintained in Filemaker Database managed by AAM Education Department. Timing: Quarterly - one month after close of quarter
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Through more flexible scheduling and better accommodating teacher needs, we were able to steadily increase our school tour numbers in the Fall and thanks to the widespread popular appeal of the Terracotta Warriors exhibition and our hosting of the SFUSD Arts Festival we enjoyed a significant lift in attendance in the Spring and we exceeded our target for the year.

Goal: Provide quality programs on Asian art and culture
Performance Measure: Number of public program participants
Description: Number of attendees at programs offered to the public including: family programs, adult programs (performance, lectures, classes, tea ceremony), Asia Alive, public tours.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Head Count taken by public program staff & registration data maintained by AAM Public Program Dept. Timing:  Quarterly - one month after close of quarter
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Total attendance for the Phantoms of Asia exhibition, which closed in September, was 5% lower than expected and our attendance in programs was down about 12% from our projection. However, we finished the year strongly with the Terracotta Warriors exhibition with robust attendance on tours and at programs. Our actual was only slightly below target as a result of the popular spring exhibition.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: [HR department manages a web-based Performance Management system for personnel.] Timing:Annually for full-time employees, (starting off with a 6 month review for new hires.)
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Our Performance Appraisals are scheduled to be completed in July, therefore our "Fiscal Year End Actuals" follow closely to what the earlier "six month Actuals" were.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  [HR department manages a web-based Performance Management system for personnel.] Timing: Annually for full-time employees, (starting off with a 6 month review for new hires.)
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Existing supervisor resigned leaving some reviews overdue. Alternate supervisor will give the review.

Goal: CSR Productivity
Performance Measure: Percentage of Customer Service Representatives that answer 17 calls per hour
Description: The percentage of Customer Service Representatives that answer 17 calls per hour, which is equivalent to 3000 calls per month. This metric was changed in July 2009 from "calls per month" to "calls per hour" in order to take into account planned and unplanned absences.
Technical Description: Calculation: Total number of calls answered divided by the total number of hours staffed by on line Customer Service Reps. Data Source: Avaya's Call Management System (CMS) and Blue Pumpkin to determine the number of calls answered and the number of staffed hours, respectively.

Goal: One Call Resolution
Performance Measure: Percentage of calls handled without a transfer
Description: Provide requested information or handle intake of service requests to callers without phone transfer to other city agencies.  This metric was developed in July 2008 as a performance measure for 311.
Technical Description: Calculation: Total number of calls not transferred out of the 311 center divided by the total number of calls answered.  Source: Avaya's Call Management System (CMS) will be utilized to determine the number of calls answered and calls transferred.  Frequency: Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Target met. No change from previous 6 months

Goal: Public Self Service
Performance Measure: Percentage of Automated 311 Service Requests
Description: The number of automated service requests received by 311 via the internet and smart phone app.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of the total number of automated requests received by 311 divided by the total number of requests received by 311 during the reporting period. Data Source: 311 Data Systems.

Goal: Quality Assurance
Performance Measure: Quality assurance percentage score
Description: The quality assurance rating for 311 is determined by conducting observations of randomly selected calls into the call center by a quality manager and supervisors. The monitorings will cover all 8 key critical main elements: 1.) greeting, 2.) listening, 3.) speaking, 4.) call handling, 5.) assessment and issue solving, 6.) CRM procedural requirements, 7.) resource/application requirements, and 8.) closing. This metric was developed in July 2008 as a performance measure for 311.
Technical Description: Calculation: The number of quality assurance points earned by a CSR on a call divided by the total number of points possible. Source: The NICE recording application will be utilized to score a minimum of 5 calls per month per CSR. Frequency: Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Target exceeded through continuous training and coaching.

Goal: Service Level Percentage
Performance Measure: Percentage of calls answered in 60 seconds
Description: The percentage of calls answered within 60 seconds versus the total number of calls received on a monthly basis.  This metric of answering 50% of calls in 60 seconds was developed in July 2008 as a performance measure for 311.
Technical Description: Calculation: The number of calls answered within 60 seconds divided the total number of calls received during the measurement interval. Data Source: Avaya�s Call Management System (CMS) and will be utilized to determine the number of calls answered within 60 seconds and the total number of calls received. Frequency: Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance exceeded due to hiring off additional as needed staff and a decrease in call volumes, partially offset by an increase in handle time.

Goal: Decrease number of animals euthanized
Performance Measure: Percentage of live animal releases
Description: As home of the "No Kill" movement, we came up with a formula that accurately measures the life saving successes of animal shelters. The "Live Release Rate,” is the ratio of live animals impounded compared to live animals released. We separate dogs/cats/others/wildlife because many jurisdictions/animal shelters provide care, shelter or handle only dogs/cats. It is our mission to consider all animals that come through our door as a measure of success. The Live Release Rate is calculated by taking the total number of animals of any species impounded alive (exclusive of owners requesting euthanasia for sick or injured animal and those that die in kennels) and comparing what is adopted, redeemed back to owners, rescued or released back to nature, to the number we cannot save and euthanize. This measure has become the national standard for animal welfare organizations to monitor and compare life saving efforts. The national average for municipal animal control agencies is approximately 45%.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The data is collected by "Chameleon," which is our in-house animal software program tracking all intakes and final disposition of animals. The documentation is located at our animal shelter facility at 1200 15th Street. Timing: Routinely available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Our staff and volunteer special efforts to improve  outreach to the community for adoptions as well as our partnership with Pet Food Express has helped to maintain our good live release record.  Our LRR includes all animals, including other companion pets, and wildlife in recent years, not just cats and dogs.  However, the number of dogs we take in has continued to rise even as the number of other animals (including cats) has decreased.  Dogs require more care and attention and we have made particular efforts at outreach for them.

Goal: Decrease or maintain average field emergency response time
Performance Measure: Field service emergency response time, in minutes
Description: Average field response time for emergencies involving sick, injured, dangerous and/or animals in distress throughout the City (time measured from when the call first comes in to the time our Animal Control Officer reaches the scene).  This is an important measure in order for us to meet our primary responsibility to protect the public. It is linked to historic measures and is directly related to staffing resources available to our Department.  This particular measure has been captured for many years and has improved from over 30 minutes to nearly 25.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The data is collected by "Chameleon," which is our in-house animal management program that tracks all intakes and disposition of animals and activity calls.  We wrote an in-house program to capture calls we consider an emergency and the accompanying response time. The documentation is located at our animal shelter facility at 1200 15th Street. Timing:  Routinely available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Animal Control Division staff consistently make extra effort to get to calls that impact public safety and/or involving animals in distress.  With the staffing of as-needed employees, the officers were able to respond in a timely fashion.

Goal: Ensure that CCSF does not contract with vendors that discriminate (a) based on defined protected classes, or (b) in providing benefits to employees with spouses and employees with domestic partners.
Performance Measure: Total Number of EBO (12B) Compliant CCSF Vendors
Description: This measure captures the number of vendors doing business with the City and County of San Francisco that are compliant with the Equal Benefits Ordinance.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of the number of EBO compliant CCSF vendors at a point in time. Data Source: Excel.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Actual numbers have remained consistent  over the life of equal benefits legislation.

Goal: Increase and ensure participation of local businesses through City contracting and purchasing.
Performance Measure: Total Minimum Dollars Awarded to LBE, PUC-LBE, NPE, and SBA Certified Firms

Goal: Increase and ensure participation of local businesses through City contracting and purchasing.
Performance Measure: Total number of awarded active CCSF contracts monitored by CMD
Description: This measure represents the total number of contracts monitored by the CMD.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of the total number of awarded active CCSF contracts monitored by CMD at a point in time.

Goal: Increase and ensure participation of local businesses through City contracting and purchasing.
Performance Measure: Total Number of LBE, PUC-LBE, NPE, and SBA Certified Firms
Description: This measure captures the total number of LBE, PUC-LBE, SBA and NPE firms that have been certified by the CMD.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of the total number of LBE, PUC-LBE, SBA and NPE Certified firms that have been certified at a point in time. Data Source: Excel, LBE Certification Database.

Goal: Streamline delivery of County Clerk services
Performance Measure: Percentage of customers assisted within ten minutes from the time they are ready to be served
Description: Percentage of customers assisted within 10 minutes from the time they are ready to be served (time from when forms are completed).
Technical Description: Calculation: Number of customers assisted within ten minutes divided by the total number of customers served. Data Source: Q-Matic.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Made changes to more efficiently serve the Vital Records queue.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Continue to serve customers efficiently and effectively without delay.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection method:  Manager and employee develop a plan for the new fiscal year.  Performance Plan is scheduled for appraisal/review end of fiscal year.  Source: Performance Plan is filed with manager and Human Resources department.  Timing of Performance Appraisal is annual.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Although the formal performance planning process was minimal this year, ADM employee performance was exceptional especially given the changes in management, acquisition of new departments and priority City-wide projects.  Employees receive constant feedback with clear expectations and they are engaged in their work.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection method:  Manager and employee meet to discuss Performance Appraisal.  Manager submits Performance Appraisal to Human Resources department for input into database and file.  Source: Performance Plan is filed with manager and Human Resources department.  Timing of Performance Appraisal is annual, after fiscal year closing.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This is an estimate as of 8/12/13.  Actuals will be available later in September.

Goal: Conduct required plan and site reviews in a timely manner
Performance Measure: Percentage of requests for plan reviews fulfilled within twenty business days
Description: Percentage of requests for review of construction plan documents fulfilled within 20 business days.
Technical Description: Calculation: The number of requests for plan reviews fulfilled within twenty days divided by the total number of requests received for plan reviews during the reporting period. Data Source: Excel.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Exceeded goals.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Placed priority on turn around. Many of the plans were for City projects.

Goal: Conduct required plan and site reviews in a timely manner
Performance Measure: Percentage of requests for site reviews fulfilled within seven business days
Description: Percentage of requests for review of actual construction sites fulfilled within 7 business days. Site reviews are more time sensitive because they are part of the construction process.
Technical Description: Calculation: The total number of site requests fulfilled within seven days divided by the total number of requests for site reviews. Data Source: Excel.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Exceeded goals.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Placed priority on turn around. Many of the inspections were for affordable housing.

Goal: Control citywide vehicle costs by reducing the number of vehicles assigned to departments
Performance Measure: Number of vehicles assigned to departments
Description: Reduction in general purpose vehicles (light duty autos, pickup trucks and vans used for general passenger transportation, not operations, excluding emergency response vehicles) assigned to departments.  This measures the number of assigned vehicles.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops vehicle inventory. Timing:  Routinely available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/13: HACTO-mandated reductions have been balanced by MBO-approved adds to fleet due to increased work in some departments.

Goal: Control citywide vehicle costs by reducing the number of vehicles assigned to departments
Performance Measure: Percentage of survey respondents who rate satisfaction with Central Shops as above average or greater.
Description: Average customer satisfaction rating on a 5-point scale.  Survey to be developed and administered by City Administrator central office, covering all of the internal services functions of the department.  This survey will be conducted annually.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Online survey instrument to be developed. Timing:  Survey to be conducted annually in the 2nd quarter.  Data available within 30 days.

Goal: Transition the general purpose fleet to clean fuel technologies
Performance Measure: Percentage of the general purpose fleet that is clean fuel
Description: Percentage of general purpose vehicles that are classified as clean fuel technology.  General purpose vehicles are light duty cars, vans, and pickups, not used for emergency response.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops vehicle inventory in automated system called MAPCON. Timing:  Routinely available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/13: Stricter purchasing rules and greater availability and acceptance of clean-fuel vehicles have driven the percentage higher.

Goal: Promote San Francisco as a tourist destination by supporting the arts and cultural community
Performance Measure: Number of attendees at programs and events supported by GFTA funding
Description: Attendance at all programs and events supported by Grants for the Arts (GFTA) funding, including tourist promotion activities.  Grants for the Arts, established in 1961, is an internationally admired model of municipal funding and support of the arts and culture in San Francisco. Providing a stable, dependable base of support to the broadest spectrum of the City's arts community, GFTA fulfills its mission of  "promoting the City by supporting the arts" through the funding of nonprofit arts and cultural organizations which help to make San Francisco as a premier destination for regional, national and international visitors.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Reports submitted by grantees and entered into a database by GFTA staff. Timing:  Data is submitted annually in grant applications and entered during the 6 month application review process. Reports can be generated in mid July. .
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Valerie Tookes, 8/22/13 - GFTA experienced a fourth year of level annual revenue. This meant that, in most cases, CBO grant levels also continued to remain level for the majority of the 217 local nonprofit arts organizations funded in FY 13. GFTA’s goal is to be a steady, dependable source of funding. It is our hope that this commitment allows continuing grantees to program at previous year levels and reach a similar estimated audience level. Please note that this number also includes of the estimated number of visitors to the SFArts.org website, an Arts and Tourism website funded by GFTA and the distribution of the SF Arts Monthly print publication.

Goal: Implement and enforce Prevailing Wage requirements
Performance Measure: Back wages assessed for violation of prevailing wage requirements
Description: Dollar value of back wages assessed during the fiscal year resulting from violations of prevailing wage requirements.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of back wages assessed for violation of prevailing wage requirements during the current reporting period. Data Source: Excel

Goal: Implement and enforce San Francisco labor laws
Performance Measure: Percent of MWO claims resolved within one year of filing
Description: Percentage of MWO claims resolved within one year of filing during the reporting period.
Technical Description: Calculation: (MWO claims filed during the period 12 months prior to the reporting period and resolved within one year of filing) / (MWO claims filed 12 months prior to the reporting period). Data Source: Excel and Access Reporting frequency: Semi-annual report for the calendar year and fiscal year report for the end of year figure.

Goal: Complete cases and investigations in a timely manner
Performance Measure: Percent of toxicology exams completed within 90 calendar days of submission
Description: The current goal is a standard set by the National Association of Medical Examiners (the Office of the Medical Examiner is accredited by NAME). Cases can be Medical Examiner cases (deaths) or tests of live persons (e.g. DUI). This parameter has the greatest effect on the turnaround time for death certificates.
Technical Description: Calculation: The sum of toxicology exams completed within 90 days, divided by the total number of toxicology exams in the reporting period. Data Source: Access.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This performance is attributable the loss of one staff person and the re-assignment of Forensic Laboratory Division personnel’s time and efforts to tasks related to new accreditation requirements.

Goal: Complete cases and investigations in a timely manner
Performance Measure: Percentage of all notifications of families completed within 24 hours
Description: Notification of a family of a death requires a sequence of events to occur: investigation, identification and notification of families, all completed within 24 hours. The Investigative Section is made up of the Medical Examiner's Investigators and Administrator. Their responsibility is to go to the scenes, investigate deaths, and communicate with grieving families.
Technical Description: Calculation: Sum of investigations, identifications and notifications of families completed within 24 hours divided by the total number of investigations, identifications and notifications of families completed in the current reporting period. Data Source: Access.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Investigative Division exceeded their target this fiscal year due to their dedication to purpose, commitment to service, and hard work.

Goal: Medical Examiner customer satisfaction
Performance Measure: Percentage of survey respondents who rate satisfaction with Medical Examiner as above average or greater.
Description: Percentage of survey respondents who rate satisfaction as above average or greater.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Online survey instrument to be developed. Timing:  Survey to be conducted annually in the 2nd quarter.

Goal: Achieve cost savings and make the purchasing process more efficient
Performance Measure: Average number of days to convert requisitions not requiring formal bidding into purchase orders
Description: Number of working days elapsed, from the day a requisition first reaches a Purchasing level approval box in the purchasing system, to the day the requisition is posted as a purchase order, for transactions not requiring Invitation to Bid process. The measure is an average of 90% of all transactions, excluding the slowest 10% because those transactions include rejected documents that would skew the average.
Technical Description: Calculation: The sum of the number of working days elapsed, from the day a requisition first reaches a Purchasing level approval box in the purchasing system, to the day the requisition is posted as a purchase order divided by the total number of requisitions during the reporting period. Data Source: Extracts run by Controller's staff from ADPICS.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Jaci Fong: We continue to experience slower turnaround times in the IT area.

Goal: Achieve cost savings and make the purchasing process more efficient
Performance Measure: Percentage of all purchases made through term contracts (excluding professional services)
Description: Spending is assumed to be the amount of ADPICS standard vouchers and direct vouchers with post dates within each fiscal year.
Technical Description: Calculation: The sum of total term contract spending divided by the total contract spending amount during the reporting period. Excludes professional services. Data Source: Extracts run by Controller's staff from ADPICS.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The 2nd half of the year includes more vehicle and equipment purchases that are not necessarily reflected in term contracts.

Goal: Keep rental rates for City tenants below market rates
Performance Measure: Average occupancy rate in City-owned buildings managed by Real Estate
Description: Occupancy:  A department or third party is paying for the space. That might mean a space is under construction or is unoccupied, but it is under a department's or third party's control and they are making rental or work order payments (or capitalized interest payments are being received) for the space.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Manual records maintained by Real Estate. Timing:  Routinely available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 1200 sf/1,752,986 sf = vacancy of 0.068%, rounded to 100% occupancy

Goal: Keep rental rates for City tenants below market rates
Performance Measure: Average per sq ft cost of City-operated buildings compared to listing rates in Civic Center
Description: Costs of six City-owned buildings managed by the department, including 25 Van Ness, 30 Van Ness, One South Van Ness, 555 7th Street, 1660 Mission, and 1650 Mission, compared to Civic Center and South of Market area rents. "Cost" of city owned space is the per square foot rate charged to city dept, calculated as the combined total cost (debt service plus O&M) for all six bldgs, divided by the total sq. ft. of space.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Costs are directly from budget.  Area rents are from CB Richard Ellis company. Timing: Quarterly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: CBRE Q1, 2013 average asking rate is $38.37/sf vs. $22.56/sf for City-operated buildings

Goal: Keep rental rates for City tenants below market rates
Performance Measure: Average per sq ft cost of office space lease portfolio compared to market rates
Description: Rental costs paid to lessors for City offices compared to market rates.  We beat the market on owned space, and on space we lease, which is what this metric measures.  By averaging the cost per sq. ft. of office space leased in Civic Center, and dividing by the market rate, we get this metric. The lower the percent, the better we are doing for compared to market.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Lease records maintained by Real Estate staff. Timing:  Routinely available
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Ave asking rate for market total Q2, 2013, per CBRE report, is $50.52/sf (latest available report), actual is $26.19/sf as of 6/2013

Goal: Promote San Francisco as a convention destination by providing high quality services
Performance Measure: Percentage of client post-convention survey ratings in the above average or higher category. *2014-2015 and 2015-2016 Targets reflect Moscone Center construction that is scheduled to begin fall 2014 and continue through 2016.
Description: Average of client survey responses.  Clients are surveyed after each convention.
Technical Description: Calculation: The convention operator (SMG) conducts the survey via an online form. All events are surveyed, but not all return the instrument.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per John Noguchi 8/13: Moscone users continue to rate their convention center experiences in the excellent/above average range. The $56M capital improvement project greatly enhanced both the front of house experience and the aging facilty infrastructure. The percentage increase clearly demonstrates that the investment was carefully thought out and efficiently implemented.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Per John Noguchi 8/13: Another extremely busy and successful convention year at Moscone. As the economy remains strong, convention business continues to thrive, resulting in higher hotel occupancy and ADR figures from the previous year.

Goal: Maintain a reasonable average maintenance cost per vehicle
Performance Measure: Average annual maintenance cost per general purpose vehicle
Description: For general purpose vehicles that are part of the vehicle leasing program, the average annual maintenance cost for all types of repairs performed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops automated vehicle maintenance system called MAPCON.  Data entered by shop supervisors.  Billing charges calculated by system. Timing:  Routinely available, but special reports must be run out of MAPCON, a cumbersome process.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/2013: Maintenance cost has increased with average age of fleet.

Goal: Maintain a reasonable average maintenance cost per vehicle
Performance Measure: Average annual maintenance cost per Police vehicle
Description: For Police black and white (not undercover) vehicles, the average annual maintenance cost for all types of repairs performed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops automated vehicle maintenance system called MAPCON.  Data entered by shop supervisors.  Billing charges calculated by system. Timing:  Routinely available, but special reports must be run out of MAPCON, a cumbersome process.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/2013: Maintenance cost has increased with average age of fleet.

Goal: Maintain availability of City vehicles for department use
Performance Measure: Percentage of repairs of general purpose vehicles performed in less than 3 days
Description: For general purpose vehicles that are part of the vehicle leasing program, the elapsed time from creation of a maintainance job order to posting as completed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops automated vehicle maintenance system called MAPCON.  Data entered by shop supervisors. Timing:  Routinely available, but special reports must be run out of MAPCON, a cumbersome process.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/2013: In the interest of safety and fleet reduction, we are removing more old lease-program vehicles from service rather than doing major repairs.

Goal: Maintain availability of City vehicles for department use
Performance Measure: Percentage of repairs of Police vehicles performed in less than 3 days
Description: For Police black and white (not undercover) vehicles, the elapsed time from creation of a maintainance job order to posting as completed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Central Shops automated vehicle maintenance system called MAPCON.  Data entered by shop supervisors. Timing:  Routinely available, but special reports must be run out of MAPCON, a cumbersome process.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Per Dan Coleman 9/9/2013: Aging of fleet may outweigh department efficiency.

Goal: Increase collection of fines and fees.
Performance Measure: Amount of fines and fees
Description: This measure includes all fines and fees collected for APD.  Effective November 2007 the APD transferred the collection of revenues including fines, fees and restitution to the Courts Collections Unit pursuant to a change in state law.   The Courts Collections Unit collects and disburses restituion payments for APD which is not included in this measure and is recorded in the Courts Collections Unit Financial System.
Technical Description: Actual funds collected according to accounting records.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Increase in Probation Fees due to system tracking and collection enforcement.

Goal: Maximize staff effectiveness
Performance Measure: Percentage of available employees receiving performance appraisals
Description: This measure represents the percentage of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months in June.
Technical Description: All performance appraisals will be completed in June.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All annual performance appraisals are completed.

Goal: Maximize staff effectiveness
Performance Measure: Percentage of eligible APD peace officer employees completing a minimum of 40 hours of mandated training
Description: The State of California Corrections Standards Authority requires that all Deputy Probation Officers complete a minimum of 40 hours of annual training as prescribed in Title 15 of the California Code of Regulations, Sections 130 et sequitur. The requirement is waived for employees on long term leaves of absence.
Technical Description: The Training Officer collects and retains this data in a computerized training database.  This training database is updated on a monthly basis as proof of completed hours that are received from the Corrections Standards Authority approved training providers.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All Deputy Probation Officers completed and exceeded the minimum of 40 hours of annual training.  Officers completed an average of 151 hours of mandated training.

Goal: Maximize staff effectiveness
Performance Measure: Percentage of newly appointed peace officer staff that have completed mandatory CORE training
Description: The State of California Corrections Standards Authority requires that all peace officer staff completes basic CORE training during the first 12 months of job assignment as prescribed in Title 15 of the California Code of Regulations, Sections 130-132.  The Department has Chief, Chief Deputy, Division Director, Supervising Probation Officer positions that are subject to this requirement during an employee's first year in the classification.
Technical Description: The Training Officer collects and retains this data in a computerized training database.  This training database is updated on a monthly basis as proof of completed hours that are received from the Corrections Standards Authority approved training providers.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All newly hired deputy probation officers completed mandatory Core training on 12/19/2012.  A newly promoted supervisor completed supervisor Core on 03/15/13.  Two directors completed mandatory Core/MACC training on 05/17/13.

Goal: Maximize staff effectiveness
Performance Measure: Probation officer cost per active probationer
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Increased cost due to hiring 15 DPO's in September 2012.

Goal: Maximize staff effectiveness
Performance Measure: Probationers, PRCS, Mandatory Supervision clients per Probation Officer
Description: Average number of active clients on community supervision (probation, Mandatory Supervision, and Post Release Community Supervision) supervised by the Adult Probation Department per case-carrying Deputy Probation Officer, as of the end of the reporting period.
Technical Description: Data on active clients and their supervising Deputy Probation Officer is entered and maintained in the department's case management system and reported weekly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: As of the end of FY13, APD supervised 5,396 active clients and had 67 case-carrying DPOs, for an average caseload size of 81:1.  This represents an average across the department, including high-high intensity supervision caseloads with an average caseload ratio of 19:1, high-intensity supervision caseloads with an average caseload ratio of 53:1, medium-intensity supervision caseloads with an average caseload ratio of 82:1, low intensity supervision caseloads with a caseload average of 704:1, and administrative caseloads with an average caseload ratio of 102:1.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Maximum established caseload size per probation officer in the domestic violence unit
Description: Maximum caseload size per probation officer in the Domestic Violence unit. The Department has a case management system for managing the caseload size of each officer. A lower caseload size improves public safety by allowing the officers to be more pro-active in their supervision services. The Department has implemented strategies that have resulted in fewer referrals, thereby improving public safety.
Technical Description: Data is maintained in the Department's case management system and is verified with actual monthly statistical checks by the supervising probation officer.  The caseload size depends upon the number of cases, the number of staff vacancies within the unit, and reassignment of officers from other caseloads when vacancies occur.  The average caseload size is a point in time calculation measured at the end of each reporting period.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Maximum caseload size is 96 for one caseload.  Remaining caseloads consist an average of 65 cases per officer, with exception of one grant funded caseload of 43 and CAIP, 30, one limited supervison caseload of 42.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of batterer treatment programs certified or renewed by Department
Description: Number of certifications issued and renewed as defined in Penal Code 1203.097 and 1203.098.   All programs are required to be recertified annually.  The certifications provide for quality batterer treatment programs in our community, which helps to improve outcomes for the probationers and safety in our community.  The goal of a batter treatment program is to stop domestic violence.  As described per Penal Code 1203.097, Probation Departments issue certifications to batterer treatment programs consisting of lectures, classes, group discussions and counseling, taking into consideration the following components: A) strategies to hold the defendant accountable for the violence in a relationship; B) a requirement that the defendant participate in ongoing same-gender group sessions; C) supervision and evaluation of the defendant's progress in the program.
Technical Description: The treatment programs are certified annually during the second half of the fiscal year.  Certification process records and data are maintained by the unit supervisor.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD exceeded our target of 7, certifying 10 programs.  We need to increase our target to 8.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of cases successfully terminated
Description: Number of cases successfully terminated. Successful cases are defined as official adult probation cases terminated due to normal expiration, court terminations, earned discharge, and not sentenced to state prison or terminated unsuccessfully.
Technical Description: The statistics are maintained by the Division Directors and reported on a monthly basis by the probation officers.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD exceeded the target in this measure by 19% due to a department-wide effort to reduce caseload sizes, implement evidence-based supervision practices, improve clients' access to services and resources, and provide training in evidence-based supervision practices to all officers.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of cases under limited supervision
Description: The Department has a case management system for managing the caseload size of each officer. When a case is assigned to limited supervision, minimal direct supervision services are being provided. Probationers are required to submit required fines and fees. If there are any issues or concerns generated from this caseload, probationers or the public are encouraged to contact the officer assigned to monitor the Limited Services Caseload. Therefore, a higher number of cases under limited supervision will indicate that these cases have minimal direct supervision.
Technical Description: The caseload size is an average of the reporting period.  Data is maintained in the Department's case management system.  Positive results are on or below target.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of community meetings attended by probation staff
Description: Meetings attended by probation staff in neighborhoods and at community based organizations. Attendance at these meetings allows the community to discuss issues affecting public safety.  These meetings also provide insight for the department to focus resources on specific community issues.
Technical Description: Staff report community meeting attendance to their supervisors monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Exceeded target by 67% as we continue to prioritize staff engagement in community outreach.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of incoming and outgoing jurisdictional transfers initiated
Description: Many San Francisco Probationers reside in another county.  Pursuant to Section 1203.9 of the Penal Code, the Department's policy is to refer these cases to the County of Residence for jurisdictional transfer and also process jurisdictional transfer requests as they are received.
Technical Description: The Community Services Division Director maintains monthly data on jurisdictional transfers. Once it is determined that a probationer resides in another county, officers initiate the process to transfer the probation matter to the receiving county per the statue.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD had an increase of 36% of incoming and outgoing jurisdictional transfers.  A contributing factor to the increase includes a comprehensive all caseload review that was conducted, the caseload management policy and statutory changes to the jurisdictional process.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of probationers age 18-25 referred to supportive services
Description: The number of probationers age 18-25 referred to appropriate treatment services. Studies have shown that offenders with appropriate treatment services reoffend less.  Officers conduct assessments using the CAIS needs and risk assessment to determine supervision and supportive service needs.  Referrals for supportive services are initiated as appropriate.
Technical Description: Referrals are reported by officers to the supervisors who maintain the statistics.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD continues to focus on increased client referrals.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of referrals to treatment and support services
Description: Number of probationers referred to treatment and support services.  Studies have shown that recidivism rates decrease when offenders participate in appropriate treatment and support services.
Technical Description: Officers provide monthly data to their supervisors.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The actual number of probationers referred to services have exceeded the target.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of site visits made to batterer treatment programs
Description: Number of probation officer visits to batterer treatment programs.  Per Penal Code 1203.097 C, the Probation Department has the authority to approve the issuance, denial, suspension, or revocation of approval and to cease new enrollments or referrals to batterer treatment programs.  The Department reviews information relative to a program's performance, failure to adhere to standards, or both.  These visits enable the Department to monitor outcome of programs for probationers, which leads to improved community safety.
Technical Description: Actual number of monitoring visits made by probation officers. Information is maintained continuously by the supervisor of the unit and is retrieved every six months for performance measure reporting.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD exceeded the target of 60.  APD conducted an audit of all certified Batterer Treatment Programs, and DPOs regularly conducted site visits.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of visits by probationers and victims to the Department for services
Description: Number of probationers and victims who physically come to Adult Probation for services.  These services include meeting with probation officers for intake, monthly reporting, interviews for court reports, etc.  In rare instances, victims come to the Department to present documentation of financial loss and to discuss the probationer and the case with the probation officer.
Technical Description: Records and Reception staff log on a daily basis the number of probationers and victims that come to the Department.  Statistics are kept on a monthly basis of this activity and reported to the Division Director.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Due to implementation of case management standards, client visits to the department have increased.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of closed cases successfully terminated
Description: Percentage of cases successfully terminated. Successful cases are defined as official adult probation cases terminated due to normal expiration, court terminations, earned discharge, modifications to court probation, transfers to other countries, and not sentenced to state prison or terminated unsuccessfully.
Technical Description: Statistics are compiled from ADP's and the Superior Court's case management systems and are reported monthly to the Department of Justice.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: While the percentage of closed cases that terminated successfully was higher in FY13 than in previous years, it was 7 percent lower than the FY13 target.  This is due to the higher number of cases terminated during the year than in previous years and the department's emphasis on evidence-based practices, including swift and certain sanctions for behavior that is noncompliant with probationers' terms and conditions, which leads to more cases being closed unsuccessfully than in previous years.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of new domestic violence probationers attending domestic violence orientation
Description: Percentage of domestic violence probationers attending orientation.  Each domestic violence probationer referred to the Department is required to attend an orientation.  The Department mandates that all new domestic violence probationers attend orientation to understand the duties and responsibilities outlined in the court order.  The Department also provides information and makes referrals to required batterer treatment programs.  The Department initiates corrective action for those who fail to attend the scheduled orientation.
Technical Description: Actual data is maintained continuously by the domestic violence supervisor who conducts the domestic violence orientation unit and is retrieved every six months for performance measure reporting.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 100% of new DV probationers were scheduled for orientation. 75% appeared due to their availability and 25% were unavailable due to custody status or absconding.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of new probationers receiving intake
Description: Percentage of new probationers receiving intake.  Probationers referred to the Department should be given an intake in addition to an orientation.  The intake is a one on one process between the probation officer and the probationer.  The purpose is to assess the probationer's needs, level of supervision, establish a case supervision plan, refer the probationer to supportive services as appropriate, and explain the terms and conditions of probation. (NOTE:  This measure was changed as of January 1, 2008 from number attending intake to percentage attending intake to provide a more meaningful measurement.)
Technical Description: Monthly statistics are provided by the supervisors and maintained by the division directors.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The department has identified that a data collection issue exists in the method which officers use to record intake appointments conducted on their caseloads.  We believe that this issue contributes to under reporting by officers of this activity.  During the next reporting cycle additional staff training will be provided.  Custody status and client absconding also contributes to intake availability.  5,848 client office visits were completed by staff during this reporting period.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of available employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  (Reports are not prepared for staff unavailable due to long-term leave.)
Technical Description: Data is maintained by Personnel Analyst.  Actual number of appraisals scheduled.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 100% of annual performance appraisals were completed as mandated.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of available employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  (Reports are not prepared for staff available due to long-term leave.)
Technical Description: Data is maintained by Personnel Analyst.  Actual number of appraisals completed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 100% of annual performance appraisals were completed as mandated.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Number of new cases supervised under Post Release Community Supervision
Description: Number of individuals released from State Prison to the Post Release Community Supervision (PRCS) program during the fiscal year.  Prior to the implementation of AB109 on October 1, 2011, these individuals were released to State parole under the supervision of California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation.  The PRCS unit provides comprehensive reentry services and community supervision to this population. Measure Definition revised March 15, 2013. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Pre-release packets are received from the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation. Data is maintained in the Department’s case management system and verified by the supervising probation officer. Unit counts are reported weekly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: In FY13, APD received 203 new Post Release Community Supervision (PRCS) cases from CDCR.  At the end of FY13, APD had received a total of 564 PRCS cases since October 1, 2011.  In November 2012, CDCR revised their projections of PRCS cases to be released to San Francisco.  The received projections for FY13 are based on these revisions and the average rate at which the actual number of PRCS clients received has exceeded CDCR's projections since October 2011.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percent of individuals completing Mandatory Supervision who complete successfully.
Description: Of individuals who complete Mandatory Supervision, the percentage who complete successfully. Successful completion is defined as cases terminated due to expiration of the term, court termination, and not sentenced to state prison or county jail or otherwise terminated unsuccessfully. Measure Definition revised March 15, 2013. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Statistics are maintained by the Division Directors and reported on a monthly basis by the probation officers.  Data is entered into the department's case management system.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 82% of individuals who completed Mandatory Supervision between January and June 2013 completed successfully.  74% of those completing during FY2012/13 completed successfully.  Through utilization of risk/needs assessment and development and use of individualized treatment and rehabilitation plans, we expect that this rate will continue to increase.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percent of individuals who have been on PRCS for at least twelve months that have successfully completed PRCS.
Description: Percentage of individuals who have been on PRCS for at least twelve months who have successfully completed PRCS.  Successful completion is defined as cases terminated due to expiration of the term, court termination, Returned to Custody completions, and not sentenced to state prison or county jail or otherwise terminated unsuccessfully.  Individuals who have died while on PRCS are not considered successful or unsuccessful completions. Individuals on PRCS for more than six months who do not re-offend or violate conditions of their supervision for six consecutive months are eligible for early release from PRCS, at the discretion of the Chief Adult Probation Officer. Individuals on PRCS for 12 months are mandatorily discharged from PRCS if they do not re-offend or violate conditions of their supervision and result in custody time.Without early release, an individual's PRCS term terminates after three years.
Technical Description: Statistics are maintained by the Division Directors and reported on a monthly basis by the probation officers. Data is entered into the department’s case management system. Please note that the Measure Definition was revised on March 15, 2013.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: ADP has not met our target of 90% during this reporting period.  With average of 8 prior felony convictions, and very high risk nature of population, ADP has been unable to yet reach 90%.  ADP expects that through utilization of risk/needs assessment and development and use of individualized treatment and rehabilitation plans, as well as maximizing utilization of Reentry Pod and the Community Assessment and Services Center (CASC), that ADP will reach 90%.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of individuals on Mandatory Supervision referred to services.
Description: The percentage of individuals sentenced under 1170h and supervised under Mandatory Supervision who are referred by their probation officer to at least one service provider and/or program for housing, vocational, educational, health, mental health, substance abuse, or other services and assistance, as appropriate.
Technical Description: Probation officers track service referrals and report on the number of referrals made to supervisors and Division Directors. For referrals to programs run by service providers under contract with the department, probation officers complete service referral forms and forms are collected by the Reentry Division.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All individuals released to Mandatory Supervision are referred to services, including medical, behavioral health, job readiness, benefits assessment, and housing services, in accordance with their Individualized Treatment and Rehabilitation Plan.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of individuals on PRCS referred to services.
Description: The percentage of individuals on PRCS who are referred by their probation officer to at least one service provider and/or program for housing, vocational, educational, health, mental health, substance abuse, or other services and assistance, as appropriate. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Probation officers track service referrals and report on the number of referrals made to supervisors and Division Directors. For referrals to programs run by service providers under contract with the department, probation officers complete service referral forms and forms are collected by the Reentry Division.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All individual release to PRCS are referred to services, including medical, behavioral health, job readiness, benefits assessment, and housing services, in accordance with their Individualized Treatment and Rehabilitation plan.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of individuals released to Mandatory Supervision that initially report to the Adult Probation Department.
Description: Of those sentenced under 1170h and released to Mandatory Supervision with no holds from other jurisdictions, the percentage that reports to APD as required. Measure Definition revised March 15, 2013. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: This information is entered into the department's case management system, and reviewed regularly by Supervising Probation Officers and Division Directors. Data Collection Method and Frequency revised March 15, 2013.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: While all 1170(h) Mandatory Supervision clients receive an orientation upon release from jail by joint APD and SFSD partners, 100% did not receive a prerelease intake by their assigned probation officer.  During much of this reporting period, there was only one DPO full time assigned to this population with others participating in the state mandated training as new deputy probation officers.  Many 1170(h) MS clients also went through the Reentry Pod, opened on February 28th 2013, providing an opportunity of them to receive engagement prior to release intake.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of individuals released to Post Release Community Supervision that receive a comprehensive risk and needs assessment.
Description: Percentage of individuals released to PRCS receiving a risk and needs assessment.  Pre-release probation officers visit individuals who are housed at state prisons within a 50 mile radius prior to their release to PRCS and perform a comprehensive risk and needs assessment. Other individuals receive a risk and needs assessment during their initial intake at the Adult Probation Department. The purpose is to assess the individual's need, recommend the appropriate level of supervision, establish a case supervision plan, refer the individual to appropriate supportive services, and explain the terms and conditions of PRCS. Measure Definition revised March 15, 2013. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Statistics are entered into the department's case management system, and reported to supervisors and Division Directors on a weekly basis. Data Collection Method and Frequency revised March 15, 2013.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Seventy-seven percent of all individuals released to PRCS have had a risk and needs assessment, as of June 30, 2013.  Of those released to PRCS from January through June 2013, 86% received an assessment.  The Case Management policy, implemented in January 2013, which requires officers to complete an assessment at intake, is therefore increasing the proportion of PRCS clients with a completed assessment.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of individuals released to PRCS that report to the Adult Probation Department within 48 hours of their release.
Description: Of those released to PRCS, the percentage that reports to APD within two business days of their release from State Prison, as required. Measure Definition revised March 15, 2013. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Division Directors issue bench warrants for those individuals who do not report with 48 hours. This information is entered into the department’s case management system and reported weekly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Only 5 of the 80 PRCS clients released to APD from January to June 2013 did not report within 48 hours of their release from prison.  Arrest warrants are issued when clients fail to report within 48 hours.  Of the 5 clients, 4 of the warrants were served within one week.

Goal: Provide protection to the community through supervision and provision of appropriate services to adult probationers
Performance Measure: Percentage of seriously mentally ill or physically disabled individuals released from State Prison to PRCS who are provided transportation from State Prison upon their release.
Description: The percentage of seriously mentally ill or physically disabled individuals released from State Prison to PRCS who are provided transportation from Prison to San Francisco. NOTE: This is a new measure for FY2012-13. No target or reporting for FY 2011-12.
Technical Description: Supervising probation officer monitors the needs of individuals to be released to PRCS through case by case communication with the CDCR liaisons, and determines and coordinates transportation needs, and enters information into the department's case management system. Data Collection Method and Frequency revised March 15, 2013.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 95% of those individuals released from CDCR and identified as participating in EOP were provided transportation from state prison to San Francisco.  Those that were not provided transportation were released from prisons outside of a feasible radius from San Francisco.

Goal: Provide timely reports to guide the courts with rendering appropriate sentencing decisions
Performance Measure: Number of COMPAS risk/needs assessments and reassessments conducted
Description: Note: This is a new measure for Fiscal Year 2009-10, therefore there is no target or reporting for Fiscal Year 2008-09. Note: The Department transitioned to COMPAS Risk and Needs Assessment on July 2011. The name of "Measure", "Measure Definition", and "Data Collection Method and Frequency" were modified to reflect the change from CAIS to COMPAS risk/needs assessment on March 6, 2012. Evidence based practices for community supervision emphasize the need for a validated risk/needs assessment to inform supervision plans for probationers and identify underlying service needs. The Department uses the COMPAS risk/needs assessment. COMPAS generates an Individual Treatment Rehabilitation Plan for clients to address their needs.
Technical Description: The performance measure tracks the number of COMPAS assessments conducted, as well as the number of follow-up reassessments conducted. The number of reports will be obtained monthly from the secure website that manages the Department's COMPAS assessment data.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD exceeded by 18% due to the implementation of case management standards and comprehensive 30 day referral to conduct Risk & Needs Assessment.

Goal: Provide timely reports to guide the courts with rendering appropriate sentencing decisions
Performance Measure: Percentage of identifiable victims for whom notification was attempted prior to the sentencing of the defendant
Description: On every case where there is an identifiable victim with known contact information, the assigned probation officer is required to send a letter to the victim requesting victim information.  The requested information includes, amount of loss to the victim, whether or not the victim has insurance to cover the loss, if the victim contacted the insurance company, and if the insurance company paid the loss.  Additionally, the victim is requested to give their thoughts about the incident and the defendant.  Victims are also informed of their rights to address the Court at the time of sentencing, where they can get services, and their right to file a civil claim in the matter.  (Measure does not address cases with no identifiable victim, or those where a contact address or phone number cannot be obtained for an identified victim.)
Technical Description: Probation officers keep a log of all cases where there is an identifiable victim and the number of victims they attempted to contact.  This information is forwarded to their supervisor on a monthly basis.  The supervisor submits this information to the division director, who compiles the information for the division's monthly statistical report.  The statistical report reflects the number of identifiable victims and the number of contacts attempted.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 100% of victim contacts was achieved for those cases that had victim contact information.

Goal: Provide timely reports to guide the courts with rendering appropriate sentencing decisions
Performance Measure: Percentage of reports submitted to the Court prior to sentencing as defined in the Penal Code
Description: The California Penal Code mandates the circumstances under which the Adult Probation Department must submit a presentence report to the Superior Court.  This report guides the Court in its sentencing decisions. The Penal Code stipulates that the presentence report be submitted to the Court and affected parties five days prior to the sentencing hearing. Due to the shortage of staffing resources, the Department and the San Francisco Superior Court have an agreement that presentence reports may be submitted two days prior to the sentencing hearing.
Technical Description: Supervising Probation Officers keep a log of all reports completed in time to meet the five day delivery.  On a monthly basis they submit that information to the Division Director who prepares the statistical report for the Department.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: APD provided 17% of five days prior to court hearing that met the statutory requirement.

Goal: Provide timely reports to guide the courts with rendering appropriate sentencing decisions
Performance Measure: Percentage of reports submitted to the Court two days prior to sentencing as per agreement with the Courts
Description: The California Penal Code mandates the circumstances under which the Adult Probation Department must submit a presentence report to the Superior Court.  This report guides the Court in its sentencing decisions.  The Penal Code stipulates that the presentence report be submitted to the Court and affected parties five days prior to the sentencing hearing.  Due to the shortage of staffing resources, the Adult Probation Department and the San Francisco Superior Court have an agreement that presentence reports may be submitted two days prior to the sentencing hearing.
Technical Description: Supervising Probation Officers (SPOs) submit the completed presentence reports to the Court on a daily basis.  As part of the daily responsibilities they keep a log of all reports submitted and when they are submitted.  On a monthly basis the SPOs submit that information to the Division Director who prepares the statistical report for the Department.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Department submitted 97% of reports in a timely manner.

Goal: Contribute to the strength of the local economy
Performance Measure: Amount of annual service payment to the City's General Fund, in millions
Description: The Airline-Airport Lease and Use Agreement provides for a payment to the City's General Fund for indirect services that the City provides to the Airport.  During the term of the Lease and Use Agreement which expires on June 30, 2021, the payment is calculated as 15% of Concession Revenues as defined in the Agreement or $5 million, whichever is greater.  Concession Revenues include fees and rentals collected by the Commission from concession operations as follows: 1) restaurants, bars, news stands, gift shops, specialty shops, advertising displays, insurance, public telephone, and other merchandising concessions and consumer services in the Terminal Area;  2) courtesy vehicles, ground transportation services, car rental services, hotels, service stations and other concessions and services in the Groundside Area; and (3) automobile parking and traffic fines.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Annual Service Payment calculation is based on the cumulative totals from all concession sub-objects from FAMIS and multiplying by 15%. The Airport's Accounting Department keeps records of all supporting totals from the concession sub-objects used to calculate the Year-End Payment that is transmitted to the city. Timing:  Can be calculated monthly, approximately 7 weeks after the end of each month. Payment made annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The FY 13 year end annual service payment is estimated to total $36.5 million.  This is 7.6% above the Target Value and 7.3% above the prior year actual.  A combination of changes to the daily parking rates, increased Airport advertising activity and higher than expected rental car volume have all contributed to the increase.

Goal: Contribute to the strength of the local economy
Performance Measure: Percent change in domestic air passenger volume
Description: Percentage increase/decrease of enplaned passengers on domestic flights over prior period.  Enplanements is defined as passengers boarding a flight at SFO and does not include any passenger already on the flight ("in-transit").
Technical Description: Collection Method: Passenger enplanement data is reported monthly by air carriers and input into the Airport's Property Management and Billing System (PMBS).  Airport passenger forecasts are prepared by Financial Planning & Analysis and an independent consultant.  Timing: Data from PMBS is available approximately 20 days after the end of the reporting month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: A strong overall growth rate of 6.7% in the first half of the fiscal year moderated to 1.2% in the second half as most service additions by United Airlines and Virgin America completed one full year.  The result was 4.2% domestic growth, which generated 707,000 more enplanements than last fiscal year, 86% of which was from United Airlines and Virgin America.

Goal: Contribute to the strength of the local economy
Performance Measure: Percent change in international air passenger volume
Description: Percentage increase/decrease of enplaned passengers on international flights over prior period.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Passenger enplanement data is reported monthly by air carriers and input into the Airport's Property Management and Billing System (PMBS).  Airport passenger forecasts are prepared by Financial Planning & Analysis and LeighFisher consultants.   Timing: Data from PMBS is available approximately 20 days after the end of the reporting month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The international increase of 3.2% had 146,000 more enplanements, with a majority (89%) traveling to Asia, Europe and Latin America.  New international services to Copenhagen by SAS Airlines, Shanghai by China Eastern and Paris by United Airlines that began in April 2013 strengthened international traffic in the latter part of the fiscal year.

Goal: Control airline cost per enplaned passenger
Performance Measure: Airline cost per enplaned passenger
Description: Control costs to airlines by controlling airline landing fees and terminal rental per passenger.  The revenues budgeted for airline landing fees and terminal rentals represent the "airline requirement" based on the net of Airport expenditures and non-airline revenues.  Rates for landing fees and airline terminal rentals are formulated from the budgeted airline revenue and forecasts for aircraft landed weight and leased terminal space.  The target Cost Per Enplanement is a measure of the change in airline revenues, the numerator in this metric, in relation to changes in enplaned passengers, the denominator in this metric.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Quarterly calculation based on actual airline terminal rental revenue and airline landing fees paid/recorded in FAMIS and passenger enplanements data reported by airlines and entered to the Airport Business Manager (ABM) system and interfaced to the Airport's Cognos data warehouse.  The airline terminal rental and landing fee revenues as collected in FAMIS are summed and divided by enplaned passenger data from Cognos data warehouse reports to calculate the CPE. Timing: This can be calculated monthly, approximately 7 weeks after the end of each month.  Final figure available after year-end books close, usually in late September.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Enplanements were 3.2% above budget, compared to a 0.9% above budget actual for airline costs.  Inflation was at 2.6%.  These factors led to a CPE at year end that was 2.3% lower than the target, indicating a positive overall airport performance.  (A lower CPE is desirable for attracting airlines.)

Goal: Control airline cost per enplaned passenger
Performance Measure: Airline cost per enplaned passenger (in constant 2008 dollars)
Description: Control costs to airlines by controlling airline landing fees and terminal rental per passenger.  The revenues budgeted for Airline landing fees and terminal rentals represent the "Airline Requirement" based on the net of Airport expenditures and non-airline revenues.
