Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Employee performance reviews completed and on file with DHR. Timing:  Annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The projection for this metric was set to 11 at mid year to reflect the current number of staff for whom performance reviews would be completed. We are just below this projection for the year due to one staff member being on extended family leave.

Goal: Improve quality of preschool services
Performance Measure: Percent of funded classrooms achieving cut-off score on adult/child interactions
Description: Percent of funded classrooms assessed for CLASS-PreK in the current fiscal year that receive an average Emotional Support rating that is equal to or greater than 5.0
Technical Description: Independent CLASS assessments as conducted by West Ed Quality Connections for a portion of sites annually so that each site receives an assessment every two years. Assessment data is entered into the WELLS database following the assessment and will be pulled at mid-year and end-of-year.

Goal: Improve quality of preschool services
Performance Measure: Percent of funded classrooms achieving cut-off score on instruction
Description: Percent of funded classroom assessed for CLASS-PreK in the current fiscal year that receive an average Instructional Support rating that is equal to or greater than 3.0
Technical Description: Independent CLASS assessments as conducted by West Ed Quality Connections for a portion of sites annually so that each site receives an assessment every two years. Assessment data is entered into the WELLS database following the assessment and will be pulled at mid-year and end-of-year.

Goal: Improve quality of preschool services
Performance Measure: Percent of funded classrooms with an environment rating of 5 or above
Description: Percent of funded classrooms assessed for ECERS in the current fiscal year that receive an average score of 5.0.
Technical Description: Independent ERS assessments as conducted by West Ed Quality Connections for a portion of sites annually so that each site receives an assessment every two years. Assessment data is entered into the WELLS database following the assessment and will be pulled at mid-year and end-of-year.

Goal: Improve quality of preschool services
Performance Measure: The percentage of parents who feel their child is enrolled in a quality preschool
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of parents surveyed through the DRDP Parent Survey who answer "Very Satisfied" or "Satisfied" to the question, "How satisfied are you with the overall quality of this program?" The DRDP-PS Parent Survey is administered on an annual basis by PFA preschool sites to all parents with children enrolled at that site.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of survey results through various media, including online; soft copy aggregates; and hard copy disaggregates. Timing: Annually, end of preschool year (May-June).
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: This measure is added under the quality preschool goal in this reporting cycle -- in parallel with metrics under school readiness from the DRDP-PS child assessment -- to supplement the Performance Measures profile of the Public Education Enrichment Fund.  These new metrics represent part of the department strategy to track and understand outcomes for children participating in the Preschool For All (PFA) initiative.  The DRDP-PS survey is a longstanding requirement for preschool provider participation, and is a foundational piece of outcome data collection efforts associated with the initiative.

Goal: Increase access to high quality preschool
Performance Measure: Number of four-year olds enrolled in Preschool For All (PFA) program
Description: Number of four-year olds enrolled in Preschool for All and who thus have access to high quality preschool.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Provider Funding Agreements, Monthly Enrollment Updates from Preschool Providers, Monitoring Reports Timing:  Semi-annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Despite unexpected attrition -- site closures due to enrollment consolidation and other factors -- and slower than expected growth in the number of PFA providers, the PFA initiative came within 3% of its target enrollment through supplemental funding to support new classroom placements at PFA sites for children at-risk of losing their existing subsidies at non-PFA sites.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The department has employed a new method of data aggregation for this metric, which more reliably minimizes duplicate child counts that might artificially inflate the figure.

Goal: Increase access to high quality preschool
Performance Measure: Number of new preschool slots created
Description: Accounts for the number of new preschool slots created in either of the scenarios listed below, supported by PEEF investments.  A “preschool slot” is space for regular, ongoing preschool program enrollment of one child who ages-3-years by December 2nd of the Program Year, at a preschool licensed by the Community Care Licensing Division of the State Department of Social Services (either Center-based, or Family Child Care). • Newly-created sessions; classrooms; or facilities, which make additional preschool slots available during the reporting period and are supported at least in part by PEEF investment • Expansion of operational capacity within existing preschool sessions which make additional preschool slots available during the reporting period, supported at least in part by PEEF investment
Technical Description: Collection method is internal aggregation of system-wide facilities development data reported by grantees as a condition of facilities development and other “pre-PFA” PEEF investments. Source:  Grantee information about facilities development, with data hosted internally (spreadsheets maintained as-needed) on department data directory. Method:  Recording of new slot data in internal data spreadsheets as grantees operationalize new sessions; classrooms; and/or facilities as indicated above.  Data is obtained via email and phone site status reports (informal). Frequency:  As-needed, minimum monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Ahead-of-schedule site expansion projects resulted in a small number of new preschool classroom spaces becoming available prior to close of FY-2013, earlier than projected.

Goal: Increase access to high quality preschool
Performance Measure: Number of vulnerable children maintaining preschool enrollment
Description: Number of vulnerable children maintaining their preschool enrollment through a PFA-tuition enhancement or PFA-bridge funding that targets mainly low-income children whose enrollments are subsidized by California State Preschool Program (CSPP) funding, like Title 5 subsidies, CalWORKs vouchers or the federal Head Start program.
Technical Description: "Vulnerable children" is defined as the children whose  preschool enrollments are funded and/or subsidized by the followng funding types: PFA/CSPP Full Day; PFA/CSPP Part Day; PFA/Head Start; PFA/APP/calWORKs, PFA/PreschoolPlus, Voucher Bridge, and Head Start supplement. Funding and subsidy information for each child participant is entered into the COCOA database monthly and will be pulled at mid-year and end-of-year.

Goal: Increase access to high quality preschool
Performance Measure: Percent of preschoolers enrolled in high-need neighborhoods
Description: Percent of PFA-funded four year olds enrolled in high-needs San Francisco neighborhoods, including the Inner and Outer Mission, Bernal Heights, Ingleside-Excelsior, Bayview, Visitacion Vally, the Inner Sunset, Outer Richmond, Hayes Valley and the Tenderloin.
Technical Description: High Needs Neighborhoods are identified by the CPAC Needs Assessment, which is conducted every five years to assess San Francisco's licensed ECE care capacity and needs. Zip code data for each child participant is entered into the COCOA database monthly and will be pulled at mid-year and end-of-year.

Goal: Increase preschool workforce development opportunities
Performance Measure: Number of PFA classroom teachers who hold a Bachelor's degree or higher
Description: Individuals eligible to receive awards through the BA Bonus initiative are classroom teachers at PFA sites who hold a minimum Bachelor's degree.
Technical Description: The number of BA bonus recipients who work in PFA classrooms are reported by the initiative's fiscal agent at mid-year (January) and year-end (July).

Goal: Increase preschool workforce development opportunities
Performance Measure: Number of Preschool For All (PFA) staff participating in PFA professional development activities
Description: This measures specifies the number of preschool staff involved in professional development activities, which includes teacher in-service trainings on arts, literacy and science; learning circles; and family involvement and inclusion trainings.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Workshop enrollment forms and education unit verification, sign-in sheets. Timing:  Semi-annual.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Revenue from the Child Signature Program award to First 5 San Francisco from First 5 California increased department's budget for planning and implementing preschool instructional supports.  This resulted in greater numbers of professional development and training activities offered by First 5 San Francisco and its PFA partners, as well as larger capacities within those activities to meet the strong demand among in-ratio preschool teachers for access to these resources.

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Number of classrooms participating in arts initiative
Description: This measure specifies the PFA Arts Initiative that will enhance existing arts programming at preschool sites, and includes: professional development for preschool teachers, and services to children that increase their exposure to the arts.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Site Director Reports; site activity sheets. Timing:  Annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Augmentations to the department's budget for arts enhancements (to attempt to meet provider demand for these enhancements) and efficiencies achieved by the contractor allowed for the initiative to reach more classrooms than originally projected for 2012/13.  This increase was made possible after budgeting for 2013/14 in January-February, 2013, so was not captured in the update of "Projection" figures in this Performance Measures system.

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Number of PFA classrooms participating in early literacy curriculum enhancements
Description: PFA classrooms that maintain a partnership MOU to implement the Raising A Reader initiative, including preparation of materials and classroom; orientation of parents/caregivers; and rotation of materials that support early literacy development.
Technical Description: Data on participating classrooms is reported on a quarterly basis through a web-based contract management system.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Augmentations to the department's budget for early literacy enhancements (to attempt to meet provider demand for these enhancements), and efficiencies achieved by the contractor allowed for the initiative to reach more classrooms than originally projected for 2012/13.  This increase was made possible after budgeting for 2013/14 in January-February, 2013, so was not captured in the update of "Projection" figures in this Performance Measures system.

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Percentage of children assessed at the highest levels of cognitive development at the end of the pre-kindergarten year
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of children at SFUSD preschools who at the end of the preschool year are performing at one of the two highest developmental levels (out of four), across the five measures that are classified under the domain of Cognitive Development, using the Desired Results Developmental Profile – Preschool.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of child assessment results through online reporting. Timing: annually, end of preschool year (June).

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Percentage of children assessed at the highest levels of cognitive development at the end of the pre-kindergarten year
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of children at SFUSD preschools who at the end of the preschool year are performing at one of the two highest developmental levels (out of four), across the five measures that are classified under the domain of Cognitive Development, using the Desired Results Developmental Profile – Preschool.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of child assessment results through online reporting. Timing: annually, end of preschool year (June).
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: This measure is added under the school readiness goal in this reporting cycle -- in parallel with metrics from the DRDP-PS parent survey -- to supplement the Performance Measures profile of the Public Education Enrichment Fund.  These new metrics represent part of the department strategy to track and understand outcomes for children participating in the Preschool For All (PFA) initiative.  The DRDP-PS child developmental assessment is a longstanding requirement for preschool provider participation, and is a foundational piece of outcome data collection efforts associated with the initiative.  The tool is also an important element of the state’s nascent tiered quality rating and improvement system (TQRIS), which aims to ultimately provide quality ratings for all early childhood programs statewide.

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Percentage of children assessed at the highest levels of self and social development at the end of the pre-kindergarten year
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of children at SFUSD preschools who at the end of the preschool year are performing at one of the two highest developmental levels (out of five), across the 12 measures that are classified under the domain of Self and Social Development, using the Desired Results Developmental Profile – Preschool.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of child assessment results through online reporting. Timing: annually, end of preschool year (June).

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: Percentage of children assessed at the highest levels of self and social development at the end of the pre-kindergarten year
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of children at SFUSD preschools who at the end of the preschool year are performing at one of the two highest developmental levels (out of five), across the 12 measures that are classified under the domain of Self and Social Development, using the Desired Results Developmental Profile – Preschool.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of child assessment results through online reporting. Timing: annually, end of preschool year (June).
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: This measure is added under the school readiness goal in this reporting cycle -- in parallel with metrics from the DRDP-PS parent survey -- to supplement the Performance Measures profile of the Public Education Enrichment Fund.  These new metrics represent part of the department strategy to track and understand outcomes for children participating in the Preschool For All (PFA) initiative.  The DRDP-PS child developmental assessment is a longstanding requirement for preschool provider participation, and is a foundational piece of outcome data collection efforts associated with the initiative.  The tool is also an important element of the state’s nascent tiered quality rating and improvement system (TQRIS), which aims to ultimately provide quality ratings for all early childhood programs statewide.

Goal: Provide preschool sites with enhancements to improve children's readiness for school
Performance Measure: The percentage of parents who feel PFA sites will help their children succeed in school
Description: This measure specifies the percentage of parents surveyed through the DRDP-PS Parent Survey who answer "Yes" to the question, "Do you feel this program helps or will help your child succeed in school?" The DRDP-PS Parent Survey is administered on an annual basis by PFA preschool sites to all parents with children enrolled at that site.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Submission by preschools of survey results through various media, including online; soft copy aggregates; and hard copy disaggregates. Timing: Annually, end of preschool year (May-June).
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: This measure is added under the school readiness goal in this reporting cycle -- in parallel with metrics from the DRDP-PS child assessment -- to supplement the Performance Measures profile of the Public Education Enrichment Fund.  These new metrics represent part of the department strategy to track and understand outcomes for children participating in the Preschool For All (PFA) initiative.  The DRDP-PS survey is a longstanding requirement for preschool provider participation, and is a foundational piece of outcome data collection efforts associated with the initiative.

Goal: Support the health of children and youth
Performance Measure: Number of high school students served at school Wellness Centers
Description: As opposed to the prior measure that looks at the number of students enrolled at high schools that have wellness centers, this measure focuses on the number of students who use wellness centers.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Wellness centers report the number of students served on the department's Contract Management System. Timing:  Data is reported on a monthly basis through the department's Contract Management System.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: There was a slight increase in the number of students served by Wellness Centers in FY2012-2013. We have added Wellness Centers to two more high schools for FY2013-2014, so we expect to increase our target next year.

Goal: Improve the availability and quality of DCYF-funded programs/services
Performance Measure: Number of children, youth, and their families participating in programs/services funded by the Children's Fund
Description: Original:  An unduplicated count of all children and youth who enrolled in DCYF-funded programs. Service areas included in are early care and education, afterschool, workforce development, teen programming, wellness, violence prevention, and parent support.   Revised:  This measure reflects the total number of children and youth who receive ongoing services and for whom we collect client-level data.The measure only reflects children and youth who participate in programs funded fully or in-part by the Children's Fund.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected and calculated through the Contracts Management System, a secured web-based system maintained by the department. Timing:  Data is available on an ongoing basis as part of the Contract Management System.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: There was a significant drop in people served by DCYF programs and services due to a few major factors. One of our largest agencies had data that needed major clean-up, which accounted for a drop of 6,000 served. That same agency had high duplicated participant counts, so after deduplication, participant counts dropped by 1,500. Our Violence Prevention and Intervention strategy had an RFP timeline that ended mid-year, so programs that served youth through the first half of the year were counted, as well as those that were funded in the latter half of the year, leading to an inflation in participant count by about 2,300 last year. We have since changed the VPI RFP to align with the fiscal year. Finally, we no longer count Early Care and Education grants; First 5 has taken over these grants. Our target of 50,000 was met, however, and we anticipate increasing the target next year.

Goal: Improve the availability and quality of DCYF-funded programs/services
Performance Measure: Percentage of Children's Fund grant recipients who meet at least 50% of their DCYF Performance Measures.
Description: DCYF grantees agree to various DCYF Performance Measures as a condition of their grant. These measures generally reflect the number of youth to be served, the amount of services received, and the level of youth-reported satisfaction with the program. The exact number and type of measures vary based on the service area of the DCYF-funded program. A grantee must be in compliance with at least 50% of their DCYF Performance Measures to be counted.
Technical Description: Collection Method: DCYF-funded programs report program participation and attendance data into the department's Contract Management System (CMS), a secure, web-based system. Data entered into the CMS is used to calculate the performance measures related to services rendered. Performance measures related to youth-reported satisfaction with programs is determined by responses collected via the annual DCYF Youth Surveys. Timing: Both service and satisfaction data pertaining to DCYF Performance Measures are not available until a few months after the end of the fiscal year, typically in late October, due to the time-consuming process of cleaning, organizing and analyzing the data.

Goal: Improve the availability and quality of DCYF-funded programs/services
Performance Measure: Percentage of grantee organizations that rate the quality of service and support they receive from DCYF as very good to excellent
Description: Of grantee organizations surveyed annually, the percent that report that the services and supports provided by DCYF were very good to excellent. Based on a five point likert scale with 4 and 5 representing very good to excellent.
Technical Description: DCYF will develop and administer a grantee satisfaction survey annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: DCYF is requesting an exemption for this measure this year. We initially asked for the measure to be postponed, as we usually do, due to the timing of the survey, because we usually do not send them to our programs until November. However, we are now asking for an exemption because this is a year where we wrapped up a funding cycle, began a new one, and launched our Community Needs Assessment. Due to these major shifts and projects, it does not make sense for us to evaluate our programs right now. We are proposing that we move the surveys to mid-June rather than November so that we can catch programs at the end of the fiscal year. That way, we will have the numbers ready when we begin filling out our year-end Performance Measures again next September, and we will also be able to avoid the awkward transition stage every three years when our funding cycle ends.

Goal: Improve the outcomes of youth that have been identified as at-risk for poor social and educational outcomes
Performance Measure: Number of youth 14-24 years old in DCYF-funded case management program receiving case management services
Description: This measure is a count of 14 to 24 year olds who are receiving case management services.  Case management services include an assessment of need and development of a case plan.  Services can last two months to one year based on need.
Technical Description: Count of 14 to 24 year olds who receive at least one hour of case management services and have been assessed.  Data is tracked on a quarterly basis through the department's contract management system.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: There was a moderate increase in the number of youth receiving case management services. We anticipate increasing our target for next year.

Goal: Improve the outcomes of youth that have been identified as at-risk for poor social and educational outcomes
Performance Measure: Percentage of youth in DCYF-funded detention alternative programs who do not have a petition filed during program participation
Description: Percentage of youth who are assigned to a community-based detention alternative program funded by DCYF who do not have a petition file during their engagement with the program.
Technical Description: Total number of youth who have a petition filed while participating in a DCYF-funded detention alternative program divided by the total number of youth participating in detention alternative programs during the same period. Program participation data will be reported through DCYF's contract management system and matched to DPH JJIS data at the end of each fiscal year to determine result.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The percentage of youth in detention alternative programs who did not have a petition filed against them held steady from last year. We expect to increase our target for next year.

Goal: Improve the outcomes of youth that have been identified as at-risk for poor social and educational outcomes
Performance Measure: Percentage of youth who are taken to the Truancy Assessment and Referral Center (TARC) that receive a minimum of three weeks of service after the initial contact and a total of 6 or more hours of case management services.
Description: Youth taken to TARC will be assessed to determine needs. TARC will provide at least three weeks of case management services after initial contact and a total of 6 or more hours for at least 75% of youth taken to TARC.
Technical Description: Number of youth who receive a minimum of 3 weeks of services after initial contact with TARC divided by the number of youth taken to TARC during reporting period. Service hours are reported through DCYF's contract management system.

Goal: Increase the availability and quality of out-of-school time programs
Performance Measure: Number of 6 to 13 year olds attending summer programs funded by DCYF an average of five hours per week
Description: DCYF funds summer programs across the city. This measure is the count of participants ages 6 to 13 that participated in summer programs an average of five hours a week.
Technical Description: Program participation is reported through DCYF's contract management system. For this measure the total summer hours will be divided by the weeks of participation for each youth (year to date weeks minus school year weeks) to determine the number of youth who averaged five hours of week of participation.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The number of youth attending summer programming has slightly decreased, but the change is not significant. We have exceeded our target, and we anticipate increasing the target next year.

Goal: Increase the availability and quality of out-of-school time programs
Performance Measure: Number of children and youth attending afterschool programs for five or more hours per week
Description: The total number of children and youth ages 6 to 13 that participate in DCYF-funded out-of-school time 3-5 day and teen programs for five or more hours per week.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is provided by funded agencies through DCYF's Contract Management System. Timing:  Data is collected monthly and analyzed quarterly. Data is available 8 weeks following the end of any quarter. The number is calculated by taking the number of hours of attendance per youth and dividing it by the number of weeks in the quarter (39 weeks for the school year) and then summing the number of youth with 5 hours/week.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: There was a slight decrease in the number of youth attending afterschool programs. The difference is not significant, and we expect to raise our target for next year.

Goal: Increase the availability and quality of out-of-school time programs
Performance Measure: Percentage of afterschool time program participants who report that there is an adult at the funded program who really cares about them
Description: Percentage of program participants surveyed that agree somewhat or strongly that there is an adult in their program that really cares about them.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Consumer satisfaction survey administered to program participants in out-of-school time programs. The result for this measure is calculated by taking the total number of participants that agree or strongly agree with the following question divided by the total number of you who responded to the survey: "There is an adult at this program who really cares about me." Timing:  Satisfaction survey for program participants in out-of-school is administered on an annual basis. Results are available at the end of each fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The percentage of youth that answered positively slightly increased from last year, and we have exceeded our target. We expect to increase the target slightly next year.

Goal: Increase the availability and quality of out-of-school time programs
Performance Measure: Percentage of participants in afterschool programs who report enhanced enjoyment and engagement in learning as a result of the program
Description: One of the investment goals of out-of-school time programs is to help participants build skills in an engaging environment, thereby enhancing their enjoyment of the learning process. This measure examines the success of programs to enhance enjoyment of learning from the participant's perspective.
Technical Description: Participants will be surveyed at the end of each fiscal year. Participants will be asked three questions related to this measure. Youth will be asked three questions related to this measure. The result for this measure is calculated by taking the total number of youth that agree or strongly agree to at least two of the three questions divided by the total number of you who responded to the survey.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The percentage of youth that answered positively slightly decreased from last year, but the difference is not significant. The target of 6% appears to be a typo; we have it recorded as 75%, and we don't expect to change the target next year.

Goal: Prepare San Francisco youth 14 to 17 years old for a productive future by helping them to develop the skills and competencies needed to succeed in school and work
Performance Measure: Number of 14 to 17 year olds placed in a job (subsidized or unsubsidized), internship, or on-the-job training program (excluding the Mayor's Summer Jobs+ Program)
Description: This measure is a count of 14 to 17 year olds that are place in a job, internship or on-the-job training program.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure is reported by grantees through the Contract Management System on an ongoing basis. Timing:  Data is available on an ongoing basis and will be analyzed biannually.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The number of youth receiving job placements align with numbers from the previous year, but it is lower than the anticipated target. We don't expect to change the target due to an increase in Youth Workforce Development funding for FY2013-14.

Goal: Prepare San Francisco youth 14 to 17 years old for a productive future by helping them to develop the skills and competencies needed to succeed in school and work
Performance Measure: Number of 14 to 17 years old served by DCYF-funded YLEAD programs
Description: The total number of 14 to 17 year olds participating in one of the following DCYF-funded programs Youth Leadership, Empowerment And Development (YLEAD) investment areas: Youth Workforce Development, Specialized Teen, Youth Empowerment and Wellness Programs.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  Data is provided by funded agencies through DCYF’s Contract Management System.  The number is calculated by obtaining an unduplicated count of participants ages 14-17 who attended individual or group activities from funded programs in the YLEAD strategy, or were placed in a job, internship, or on-the-job training program.  Timing: Data is collected monthly and analyzed biannually.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: There was a slight decrease in the number of youth 14-17 served, from 13,443 in FY2011-12 to 12,051 in FY2012-13. It is still above our target, and so we expect to increase the target in FY2013-14.

Goal: Prepare San Francisco youth 14 to 17 years old for a productive future by helping them to develop the skills and competencies needed to succeed in school and work
Performance Measure: Percentage of 14 to 17 year olds in specialized teen programs who report enhanced enjoyment and engagement in learning as a result of the program
Description: Specialized Teen Programs are those programs that provide youth with at least 80 hours of skill building in an area of interest to the youth. The goal of the specialized teen investment is to help youth build skills in an engaging environment, thereby enhancing their enjoyment of the learning process.
Technical Description: Teens will be surveyed at the end of each fiscal year. Youth will be asked three questions related to this measure. The result for this measure is calculated by taking the total number of youth that agree or strongly agree to at least two of the three questions divided by the total number of you who responded to the survey.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The percentage of youth that responded positively has held steady from last year, and we have met our target of 75%. We do not expect to change the target next year.

Goal: Prepare San Francisco youth 14 to 17 years old for a productive future by helping them to develop the skills and competencies needed to succeed in school and work
Performance Measure: Percentage of youth in YWD programs who report developing education or career goals and learning the steps needed to achieve their goals
Description: Youth participating in Youth Workforce Development (YWD) programs who report that their program helped them develop education and/or career goals and helped them identify the steps they need to take to achieve their goals.
Technical Description: Youth will complete a survey annually on which they will be asked if they developed education and/or career goals and learned the steps to achieving their goals. The measure is calculated by taking percentage of youth with a positive result to be the number who confirm setting goals steps AND learning the steps to achieve their goals (at least one of the two related questions) divided by the number of youth who completed the survey.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The percentage of youth responding positively decreased slightly. We did not meet our target of 75%, but we do not expect to lower the target due to an increase in YWD funding for FY2013-14.

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion. Timing:  The data is available on an ongoing basis as appraisals are conducted.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The number of scheduled employee performance appraisals dropped slightly this year due to vacancies, temp positions, and some staff turnover. Because we expect this to be the case for almost every year, we anticipate lowering the target next year.

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year. Timing: This metric will be reported on an annual basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The number of employee performance appraisals completed increased from 17 to 20. We are still short of the target due to vacancies, temp positions, and staff turnover. Because we do not expect the number of full-time permanent staff to be anywhere near 33, we anticipate lowering the target next year.

Goal: Ensure that the City follows appropriate accounting procedures
Performance Measure: Number of audit findings with questioned costs in annual Single Audit of federal grants
Description: Revised Measure:  This measure accounts for findings with questioned costs reported by external auditors in the Single Audit consisting of compliance and internal control audit as well as financial audit of federal grants awarded to the City.  Single audits are completed well after year-end and are asscociated with the data for the previous fiscal year. The actual number of findings is not known for prior year until February or March of each successive year.
Technical Description: Collection Method: AOSD Operations Unit. Timing: FY2013-14 Audit will be completed by 3/31/2015. Findings will be available at that time. Preliminary potential issues are estimated to be 4 or fewer questioned costs.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The measure has been revised so that only findings with questioned costs will be reported.

Goal: Ensure that the City follows appropriate accounting procedures
Performance Measure: Number of findings of material weakness in annual City audit
Description: Material weaknesses in the City's financial practices as determined by the City's external auditors.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Management letter from external auditors.  Letters are kept by CAFR team in  Controller's Systems and Reporting offices. Timing:  The data is available annually, after the annual audit is complete and are associated with data from the previous fiscal year.

Goal: Manage the Citywide family of financial professionals
Performance Measure: Percentage of 16 major departments that have been trained this year on cost recovery policies and procedures and related topics
Description: The Controller's Office will develop, maintain and implement a continuity of operations and emergency response plan. The Controller's Office will exercise this plan annually and provide training elements of this plan to the City departments that comprise the "big sixteen" that are the key responders during an emergency, as well as any other departments as identified.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Controller's Adminisatration Division Timing:  Timing of trainings can vary from year-to-year.  Accordingly, reporting on this measure will occur at the end of each fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Human Services Agency was trained on shelter and feeding cost recovery for the 2013 Golden Guardian exercise. This training also included non-profits. The main focus in 2013 was to train the Controller's management and lead staff on the Controller's Office Continuity of Operations Plan.

Goal: Provide accurate, timely financial reporting
Performance Measure: City receives certificate of achievement for excellence in financial reporting from Government Finance Officers Association (1 equals yes)
Description: Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting, awarded by the Government Finance Officers Association of the United States and Canada.  Reflects an easily readable and efficiently organized Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR). "1" equals yes, "0" equals no.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Measure reflects award for previous FY CAFR.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: We have not yet , but still expect to receive the GFOA Award.

Goal: Provide accurate, timely financial reporting
Performance Measure: Number of days from previous fiscal year end to complete the City's comprehensive financial report
Description: The number of days to complete the Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR) is the date when the auditors complete their fieldwork subtracted from June 30th.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Date used by the external auditors on their opinion letters for the City annual audit based on data from the previous fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Should be 192 days.

Goal: Provide effective systems for Citywide payroll, budgeting, accounting and purchasing functions
Performance Measure: Average Percentage of scheduled time that systems are available for departmental use
Description: REVISED TO INCLUDE ALL SYSTEMS IN FULL PRODUCTION, NOT JUST FAMIS The system should be available every day from 7 AM to 6 PM daily except for scheduled maintenance.  There should be no more than 3 hours of unscheduled down time per month.
Technical Description: Collection Method: We track system availabiity on a spreadsheet by tracking the date and time of system problems and send notices to users by email.  Data is kept in: N:Finance\\\\AOSD Systems Performance Measures\\\\Unscheduled Systems Downtime.. Timing:  Data is updated whenever a system is unavailable.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: EIS VM servers continue to provide reliability and stability to EIS processes. Cutover of PowerPlay Enterprise Server to VM on 7/18/2013 replaced last trouble-prone physical server.

Goal: Audit departments, contractors, and concessions timely to minimize risk to the City
Performance Measure: Count of code required audits completed
Description: Measure definition: The measure will be a simple count of the number of Administrative Code mandated audits completed.
Technical Description: Collection Method and frequency: Mandated audits will be counted as completed. The count will capture all audits done during the applicable reporting period ( mid-year, fiscal year-end and as requested.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Based on actual number of audits completed as mandated by Admin Code and work plan

Goal: Conduct audits and projects efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of audits completed within hours budgeted
Description: Each audit has a budgeted number of hours required to perform the work and issue a report. This measure will take the budgeted number of hours required to complete the audit, over the actual number of hours used to perform the work and issue a report.  Audits that were completed within the budgeted number of hours will be considered as  "completed within hours budgeted."
Technical Description: Collection Method: For each audit that is completed within the applicable reporting period, extract data on budgeted hours and actual hours from OpenAir. Frequency: The value for this measure will be updated as audits are completed and are issued.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY12-13 actual of 51% was based on the actual number of audits completed within hours budgeted. Generated as of 8/29/2013.

Goal: Conduct audits and projects efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of planned audits completed within scheduled deadline
Description: Each planned audit (i.e., those that are included in the published CSA workplan) has a scheduled deadline for completion. The date is the actual date the final report is released to the client and/or the Controller's website. This measure will be a simple count of all audits that have met the scheduled deadline for completion and then divided by the count for all completed planned audits. Audits that were completed within the scheduled deadline will be considered as "completed within scheduled deadline."
Technical Description: Collection Method: For each audit that is completed within the applicable reporting period, extract data on scheduled deadline for completion and actual date of completion from OpenAir. Frequency: The value for this measure will be updated as audits are completed and are issued.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY12-13 actual is based on the actual number of audits completed within scheduled deadline. Efforts are underway to ensure completion of deliverables within scheduled deadline.

Goal: Conduct audits and projects efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of planned projects completed within scheduled deadline
Description: Each planned project (i.e., those that are included in the published CSA workplan) has a scheduled deadline for completion. The date is the actual date the final major milestone, as indicated in a project agreement, is reached. This measure will be a simple count of all projects that have met the scheduled deadline for completion and then divided by the count for all completed planned projects.  Projects that were completed within the scheduled deadline will be considered as "completed within scheduled deadline."
Technical Description: Collection Method: For each project that is completed within the applicable reporting period, extract data on scheduled deadline for completion and actual date of completion from OpenAir.  Frequency: The value for this measure will be updated as projects are completed and are issued.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: As of the 6 month mark, 100% of completed projects were on schedule. However; as more FY13 projects are closed out, those that lag their schedule will come into the calculation and drop the number. As of the 6 month mark, about 78% of in-progress projects were on schedule.

Goal: Conduct audits and projects efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of projects completed within hours budgeted
Description: Each project has a budgeted number of hours required to perform the work and complete the deliverables.  This measure will take the budgeted number of hours required to complete the project, over the actual number of hours used to perform the work and complete the deliverables.  Projects that were completed within the budgeted number of hours will be considered as "completed within hours budgeted."
Technical Description: Collection Method: For each project that is completed within the applicable reporting period, extract data on budgeted hours and actual hours from OpenAir. Frequency: The value for this measure will be updated as projects are completed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Staff training, multiple projects are affecting efficiency

Goal: Provide effective consulting, technical assistance and audit services to City departments to improve their operations
Performance Measure: Percentage of audit recommendations implemented within 2 years after report issuance.
Description: All recommendations included in the Unit's audits and assessments are followed up on at 6-months, 12-months, 18 -months, and 24-months after the date of issuance to determine whether corrective actions have been taken by the department to address recommendations. A recommendation is considered implemented or closed, if, based on the follow-up results, the department has taken appropriate corrective actions to address the original intent of the recommendation.
Technical Description: CSA Audits will use the results of its' recommendation follow-up at the 24-month juncture (i.e., from time of report issuance) as the basis for calculating this percentage. Results of 24-month follow-up will be reviewed to derive this percentage and determine what portion of the population of recommendations have been implemented or closed

Goal: Provide effective consulting, technical assistance and audit services to City departments to improve their operations
Performance Measure: Percentage of auditee ratings that are good or excellent
Description: Measure definition: An auditee survey document is used to inquire of auditees about the effectiveness, quality, timeliness of the audit, professionalism of audit staff, and communication of concerns and findings during the audit (regardless of agreement or disagreement of the findings).
Technical Description: Collection Method and frequency: Surveys will be sent to each applicable auditee as part of the closeout process for each project/audit. Rating calculation will capture all survey results during the applicable reporting period (mid-year, fiscal year-end and as requested.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The actual value for the year-end measure (FY2012-13) was 70%, based on actual Auditee Survey Results completed between 7/1/2012 - 6/30/2013.

Goal: Provide effective consulting, technical assistance and audit services to City departments to improve their operations
Performance Measure: Percentage of client ratings for technical assistance projects that are good or excellent
Description: Measure definition: Project evaluations are collected which ask clients and users about the quality of the outcomes, project management and professionalism of the city performance staff.  Clients and users rate on a five point scale from Execllent to Poor.  Multiple evaluations may be collected if a project has several sponsors or users.
Technical Description: Collection Method and frequency: Evaluations will be done as part of the closeout process for each project and. Rating calculation will capture all evaluations done during that period (six months, fiscal year total, etc.)
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: none

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: CON HR Office files. Timing:  Employees scheduled for performance appraisals varies throughout the fiscal year as employees enter or leave the department or promote within.  Accordingly, data will be collected at the end of each fiscal year.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: CON HR Office files. Timing:  Employees scheduled for performance appraisals varies throughout the fiscal year as employees enter or leave the department or promote within.  Accordingly, data will only be collected at the end of each fiscal year.

Goal: Recognize and reward employee contributions and ensure employee satisfaction
Performance Measure: Percentage of employees who agree with the statement:  Overall, I'm satisfied with the Controller's Office as a place to work and grow
Description: New measure developed in FY07 by Controller's Office as a result of ongoing evaluation and discussion relating to goal setting and tracking for the Office. The Office has set goals for training.  A component of this measure is to identify areas in the workplace enviornment that can be improved and barriers to growth so that corrective actions can be taken.
Technical Description: Collection Method: CON Bi-Annual Climate Survey. Timing:  After issuance of Bi-Annual Climate Survey.

Goal: Provide timely economic and operational analyses to inform legislation and management decisions
Performance Measure: Percentage of OEA economic impact reports completed by the hearing date
Description: Percentage of OEA economic impact reports completed by the hearing date.
Technical Description: Technical Description: Data is collected by comparing the date a report is filed with the Clerk of the Board of Supervisors with the date the item is first heard in committee.

Goal: Provide efficient and effective central employment management systems functions - Payroll, Time Reporting, Human Resources
Performance Measure: On-time delivery of business information to business partners, through reports and/or data transmission
Description: Percentage of reports delievered on-time by system Percentage of data transmissions delievered on-time GEAC Reports - 272 Data Transmissions - 132 PeopleSoft Reports - 587 Data Transmissions - 74 TESS Data Transmissions - 6 No more than 5% of the combined reports/data transmission by systems are late
Technical Description: Each system support team tracks delayed delivery through incident logs
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The overall figure is 99.43%. This number includes GEAC, PeopleSoft 7.5, TESS and eMerge PeopleSoft. The number for eMerge only is higher (99.62%) but only tracks the success of outbound interfaces. It was not possible to track success of all reports and data transmissions in eMerge, so we hope to replace this metric to something more meaningful and measurable in FY14.

Goal: Provide efficient and effective central employment management systems functions - Payroll, Time Reporting, Human Resources
Performance Measure: Percentage of scheduled time that systems are available for central and local departmental use
Description: Standard hours of availability by system: PeopleSoft HR/Benefits - 5 a.m. to 8 p.m. (15 hours daily) GEAC Payroll - 24 hours daily TESS Time Reporting - 24 hours daily, except 9 a.m. Thursday to Noon Friday, alternating weeks No more than 5% unscheduled down time per month per system.
Technical Description: Each system support team tracks application downtime using incident logs that describe the outage, duration and resolution.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY13 number of 99.66% includes GEAC, PeopleSoft 7.5, TESS and eMerge PeopleSoft. The number for eMerge only is lower (99.56%).

Goal: Provide accurate, timely information to support fiscal planning
Performance Measure: Percentage by which actual General Fund revenues vary from prior year revised budget estimates
Description: This is the difference between budgeted and actual General Fund revenues plus transfers in.  The budget figures are the Revised Budget as stated in the annual Six-Month Budget Status Report.  The actual revenues are as stated in the CAFR.  The target is a maximum percentage; i.e., the objective is to project revenues as close to actual as possible. 10/6/11: All historic year actuals moved up by one year to correspond to new definition. DMM
Technical Description: Collection Method: Difference between total General Fund revenues and transfers in per the CAFR and 6-Month Report projection, electronic copy of caluclation saved located in: N:\\\\Budget\\\\Policies_Procedures\\\\Performance Measures - PM #1 and 2. A hard copy of documentation is kept in Controller's Office, Room 308 of City Hall. Timing:  Data is from the CAFR which is typicically available in late November or early December of each year for the preceding fiscal year.  Budgetary comparisons are updated when the CAFR is completed and published.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY13-14 final numbers will be reported in January 2014 using the FY12-13 CAFR,

Goal: Provide accurate, timely information to support fiscal planning
Performance Measure: Percentage by which actual revenues vary from mid-year estimates
Description: This is the difference between projected and actual General Fund revenues plus transfers in.  The projections are from the annual Six-Month Budget Status Report.  The actual revenues are as stated in the CAFR.  The target is a maximum percentage; i.e., the objective is to project revenues as close to actual as possible.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Difference between CAFR actuals and the 6-Month Report projection. An electronic copy of the spreadsheet is located in: N:\\\\Budget\\\\Policies_Procedures\\\\Performance Measures - PM #1 and 2.  A hard copy is located in City Hall Room 308. Timing:  Late November/early December each year.  Budgetary comparisons are updated when the CAFR is completed and published.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Final FY13-14 numbers will be reported in January 2014 using the FY12-13 CAFR.

Goal: Provide accurate, timely financial transactions
Performance Measure: Percentage of payroll transactions not requiring correction
Description: Corrections to payroll transactions include cancellations, reissues, and recovery of overpayments (PPSD).  Approximately 31,000 employees receive pay deposits/checks each pay period.  Retroactive payments such as those generated by a labor decision may result in additional paychecks.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Problems/corrections are counted manually and entered in an excel spreadsheet entitled "Payroll Summary Report:  Problems vs. Checks Issued."  Maintained at PPSD office, One South Van Ness, 8th Floor. Timing:  Every pay period.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FYE exceeded expectations
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Based on 840,613 total employees paid divided by 6,847 pdfs processed = .8% so 99.2% payroll transactions not requiring correction.

Goal: Provide accurate, timely financial transactions
Performance Measure: Percentage of Problem Description Forms (PDF) processed within 2 pay periods of receipt
Description: The number of problem description forms received from departments each pay period and the percent of those processed each pay period.
Technical Description: Data collected from payroll statistical reports. Data is collected daily. Data is reflective of period between March 15th through 6/27/2013.

Goal: Reduce the City's debt service costs through bond refinancings
Performance Measure: Number of bond refinancings
Description: Number of refunding bonds issued.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data provided by Office of Public Finance staff Timing:  Upon request to Finance staff
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: No refundings issued. The Mator and BOS approved refunding legislation on August 7, 2013.

Goal: Reduce the City's debt service costs through bond refinancings
Performance Measure: Present value savings from bond refinancings
Description: Net debt service savings on a present value basis.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data provided by Office of Public Finance staff. Timing:  Upon request to Finance staff.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: No refundings issued. The Mayor and BOS approved refunding legislation on August 7, 2013.

Goal: Reduce the City's debt service costs through bond refinancings
Performance Measure: Ratings of the City's General Obligation Bonds - Average of Three Rating Agencies (1 equals top half of investment ratings)
Description: DEsignations assigned by credit rating agencies to give relative indications of credit quality. More specifically, an evaluation indicates the likelihood that a debt issuer will be able to meet scheduled interest and principal repayments. Typically, AAA+ or Aaa1 is  best quality, and B is speculative quality.  Target is to be in the top half of investment grade ratings.  1 = Target Met; 0 = Less than Top Half of Investment Grade.  In Nov 2006, was proposed to move this measure to a Citywide measure, housed in the Controller's.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Ratings are from Fitch, S&P and Moody's.   The Office of Public Finance also monitors the city's G.O. bond ratings and collects the documentation explaining those ratings (Nadia Sesay, 554-5956). Timing:  Rating agencies renew the City's GO bond rating at least as often as the City sells GO bonds.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Met target. Moody's and Fitch's ratings upgraded the City's ratings to Aa1/AA from Aa2/aA-. Standard & Poor's revised the City's outlook to "stable" from "negative".

Goal: Engage with the community regarding Planning-related projects
Performance Measure: Percent of community engagement event participants who rate the event as successful
Description: The percent of community engagement event participants who rate the event as being successful.  Successful can be defined by …
Technical Description: After each community engagement event, an evaluation shall be distributed to all attendees.  A question should be asked on each survey to gather this data for all events held. Data storage location: Project Managers/POE database library, (Number saying event is successful)/(Total number of surveys). Measure owner: Jose Campos, and Joanna Linsangan.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This measure was recently implemented this fiscal year. A general feedback form was developed and distributed to all staff for use at all public meetings.

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive review of projects
Performance Measure: Percent of general plan referrals completed within 45 days
Description: The percent of general plan referrals that are completed within 45 days.
Technical Description: Calculate summary during quarterly volume trending summary to Senior Management, Data storage location: PTS, 1650 Mission St, 4th Floor, (Referrals completed w/n 45 days)/(Total number of referrals completed). Measure owner: Jose Campos, and Alton Chinn.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Due to several challenging cases which required numerous correspondence with project sponsors, not all cases were completed within the 45 day time target.

Goal: Successfully implement planning priority projects
Performance Measure: Central SoMa area plan to be adopted by the Board of Supervisors by June of 2015 (1=Yes, 0=No)
Description: The Central SoMa Plan proposes to build off the neighborhood's success, while addressing many of its challenges, with a comprehensive strategy that will address such issues as land use, building size and heights, transportation, the public realm (including sidewalks and open space), preservation of historic buildings and environmental sustainability.

Goal: Successfully program development impact fee revenue
Performance Measure: Percent of projected development impact fee revenue for the following 2 fiscal years programmed by fiscal year end

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive review of applications
Performance Measure: Percent of Historical Resources Evaluation Reports (HRERs) completed within 60 days
Description: A Historic Resource Evaluation Report (HRER) is the primary technical document used by the Planning Department to evaluate historic resources and potential projects, according to the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA).  The Planning Department offers their response to these document through a Historic Resource Evaluation Response.
Technical Description: PTS system report, Data storage location: PTS, 1650 Mission Str. 4th Floor, (Number of HRERs completed within 60 days)/(Total number of HRERs). Measure owner: J. Joslin, and Alton Chinn.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The number of HRERs, along with other project demands on Preservation staff time and other generally heightened permit activity, rose significantly during the period.  While staff was added, key and highly-production staff was also lost to attrition.  New staff has ramped up well, additional staff are in the process of being added, and additional process improvements have been made; in order to shorten processing times in the next quarter

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive review of applications
Performance Measure: Percentage of all building permits involving new construction and alterations review that are approved or disapproved within 90 days
Description: When a member of the public wants to conduct major physical improvements to existing construction or to develop property, the proposal comes to the Planning Department for review to ensure the project conforms with existing land use requirements as specified in the Planning Code.  Excludes Section 311 and 312 noticing.
Technical Description: PTS system report, DBI's permit tracking system, (Number of permits approved within 90 days)/(Total number of permits approved), Measure Owner: K. Amdur & A. Chinn
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The number of permits rose significantly during the period.  While staff was added, key and highly-production staff was also lost to attrition. New staffing was not yet sufficient during training to keep pace with the heightened permit activity, and positions allocated through the supplemental appropriation process were not yet implemented due to required hiring procedures.

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive review of applications
Performance Measure: Percentage of conditional use applications requiring Commission action approved or disapproved within 180 days
Description: Conditional use may be issued to individuals who propose a use for a property that requires authorization by the Planning Commission in specific situations and under certain conditions.  Conditional Use authorizations may be granted after a public hearing  before the Planning Commission.
Technical Description: PTS system report, Data storage location: PTS, 1650 Mission St, 4th Floor, (Number of Cus approved or disapproved within 180 days)/(Total number of Cus). Measure owner: K. Amdur, and Alton Chinn.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The number and scale of projects subject to Conditional Use rose during the period.  While staff was added, key and highly-production staff was also lost to attrition. The net-stability of positions, coupled with the increase in reviews, resulting in a modest change indicates an efficient staff and Commission effort.  With the addition of numbers of new staff in the coming period, significant gains are anticipated in the near term.

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive review of applications
Performance Measure: Percentage of public initiated Discretionary Review applications approved or disapproved within 120 days
Description: The Planning Commission may use its discretionary powers to review any building permit application, including those which otherwise meet the minimum requirements and standards of the Planning Code.  The measure is the percent of public initiated discretionary review requests completed in 90 days.  This is measured from the filing date to the withdrawn date or the final Commission action date.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Permit Tracking System (PTS) report. Data Storage location: PTS, 1650 Mission St, 4th Floor. (Number of DRs approved or disapproved within 90 days)/(Total number of DRs). Measure owner: Kelley Amdur, and Alton Chinn.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The number and complexity of Discretionary Reviews rose significantly during the period alongside generally heightened permit activity.  While staff was added, key and highly-production staff was also lost to attrition. Additional staffing is imminent, but was not yet sufficient during this quarter to meet established targets.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: The number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  This is a required measure, per Mayor's policy.
Technical Description: Completed performance appraisal forms kept on file in employee personnel files and summarized by the Personnel Analyst. Data Storage location: Employee's personnel files and summary with Personnel. Data Calculation: Count of employee appraisals that are scheduled. Measure owner: Alicia John-Baptiste.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: A number of employees have terminated their employment with the department.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: The number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  This is required, per Mayor's policy.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Completed performance appraisal forms kept on file in employee personnel files and summarized by the Personnel Analyst. Data Storage location: Employee's personnel files and summary with Personnel. Data Calculation: Count of employee appraisals that were completed. Measure owner: Alicia John-Baptiste.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The remaining PPAR’s should be completed over the next 2 weeks due to various employees/supervisors being on vacation.

Goal: Ensure high availability of the department's machines and systems
Performance Measure: Planning core network uptime percent
Description: Up-time for all department IT systems, including Case Intake, Parcel applications, Time Accounting 3, and the department intranet and intranet sites.
Technical Description: Percent of time all systems are up and running. Data Storage location: IT Staff. (Number of hours all systems are up)/(Total number of hours). Measure owner: Brian Smith.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: DCP is between industry standards of: 99.5% uptime = 7.2 minutes/day or 0.84 hours/week or 3.6 hours/month or 1.83 days/year AND 99.9% uptime = 1.44 minutes/day or 0.17 hours/week or 0.72 hours/month or 8.8 hours/year.

Goal: Implement the new Permit & Project Tracking System (PPTS) in a timely manner
Performance Measure: Percent completion of the Permit and Project Tracking System (PPTS) to be fully implemented for staff use by the Summer of 2014
Description: The percent completion of the implementation of the Permit Tracking System (PPTS), as outlined in the agreed-upon contract with the vendor and DBI.
Technical Description: Project managers tracking of the implementation of the project. Data Storage location: Project Plan. (Steps completed to date)/(Total number of steps). Measure owner: Isabelle Vulis.

Goal: Perform timely review of legislation
Performance Measure: Percentage of Ordinances initiated by an elected office that are reviewed by the Commission within 90 days or continued at the request of the elected official
Description: Percentage of Ordinances initiated by an elected office that are reviewed by the Commission within 90 days or continued at the request of the elected official.
Technical Description: Legislative Affairs manager log of activity (http://plannetportal.cityplanning.sfgov.org/administration/LA/Lists/Legislation%20Tracking/Active%20Items%20Not%20Filed%20Adopted%20or%20Abandoned.aspx). Data Storage location: Legislative Affairs summary. Measure owner: AnMarie Rodgers.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: While the Commission, at times, requested additional time for review of ordinances; the Department staff successfully prepared analysis and brought every ordinance to hearing within the 90-day timeframe.

Goal: Respond to information requests in a timely and professional manner

FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 931 HelpDesk tickets were created and 777 items were resolved within 24 hours.

Goal: Perform timely and comprehensive reivew of applications
Performance Measure: Percent of all environmental impact reports (EIRs) completed within 24 months
Description: The Department reviews a variety environmental impact reports at various complexities.  The percent of EIRs that are completed within 24 months.  Include "project" EIRs only, not "plan" EIRs.
