Description: This is the proportion of eligible CalWORKs families that are required to participate and are participating within predefined acceptable welfare to work activities.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure is tracked on an ongoing basis within the CalWIN data tracking system and case files maintained by Employment Specialist. Timing:  Data for this measure generally has a two to three month lag time due to reporting practices/protocols of our community partners.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The CalWORKs Participation rate is calculated on a regular basis based upon cases selected by the State to be reviewed for program compliance. As this is a Statewide process and cases are selected for a particular time period (month), the data for this measure lags behind the SF Performance Measurement reporting periods.  It should also be noted that figures reported in FFY 2013 are unweighted. The San Francisco WPR for Federal Fiscal Year 2013 is 30.8% and was entered on 8/27/2013.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: CalWORKs: Percentage of active CalWORKs cases with earned income
Description: Non-exempt adults in CalWORKs families receiving aid must participate in welfare-to-work activities that will lead to employment.  Exemption from welfare-to-work activities can be granted for a variety of reasons (e.g., clients under 16 or over 59 years old, disabled, or pregnant).  Active cases are those that are currently receiving cash aid via CalWORKs.  This measure is calculated by dividing the number of non-exempt cases earning income by the total number of active non-exempt cases.
Technical Description: Collection Method: All CalWORKs cases are tracked in the CalWIN Data System.  Earned income is one of the pieces of information entered, because it can affect the cash aid payment amount and CalWORKs eligibility.  Whether a case is exempt or non-exempt is also stored within CalWIN.  Therefore, CalWIN contains the total number of non-exempt cases, as well as the number of non-exempt cases with earned income.  The measures here were calculated using the data from these extracts for the corresponding periods of time. Timing:  The CalWIN data system is dynamic, and can be queried for current data.  Historical data is stored in extracts that can also be queried for previous periods.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This group of individuals (CalWorks recipients) tends to be disproportionately impacted due to limited work histories, educational attainment, low skill levels and prevalence of psychosocial barriers to employment.  The 53% performance is an improvement over the previous several years.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Current active CalWORKs caseload
Description: This measure is the number of CalWORKs cases that have received cash assistance (TANF) during the month for which the data is reported.
Technical Description: Data for this measure is obtained from a monthly extract generated by the CalWIN client tracking system.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The CalWORKS caseload is the lowest it has been in more than 10 years.  This is in part due to individuals timing out on aid due to legislated maximum time on aid limits as well as concerted efforts to assist individuals in obtaining employmnet, training and/or education. Other factors that may have impacted the decline in the CalWORKs caseload is the gentrification of historically low income neighborhoods and rising cost of living in San Francisco resulting in the displacement of low-income San Franciscans to other communities.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Current active CAAP caseload
Description: This measure reflects the number of cases that are paid cash assistance during the month for which data has been reported.
Technical Description: Data for this measure is obtained from a monthly extract generated from the CalWIN client tracking system.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Federal reimbursement resulting from CAAP SSI Case Management (HSA's internal SSI advocacy program) clients being awarded SSI
Description: This is the total amount of federal reimbursement during the period resulting from CAAP SSI Case Management (SSI-CM) clients being awarded SSI.  The amounts are based on notifications from SSA.
Technical Description: Collection Method: HSA's fiscal department is alerted by the Social Security Administration via an online system when a CAAP client is awarded SSI and the amount of reimbursement due HSA.  The HSA fiscal unit then records this information into HSA's COSTS database.  On a semi-annual basis, the HSA Planning Unit performs a data match between the COSTS system and the SSI-CM client tracking spreadsheet.  Timing: Data is gathered on an ongoing basis and the data match is performed on a semi-annual basis for performance measures purposes. Data is gathered by HSA's fiscal unit and the SSI-CM program.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This was a new measure starting in FY10-11.  During FY12-13, SF-HSA recouped $1,543,384 in federal reimbursement for CAAP SSI-CM clients awarded SSI.  This exceeds the target of $1.5 million for this measure.  SF-HSA has take steps in recent years to ensure that it collects all of the reimbursement the agency is entitled to.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Number of CAAP SSI Case Mgmt (HSA's internal SSI Advocacy program) clients exiting cash aid due to receipt of SSI benefits
Description: This is the cumulative number of individuals during the period that received HSA's internal SSI Advocacy services and are discontinued from CAAP due to receipt of SSI benefits. The number is determined based upon the receipt of award letters from SSA.
Technical Description: Collection Method: HSA's SSI Case Management Program (SSI-CM) maintains a client tracking spreadsheet and tracks which clients are awarded SSI based on award letters and other communications with SSA.  Timing: Data is gathered on an ongoing basis and awards are tallied on a monthly basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This was a new measure starting in FY10-11.  HSA used to report all CAAP clients awarded SSI, but is now only reporting those assisted by its internal SSI advocacy program.  During FY12-13, 699 SSI-CM clients were awarded SSI.  This is 87% of the target of 800 for this measure.  Delays by the Social Security Administration in processing SSI applications and a decrease in the nation-wide award rate for SSI over the last decade are both factors.  In addition, HSA's internal SSI advocacy program experienced some  staff turnover early in the fiscal year, which impacted productivity while new staff were being trained.  Applications submitted increased during the second half of the fiscal year, but many of these claims are still being adjudicated.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Number of SSI applications submitted for CAAP SSI Case Management (HSA's internal SSI advocacy program) clients
Description: This is the cumulative number of SSI applications submitted during the period for SSI Case Management (SSI-CM) clients. This information is tracked by the SSI-CM program.
Technical Description: Collection Method: HSA's SSI Case Management Program (SSI-CM) maintains a client tracking spreadsheet and tracks which clients they submit SSI applications for.  Timing: Data is gathered on an ongoing basis and applications submitted are tallied on a monthly basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This was a new measure starting in FY10-11.  During FY12-13, SF-HSA's internal SSI advocacy program submitted 997 SSI applications for CAAP clients.  This exceeds the target of 920 for this measure.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: The number of CAAP recipients who are homeless
Description: New measure Feb 2006:   This is an average of the number of homeless CAAP clients receiving cash aid each month.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure comes from the CalWIN database system.  Data is gathered initially at the time of intake and updated whenever the client has a change in housing status. Timing:  The CalWIN data system is dynamic, and can be queried for current data.  Historical data is stored in extracts that can also be queried for previous periods.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The actual average monthly homeless CAAP caseload for FY12-13 was 368 (well below the target of 420).  The homeless caseload was fairly stable over this period.  There is no funding for additional Care Not Cash-exclusive hotels, but there is turnover within the existing portfolio, so homeless caseload entries were offset by exits into housing.

Goal: Maximize personal and agency resources
Performance Measure: Personnel: Number of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  9/11/09  All future data reporting will be based soley on those PAR's required for the correspodning time period.
Technical Description: Collection Method: In March 2006 HSA developed a Performance Evaluation System. We created an Access Database using our Excel based Position Control data.  We implemented the system beginning in April 2006.  In May 2006 we made enhancements to the Access Database and were able to link directly to our Position Control spreadsheet which has all of the department's positions listed, which is about 1, 710 filled. Timing:  Current
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance on this measure is significantly below target due to changes in our business practices for scheduling and completing performance appraisals.  The Agency is transitioning from tying performance appraisals to an employees start date to a fixed date for all.

Goal: Maximize personal and agency resources
Performance Measure: Personnel: Number of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: In March 2006 HSA developed a Performance Evaluation System. We created an Access Database using our Excel based Position Control data.  We implemented the system beginning in April 2006.  In May 2006 we made enhancements to the Access Database and were able to link directly to our Position Control spreadsheet which has all of the department's positions listed, which is about 1, 710 filled. Timing:  Current
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance on this measure is significantly below target due to changes in our business practices for scheduling and completing performance appraisals.  The Agency is transitioning from tying performance appraisals to an employees start date to a fixed date for all.

Goal: Maximize personal and agency resources
Performance Measure: Personnel: Percent of required bilingual positions filled
Description: This measure attempts to reflect the Human Services Agency commitment to providing access to services for individuals with limited English Proficiency.  Furthermore, the Department is legislatively mandated to provide access.  Division 21 states, "The number of public contact positions in each major occupational group shall be determined for each program and/or location whose non-English language cases equal or exceed five percent of the total cases for each program or location."  The Equal Access to Services Ordinance states, "...that City Departments would be required to provide services in non-English languages when (a) 10,000 City residents, (b) 5 percent or more of the clients served by the Department, or (c) 5 percent of the residents of the Supervisorial District in which the Departments' offices are located are limited to English-speaking and share a common language."
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure is tracked in several places.  The personnel or staffing data is tracked by our Personnel Department in an Excel spreadsheet (personnel Control Report).  Caseload data is tracked in severl client tracking systems (CalWIN, CMIP, AACTS, and Panoramic). Timing:  Data for this measure is compiled annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The HSA maintains a committment to providing language and culturally appropriate services.  To this end, the Agency identifies a number of direct service positions as being bilingual positions.  These positions require staff to have language skills other than English.  As staff vacancies come up, these positions are prioritized to be filled.  The Agency also has contracted services to provide translation services (oral and written) as needed.  The 91.7% performance meets and exceeds are stated target for this measure.

Goal: Assist individuals and families to achieve their greatest potential within the context of family, community and/or society
Performance Measure: Percent of children who were adopted from child welfare supervised foster care during the most recent 12 month study period that had been in care for less than 24 months (FCS)
Description: CSSR utilizes a "rolling year" methodology.  Each quarter they will present data on the previous year up to that quarter.  This differs from the Controller's Office framework, but provides a more rigorous methodology, minimizing the effects of seasonal changes and the anomalies that result from small data samples.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Effective January 1, 2004, SF-HSA is required by the state and federal government to report on these measures.  As part of these requirements, the Center for Social Services Research (CSSR), which is affiliated with the University of California at Berkeley, will be cleaning and analyzing data from the statewide child welfare database and reporting on outcome measures quarterly.   The data is derived from the statewide child welfare database, Child Welfare Services/Case Management System, and the Center for Social Services Research uses special algorithms to eliminate data irregularities. The data is then posted on the CSSR website: http://cssr.berkeley.edu/CWSCMSreports
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Data for this measure comes from UC Berkeley and the most recent data available is reflected (Q1, 2013).  Performance on this measure is below target and lags behind the States performance.

Goal: Assist individuals and families to achieve their greatest potential within the context of family, community and/or society
Performance Measure: Percent of children who were reunified from child welfare supervised foster care during the most recent 12 month study period and had been in care less than 12 months
Description: As mentioned in the previous measure, CSSR utilizes a "rolling year" methodology.  Each quarter they will present data on the previous year up to that quarter.  This differs from the Controller's Office framework, but provides a more rigorous methodology, minimizing the effects of seasonal changes and the anomalies that result from small data samples.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Effective January 1, 2004, SF-HSA is required by the state and federal government to report on these measures.  As part of these requirements, the Center for Social Services Research (CSSR), which is affiliated with the University of California at Berkeley, will be cleaning and analyzing data from the statewide child welfare database and reporting on outcome measures quarterly.  The data is derived from the statewide child welfare database, Child Welfare Services/Case Management System, and the Center for Social Services Research uses special algorithms to eliminate data irregularities. The data is then posted on the CSSR website: http://cssr.berkeley.edu/CWSCMSreports
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: San Francisco's performance on this measure is better than 68%.  THough this is lower than the established target (75%), it is worth noting that performance exceeds the State's average of 64% and represents an improvement since the last reporting.

Goal: Protect and shield against abuse and neglect
Performance Measure: Number of first time entries into foster care
Description: Unduplicated count of child clients <18 entering a child welfare supervised placement episode of at least eight days duration for the first time during the reporting period.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Effective January 1, 2004, SF-HSA is required by the state/federal government to report on select performance measures.  The Center for Social Services Research (CSSR), affiliated with the University of California at Berkeley, cleans and analyzes data from the statewide child welfare database and reporting on outcome measures quarterly.  CSSR utilizes a "rolling year" methodology.  Each quarter they present data on the previous year up to that quarter.  This differs from the Controller's Office framework, but provides a more rigorous methodology, minimizing the effects of seasonal changes and the anomalies that result from small data samples.  The data is derived from the statewide childwelfare database, Child Welfare Services/Case Management System, and the Center for Social Services Research uses special algorithms to eliminate data irregularities. The data is then posted on the CSSR website: http://cssr.berkeley.edu.ucb_childwelfare/entryrates.aspx
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The 301 first time entries into foster care is for the period of January through December 2012 for youth betweenthe agesd of 0-17 years of age.  Data for this measure comes from UC Berkeley and represents the more recent information available.

Goal: Protect and shield against abuse and neglect
Performance Measure: Of all children who were victims of a substantiated maltreatment allegation during the first 6 months of the year, what percent were not victims of another substantiated allegation within the next 6-month period?
Description: HSA: Effective January 1, 2004, SF-HSA was required by state and federal government to report on this measure.  As part of these requirements, the Center for Social Services Research (CSSR), which is affiliated with the University of California at Berkeley, is cleaning and analyzing data from the statewide child welfare database, Child Welfare Services/Case Management System, and CSSR uses special algorithms to eliminate data irregularities.    CSSR�s time frame, however, differs from that of the Controller�s Office, as their latest reporting period lags behind the Controller�s reporting period.  However, SF-HSA is dependent on CSSR for accurate data on this measure, and this is the latest, reliable information available. This measure reflects the percent of children who were victims of child abuse/neglect and did not have a subsequent substantiated report of abuse/neglect within specific time periods.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Effective January 1, 2004, SF-HSA was required by state and federal government to report on this measure.  As part of these requirements, the Center for Social Services Research (CSSR), which is affiliated with the University of California at Berkeley, is cleaning and analyzing data from the statewide child welfare database, Child Welfare Services/Case Management System, and CSSR uses special algorithms to eliminate data irregularities.    CSSR�s time frame, however, differs from that of the Controller�s Office, as their latest reporting period lags behind the Controller�s reporting period.  However, SF-HSA is dependent on CSSR for accurate data on this measure, and this is the latest, reliable information available.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Data for this measure comes from UC Berkeley and the most recent data available (Q1, 2013) is reflected.  Performance on this measure meets or exceeds target.  It is also worth noting that HSA's performance exceeds the State's (93%) overall performance in this area. .

Goal: Protect and shield against abuse and neglect
Performance Measure: Total number of children in foster care
Description: This measure provides a count of the number of children with an open case in foster care at the end of each month that data is being reported.
Technical Description: The data source for this measure is the Child Welfare Services Case Management System (CWS/CMS). CWS/CMS is a longitudinal statewide database that can be queried for current and historical data.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: AB12 legislation now gives every foster youth the opportunity to stay in care until age 20.  Future targets will need to be adjusted to reflect the implementation of AB12.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Current active food stamp caseload
Description: This is the total number of cases receiving non-assistance food stamps.  Non-assistance food stamps cases do not include those cases which also receive other forms of public assistance (e.g. CalWORKs).
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure is tracked within the CalWIN system.  A case file is opened at the point of intake and maintained while the case is active. Timing:  The CalWIN data system is dynamic, and can be queried for current data.  Historical data is stored in extracts that can also be queried for previous periods.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Food Stamps: Error rate
Description: The food stamps error rate is a quality control measure that looks at the percentage of cases with an error in the grant amount determined.  This rate could be compared to other counties and an overall national food stamp error rate.  In general, the federal goal is to have a rate at or below 4.5%.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The California Department of Social Service routinely samples approximately 35-40 food stamp cases for review/audit pulled from the county data system - CalWIN.  As these case files are noted, CDSS refers back these cases to HSA's Quality Control, who in turn does the audit and reports back their finding to the State.  The results are tabulated by the State on a county to county basis, and it in turn calculates the State error rate.  This State information is forwarded to the Federal government and the data is combined to form the national error rate.   Food Stamp Error Rate reported to the State.  Monthly reports reflect the rolling error rate and compares it against the prior Fiscal Year.   As this information gets reported to the State, transmitted thrugh its proprietary on-line Q5I software program, the Federal government is also reviewing subsamples of the completed reviews on a monthly basis.  The Federal findings will validate the State findings, which will be
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: We originally reported a rate of 3.9% through April 2013.  The latter part of the fiscal year's performance was not available until October 18th. As of 2/28/2014 the error rate reflects the rate through June 2013. The program continues to perform below the target of 4.5%  This is a positive outcome.

Goal: Assist individuals and families to achieve their greatest potential within the context of family, community and/or society
Performance Measure: Number of families receiving a rental subsidy
Description: This is the number of rental subsidies provided to families in order to secure/maintain housing and/or avoid eviction.
Technical Description: A monthly census report detailing all disbursement and families receiving subisides are submitted monthly on an Excel spreadsheet to the Housing Homeless Division.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 202 families were receiving a rental subsidy funded by the general fund at the end of FY12-13.  This is almost exactly at the target level of 200 for this measure.  The Home for the Holidays funding increased the number of GF slots for FY12-13; however, this funding will sunset by around December 2013.  Also, programs continue to report challenges in clients' ability to secure a unit to attach the subsidy to, due to increasing rents, very low incomes, the lack of affordable units for larger families, and the sometimes poor credit and eviction histories of clients at a time when landlords can be more selective about who they rent to.  Therefore, SF-HSA reduced the target for this measure to 185 starting  in FY13-14.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Average nightly homeless shelter bed use
Description: The numbers reported here represent the average number of beds (single adult) used during the month.
Technical Description: Data for this measure is reported via the CHANGES system, but the actual number of beds available is based upon negotiated contracted obligations.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Number of CAAP clients leaving homelessness due to obtaining housing through Care Not Cash
Description: This is the number of homeless CAAP clients who become housed via Care Not Cash within the year.  Care Not Cash housing is in the form of units within the Housing First Program operated by our Housing and Homeless Division.                                                                         CON Jan 2006:  Name revised per HSA's request, data same.  CON Nov 2006:  Name revised per HSA's request, data same.
Technical Description: Collection Method: An internal HSA unit called the Housing Access Team (HAT) serves as the gateway for homeless CAAP clients being referred and placed into Housing First units as part of the Care not Cash initiative.  The HAT has its own database where they track housing referrals and move-ins of homeless CAAP clients.  Monthly reports from this database are produced and archived for reporting to various audiences. Timing:  Monthly and ongoing
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 280 homeless CAAP clients were placed into housing via Care Not Cash during FY12-13.  This is 102% of the current target of 275.  There is no funding for additional Care Not Cash housing, so housing placements can only be made when there is turnover within the existing portfolio of permanent supportive housing.  For this reason, the old target of 360 was reduced to 275 as of FY12-13.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Number of households that secured and/or maintained housing due to a one-time grant
Description: One time grants assist families and single adults who are at risk of becoming homeless to stabilize and maintain their housing and avoid accessing the emergency shelter system.  One time grants are direct financial assistance to pay for rent arrearages.  The measure is calculated by counting the number of one time grants (move-in and back rent) awarded during the specified period.
Technical Description: Collection Method: One time grants are funded through HSA, but directly administered through third-party, non-profit agencies.  These non-profits are under contract with HSA to submit quarterly reports detailing the number of back-rent grants provided during the period. HSA stores two copies of past quarterly reports from the third-party non-profit agencies, one within the Contracts Unit, and one within the Division of Housing and Homelessness. Timing:  Quarterly and annually
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The annual target for this measure is currently 2,500, and the actual figure for FY12-13 was 2,434 (97% of annual target).  There was a substantial increase in the use of these funds due to the expiration of the HPRP federal stimulus grants in June 2012.  Additionally, the Board of Supervisors approved a $1 million add back for this program for FY12-13 to ease the transition away from HPRP.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Percent of formerly homeless clients (single adults ) still in supportive housing or other appropriate placements after one year
Description: Once supportive services for homeless clients have successfully placed the clients in permanent housing, the goal then becomes to maintain a permanent housing arrangement (i.e., avoid a recurrence of homelessness).  This measure looks at the percentage of homeless clients that have retained a housing placement after one year.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The supportive services to assist homeless clients to obtain and maintain permanent housing are funded through HSA, but directly administered through third-party, non-profit agencies.  These non-profits are under contract with HSA to submit quarterly reports detailing the percent of formerly homeless clients during the period that maintained permanent housing for one year. HSA stores two copies of past quarterly reports from the third-party non-profit agencies, one within the Contracts Unit, and one within the Division of Housing and Homelessness. Timing:  Quarterly and annually
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This measure is computed annually at the close of each fiscal year.  The stability measure for single adults across all HSA housing programs (Master Lease, LOSP and Shelter Plus Care) for FY12-13 is 94.0%. This actual percentage is above the target of 90%.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Percentage of all available homeless shelter beds used
Description: This is the average percentage of shelter beds (single adult) available that have been reserved and used on a nightly basis.
Technical Description: Data for this measure is derived from the CHANGES shelter bed reservation system.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Percentage of families exiting shelter who have stayed for 30 days or more and will successfully exit into permanent housing, transitional housing, or a residential treatment program
Description: Supportive services provided at shelters are intended to assist in stabilizing the lives of clients so they are better able to secure permanent housing.  Cases managers are assigned to clients to help them identify and overcome barriers to obtaining permanent housing.  The three outcomes listed above are the main avenues through which case managers guide clients to leave the shelters and enter more permanent housing arrangements.  This measure is calculated by counting the number clients with case managers that achieve one of the three outcomes and then divided the total who exit the program.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The shelter supportive services and case managers are funded through HSA, but directly administered through third-party, non-profit agencies.  These non-profits are under contract with HSA to submit quarterly reports detailing the number of case managed clients  that achieve one of the three described outcomes during the period. HSA stores two copies of past quarterly reports from the third-party non-profit agencies, one within the Contracts Unit, and one within the Division of Housing and Homelessness. Timing:  Quarterly and annually
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 72 out of 118 (61%) of families have exited to permanent or transitional housing, a treatment program or reunited with family during FY12-13.  This is 1% higher than the 60% target for this measure.  The competitiveness of the Bay Area rental market has made it increasingly difficult to exit families from shelter into housing successfully, but SF-HSA was still able to meet the target mainly due to temporary rental subsidies and SFHA public housing units.  More opportunities for successful shelter exits should occur during FY13-14, with the opening of a new family permanent supportive housing development in the Bayview.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Medi-cal: Percentage of Medi-Cal applications processed within 45 days
Description: These measures were calculated using applications process within 45 days during the quarter and divide it by total applications during the quarter.
Technical Description: Collection Method: All MediCal cases, including application dates, are tracked in the CalWIN Data System.  This measure is calculated by comparing the application date to the date eligibilty date or status change date. Timing:  The CalWIN data system is dynamic, and can be queried for current data.  Historical data is stored in extracts that can also be queried for previous periods.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Medi-Cal program continues to meet or exceed established program standards for this measure.

Goal: Promote the health and well being of San Franciscans
Performance Measure: Medi-Cal: Percentage of Medi-Cal cases redetermined annually
Description: The Medi-Cal program is required to redetermine the eligibility of cases on an annual basis.  This measure is a reflection of the proportion of cases that meet the guidelines for correctly redetemining Medi-Cal cases.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for this measure is maintained within the CalWIN data tracking system and is captured at the time of intake. Timing:  Current data for this measure is available by querying the CalWIN data tracking system.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Medi-Cal program continues to meet or exceed established program standards for this measure.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Job placement rate at or above 125% of the San Francisco minimum wage for aided individuals
Description: NEW.  CON Feb 2006:  Recommended new measure - this will provide additional information on the welfare client component of individuals receiving job placement services.  We request HSA begin reporting on this measure for FY 2006-07.  HSA 2006 - HSA plays a key role in developing and managing employment, training and workforce development services for the residents of San Francisco.  The target clients for these programs are CalWORKs welfare to work clients and PAES clients, although many of the services are open to a broader population.  This measure looks at the job placement rate of individuals placed in positions at or above the 125% of the local minimum wage from employment programs specifically administered by HSA's Employment Services Program.  The rate is calculated by dividing the number of aided participants that obtained jobs at or above 125% of the local minimum wage by the number of aided participants served by the programs.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The data for this measure are tracked and stored internally within HSA's Employment Services Program.  The data come from a variety of sources, including tracking spreadsheets, billing logs and case records. Timing:  Data for this measure is compiled on a monthly basis and is available for the prior month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance on this measure is below target; however, it is a marked improvement over last year. This performance is chiefly due to increased efforts to place individuals through the Jobs Now program which has a slightly less than 125% San Francisco minimum wage rate.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Job placement rate for aided individuals
Description: HSA 2006 - This measure is calculated by taking the number of aided individuals (CalWORKs or PAES recipients) that have been placed in a job divided by the number of those individuals referred to the WDD from cash assistance programs.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data for all placements are tracked by the Workforce Development Division in a log and specialized database and then reported to the Planning Unit. Timing:  Data for this measure is compiled on a monthly basis and is available for the prior month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The WDD program has met or exceeded the target for this measure.  This is in large part due to the success of the JobsNOw program.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Number of individuals that received workforce development services
Description: An unduplicaed count of those individuals that received workforce develoment services either by HSA staff or a contracted service provider.
Technical Description: An unduplicated client count of individuals recorded as either receiving services directly from HSA and/or a contract service provider. Data for this measure is obtained from the PIC/WIA client date base and then matched against those clients recorded in the OASYS client data base.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The WDD program has met or exceeded the target for this measure.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Number of individuals that were placed in employment (subsidized or unsubsidized)
Description: Count of individuals that were placed in employment within the reporting period.
Technical Description: Count of individuals that were placed in either subsidized or unsubsidized employment within a specified time period.  Data for this measure is obtained from HSA's WDD program.  WDD uses multiple databases to track placements depending upon where an individuals enters the system (ie. OASYS, CalWIN, and Contracts). Data is gathered throughout a person's connection with the system, but reported when requested.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The WDD program has met or exceeded the target for this measure.

Goal: Facilitate economic self-sufficiency
Performance Measure: Rate of completion of participants enrolled in job readiness programs
Description: The measure is calculated by dividing the number of individuals completing a program component (JRA/JRT)by the number of individuals (CalWORKs and PAES participants) enrolled in the component.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Staff within the Workforce Development Division keep logs for various program components.  The logs track each individuals receiving services. Logs are maintained within each program and then summarized on a monthly basis.  The summary reports are forwarded to the Program Section Manager. Timing:  Logs are maintained within each program and then summarized on a monthly basis.  The summary reports are forwarded to the Program Section Manager.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance on this measure is below target but within an acceptable tolerance range.

Goal: Respond quickly to incoming calls
Performance Measure: Average time (in minutes) from received to dispatch of Code 3 medical calls
Description: The goal for received to dispatch for code 3 medical calls is 2 minutes.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is retrieved from CARS (CAD Activity Reporting System).  Data is based on information collected from 01/01/08-12/31/08. (CARS: Computer Area reporting system; NFRIS:  National Fire Reporting Information system; CAD:  Computer Aided Dispatch).  Each database provides a stream of information that provides the time intervals for emergency medical dispatching.  The time interval goval are set by the local EMSA.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The time is based on the average response from the time the call is received to when it is dispatched, which was 1 min. 52 secs.

Goal: Respond quickly to incoming calls
Performance Measure: Calls handled per dispatcher FTE/hour
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The average number of 911 phone calls handled by a call taker per hour was 13.

Goal: Respond quickly to incoming calls
Performance Measure: Percentage of emergency calls answered within ten seconds
Description: Percentage of emergency calls answered within 10 seconds.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Monthly data is retrieved from Symposium Contact Center Manager. All data in a year combined to determine the rate. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The actual answering of all emergency calls were answered 86% of the time within 10 seconds.

Goal: Respond quickly to incoming calls
Performance Measure: Percentage of non-emergency calls answered within 1 minute
Description: Volume of non-emergency calls (allied agencies & police non-emergency) answered in the communication center.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Monthly data is retrieved from Symposium Contact Center Manager, which was implemented in December 2006. Data is based on information collected from 01/01/08 thru 12/31/08.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The actual answereing of all non-emergency calls were answered 62% of the time within 1 minute.

Goal: Respond quickly to incoming calls
Performance Measure: Response to code 3 medical calls(in minutes)  in 90th percentile
Description: The goal for received to dispatch for code 3 medical calls is 2 minutes.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is retrieved from CARS (CAD Activity Reporting System) Data is based on information collected from 01/01/08-12/31/08. (CARS: Computer Area Reporting System; CAD:  Computer Aided Dispatch).   Reports are generated weekley, monthly, and annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The time is based on the 90th percentile response from the time the call is received to when it is dispatched, which was 3 mins. 13 secs.

Goal: Staff emergency communication center with fully-trained personnel
Performance Measure: Ensure staff that require continuing professional training receive training.
Description: Ensure staff that require continuing professional training receive training - maintain mandated training certification for all staff.  all staff must have 36 hours continuing professional training biennially to maintain their dispatch certification.    8/22/14 update: the Definition will be changed to "Ensure staff that require the POST (Peace Officer Standards and Training) mandated 24 hours of Continuing Professional Traning (CPT) receive training in the 2 year cycle; maintain mandated training certification for all staff.  All staff must have 24 hours of CPT biennially to remain compliant with POST requirements."
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEC's Training Unit. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All staff are up to date with continuing education requirements.

Goal: Staff emergency communication center with fully-trained personnel
Performance Measure: Number of 8238s successfully completing the fire medical dispatch training program
Description: Ensure successful training completion - all 8238 staff are cross trained for fire/medical dispatch while maintaining a core group in this capacity.(8238-Public Safety Communications Dispatcher).
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEC's Training Unit. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: No Fire Dispatch Academy  was scheduled during this fiscal cycle due to budget constraints.  Next Fire Academy August 5-6, 2013.

Goal: Staff emergency communication center with fully-trained personnel
Performance Measure: Number of 8239s and 8240s successfully completing the fire medical dispatch training program
Description: Ensure successful training completion - all 8239 and 8240 staff are cross trained for fire/medical dispatch. (8239-Senior Police Communications Dispatcher; 8240-Public Safety Communications Coordinator).
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEC's Training Unit. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: No 8239 and 8240 fire medical dispatch training conducted.

Goal: Staff emergency communication center with fully-trained personnel
Performance Measure: Number of new dispatchers successfully completing the training program
Description: Ensure trainees successfully complete training - Emergency Call Taking and Radio Dispatching training.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  DEC's Training Unit. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Due to budget constraints, no training provided in this period.

Goal: Staff emergency communication center with fully-trained personnel
Performance Measure: Percentage of fully qualified staff maintaining continuing education requirements.
Description: To maintain mandatory certification as Emergency Medical and Emergency Fire Dispatchers, operations personnel must complete 36 hours of Continuing Dispatch Education (CDE's) training in various medical and fire service categories biannually.  Additionally, the Department of Justice's Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training (P.O.S.T.) Regulations require operations personnel to complete 24 hours of Continuing Professional Training (CPT's).  DEM projects to have all staff complete half of their requirements each year to keep up with requirements.   8/22/14 Update: Definition will be changed to "To maintain mandatory certification as Emergency Medical and Emergency Fire Dispatchers, operations personnel must complete 36 hours of Continuing Dispatch Education (CDE's) training in various medical and fire service categories biannually.  DEM projects to have all staff complete half of their requirements each year to keep up with requirements."
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEM's Training Unit. Timing:  Monthly
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All staff are up to date with continuing education requirements.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Number of training courses provided by DES staff
Description: DEM provides several training sessions each year to supplement the vendor training.  These sessions are typically focused on CCSF response-specific procedures.
Technical Description: DES maintains XL document that tracks training title, date, attendee and overall satisfaction.  The number of training courses is reported bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Some planned trainings (specifically for Golden Guardian 2013) were hosted and facilitated by other City departments (PUC, HSA, CON).

Performance Measure: Number of EMS hospital diversion reports
Description: Number of hospital diversion reports provided to EMS system participants (e.g. EMS providers, hospitals, clinics, health care providers, etc)

Performance Measure: Number of new emergency plans developed or existing emergency plans revised.   (Replace old measure - Number of DES plans completed or revised)
Description: Completion of new plans or revision of existing plans where DES is the primary author.
Technical Description: DES tracks plan initiation and revision in an XL spreadsheet.  This number will be reported bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: SF Disaster Corps Deployment Guide and DEM COOP completed. The staffing transition continued to cause some delays.  Additional plans delayed due to prioritization of the Hazard Mitigation Plan Revision which took extensive staff resources.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Number of outstanding DEM tasks in the master improvement plan completed.
Description: Number of outstanding DEM tasks in the Master Improvement Plan that have been resolved in the last 6 months.
Technical Description: Data is collected from Master Improvement Plan and reported out bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: DES continues to identify MIP tasks through training and exercise.  Outstanding items are being incorporated into planned activations to validate completion then closed out.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Number of participants in DEM hosted trainings.
Description: Tracks number of individuals from city departments and partners (NGO, volunteer organizations, business community, and private sector) that participated in DEM hosted trainings.
Technical Description: Total number of participants in DEM hosted trainings during measurement period. Will be tracked as part of training tracking XL spreadsheet and reported bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Anticipated number of participants in DES hosted training.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Number of participants in training courses provided by DES staff.
Description: Tracks number of individuals from city departments and partners (NGO, volunteer organizations, business community, and private sector) that participated in DEM hosted trainings.
Technical Description: Total number of participants in DEM hosted trainings during measurement period. Will be tracked as part of training tracking XL spreadsheet and reported bi-annually.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Number of training courses hosted by DES
Description: DEM hosts several vendor led training sessions each year to supplement the training program.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Overall satisfaction with trainings hosted by DES (5-best, 1-worst)
Description: Participant satisfaction with vendor trainings will be measured (or normalized) on a 1-5 scale where 1 is poor and 5 is excellent.  This information will be used to select vendors who can provide engaging training to CCSF employees.
Technical Description: Student evaluations will be collected and enterd into a tracking database.  DES will develop a standard for integrating disparate evaluation templates to create one common measure to quantify satisfaction.  Metric will be reported bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Trainings were led by subject matter experts, providing more indepth training and an increased benefit to participants. Will continue to strive to increase participant satisfaction.

Goal: Coordinate interagency planning
Performance Measure: Overall satisfaction with trainings provided by DES staff
Description: Participant satisfaction with DES provided trainings will be measured on a 1-5 scale where 1 is poor and 5 is excellent.
Technical Description: Student evaluations will be collected and entered into a tracking database.  Metric will be reported bi-annually.

Improvement items identified during the exercise will be tracked in the Master Improvement Plan.  The number of exercises will be reported bi-annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: In lieu of doing 6 smaller exercises, we did a large functional exericse (Golden Guardian 2013) and two smaller build-up exercises.

Goal: Exercise emergency response capabilities
Performance Measure: Number of participants in DES led exercises
Description: Tracks number of participating departments and City partners (NGO, volunteer organizations, business community, and private sector) in each discussion based exercise to evaluate depth of preparedness of departments.

FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: DES decreased the number of expected exercises in order to allow other CCSF departments to lead/host build-up exercises for the State’s annual Golden Guardian 2013 Functional Exercise. In lieu of doing 6 smaller exercises, DES did a large functional exercise (Golden Guardian 2013) and two smaller build-up exercises.

Goal: Exercise emergency response capabilities
Performance Measure: Overall satisfaction with DES led exercises
Description: Participant satisfaction with DES led exercises  will be measured on a 1-5 scale where 1 is poor and 5 is excellent.

FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Collateral Material distribution reduced by directing public and private partners to on-line resources.

Goal: Promote community preparedness for emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of preparedness presentations made
Description: DES provides emergency preparedness training to community groups, from neighborhood associations to corporate volunteer councils.
Technical Description: DES maintains records of the organization and number of attendees to which presentations are given and reprots the number of presentations twice annually.

Description: DES provides emergency preparedness messaging to residents of San Francisco via Social Media channels
Technical Description: DES will use various software mechanisms to calculate our online and social media reach with preparedness messaging.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The reduction of collateral and continued education of online and social media properties has resulted in an increase in online traffic.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEM's HR Division. Timing:  Annually by calendar year for Operations personnel and fiscal year for all other employees.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Administration, DES and UASI divisions were scheduled for 72 performance appraisals and are completed on a FY basis.. The DEM Operations staff PPAR's are completed on a calendar year basis. Appraisal completion for FY13 is 100%.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.
Technical Description: Collection Method: DEM's HR Division.  Timing: Annually by calendar year for Operations personnel and fiscal year for all other employees.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Operations appraisals are completed on a calendar year basis.  Administration, DES and UASI appraisals are completed on a Fiscal Year basis.  The department appraisal completion is 100%.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Evaluations tracked by the managing deputy director for OEWD. Timing: OEWD conducts performance evaluations on an annual year basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: OEWD has switched to a calendar year period to conduct performance appraisals. This number reflects the number of performance appraisals that have been schedule for the CY 2013 period.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Evaluations tracked by the managing deputy director for OEWD. Timing: OEWD conducts performance evaluations on an annual year basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: OEWD has switched to a calendar year period to conduct performance appraisals. This number reflects the number of performance appraisals that have been completed for the CY 2012 period.
