Goal: To foster international trade
Performance Measure: Number of international trade delegations hosted or co-hosted
Description: Number of meetings and forums between international officials and/or international business associations and city officials designed to increase trade.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected in a spreadsheet by the Director of International Trade and Commerce Timing:  Data collection will be ongoing and will be reported on an annual basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This represented 1,839 persons from 49 countries. 2012-13 saw a revival of the global economy which was strongly reflected in the number of international business, governmental and community delegations that visited our city.  Even the slowing economy of China did not slow the number of Chinese delegations.We also saw significant visits from New Zealand due to America’s Cup preparations and numerous EU trade visits, including for the first time, two major Polish visits and two Swedish trade leadership events and visits.

Goal: To grow and support quality workforce opportunities for all San Francisco residents
Performance Measure: Average wage increase of individuals receiving workforce services
Description: The average difference between wage at program intake to wage at placement from the program for all individuals over 18 placed in unsubsidized and either part-time or full-time employment.
Technical Description: Collection Method: There is currently no common or centralized workforce data system that cuts across all City departments, nor do we have common definitions of services, and outcomes. MOEWD plans to develop a comprehensive, real time workforce development data collection system, which will allow us to look at common performance measures across city agencies and contractors. OEWD has began to engage city agencies with workforce portfolios to define outcome measures, data collection techniques, process of developing contracts. For FY2008, data reflects only OEWD, MOCD, HSA and DCYF. Timing: To be determined
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Wage data is inconclusive. Therefore, OEWD is not able to report results under this metric.OEWD is proposing to eliminate this metric.

Goal: To grow and support quality workforce opportunities for all San Francisco residents
Performance Measure: Placement rate of individuals 18 and older who complete a program in jobs that are either full-time or part-time
Description: Placement rate of individuals 18 and older who complete a program in jobs that are either full-time or part-time.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  Includes the number of individuals who completed training during the Fiscal Year (denominator), and of those individuals, the number who were placed in jobs by the end of the Fiscal Year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During FY12-13, 484 individuals completed training in CityBuild, HealthCare Academy, Hospitality Training, and TechSF. Of those individuals, 337 were placed in jobs as of June 30, 2103.

Goal: To improve the business climate in San Francisco in order to attract and retain businesses, with specific focus on targeted industries and including small business
Performance Measure: Number of businesses receiving one-on-one technical assistance
Description: Number of businesses receiving substantive assistance will be tracked by business name, size, type, location, description of problem or issue, assistance provided and outcome.
Technical Description: Collection Method: OEWD and SBC will track each organization and business assisted in a database. As of February 1, 2007 OEWD and SBC is collecting data manually and is not yet able to track all relevant data. We are currently tracking number of calls and referrals. Timing:  Data collection will be ongoing.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: OEWD has continued to provide direct 1 one on one 1 assistance with San Francisco businesses across key sectors in the City, as well as small businesses.  This includes assistance provided at the Office of Small Business, outreach meetings on site with individual businesses, responding to business issues and concerns and attracting new businesses to San Francsico.

Goal: To improve the business climate in San Francisco in order to attract and retain businesses, with specific focus on targeted industries and including small business
Performance Measure: Number of businesses taking advantage of incentive programs including local payroll tax exemptions and state enterprise zone benefits
Description: Number of businesses that apply for and receive the biotechnology payroll tax exclusion, the clean technology payroll tax exclusion and the local enterprise zone payroll tax exclusion, as well as the  number of businesses that received state enterprise zone income tax credits vouchers.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected from a Treasurer and Tax Collector database and OEWD data. Businesses are counted by unique address. Timing:  Data will be collected on an annual basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Outreach and an online application system for the EZ program drove additional participation in the EZ.  Additionally, because of the large increase in payroll tax collection this year the Surplus Business Revenue Credit was triggered resulting in virtually every business that pays payroll tax receiving a credit.

Goal: To improve the business climate in San Francisco in order to attract and retain businesses, with specific focus on targeted industries and including small business
Performance Measure: Number of businesses that benefited from Office of Economic and Workforce Development (OEWD) and Small Business Commission (SBC) programs, as identified through business surveys
Description: Number of businesses that responded to survey questions indicating benefit from OEWD and/or OSB programs.  Survey question (e.g., "did you find your experience with SBC to be helpful?") rated on a 1 to 5 scale, with one being "not helpful at all" and 5 being "extremely helpful," and measure includes all survey responses scored either 4 or 5.  Surveys will be sent to all businesses and organizations that have substantive contact with OSB. Substantive contact is defined as having received grants, attended trainings or workshops, received one-on-one technical assistance or consultations with OSB.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected by OEWD through surveys available via the web and email. Timing:  Data will be updated and available on an ongoing basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The surveys were not conducted to contract issues and is extended into 13/14

Goal: To improve the business climate in San Francisco in order to attract and retain businesses, with specific focus on targeted industries and including small business
Performance Measure: Number of state and local enterprise zone vouchers issued
Description: Number of vouchers issued for buisnesses that hired qualified workers with multiple barriers to employment.  Those eligible for or enrolled in Workforce Investment Act (WIA) job training, CalWORKs, or Work Opportunity Tax Credits; economically disadvantaged individuals age 14 years or older; Native Americans; ex-offenders; disabled; those eligible for or receiving Food Stamps, Supplemental Security Income, state or local County Adult Assistance Program (CAAP) (formerly General Assistance or GA); service-connected disabled veterans, veterans of the Vietnam era or a Veteran separated from military service within the last 48 months; dislocated workers; and residents of recognized target employment areas.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected from an OEWD database. Timing:  Data will be collected on an ongoing basis
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Creation of an online system and threats to the program at the state level allowed for an increased volume of applications to the program.

Goal: To strengthen the economic vitality of neighborhoods and commerical corridors
Performance Measure: Annual Community Benefit District (CBD) revenue
Description: Total assessment revenue generated in CBDs throughout the City.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data collected from CBD plans (projections), in annual report from the CBD management Board and the Treasure and Tax Collector database. Timing:  Data will be collected on an annual basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Redemption of prior year property taxes  and associated fees contributed to increase.   Also, TID Q4 numbers alone show nearly a $2m increase from FY 11-12 Q4 data.

Goal: To strengthen the economic vitality of neighborhoods and commerical corridors
Performance Measure: Number of commercial vacancies in targeted commercial corridors
Description: Number of vacant retail spaces in 12 of the commercial commercial districts that are included in the Invest in Neighborhoods initiative: Leland Avenue in Visitacion Valley, San Bruno in Portola, 3rd Avenue in Bayview, Ocean Avenue in OMI, Mission Street in Excelsior, Lower Polk Street, Lower 24th Street in the Mission, Japantown, North Beach, Chinatown, Larkin Street, and Noe Valley. Our definition of vacant retail spaces had heretofore been primarily limited to vacant spaces available for lease. We have expanded the definition to include vacant spaces under construction and spaces occupied by non-confirming uses (e.g., resident-occupied). This has resulted in a slight increase in our figures that is not representative of actual vacancy trends.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected from commercial corridor managers that work for nonprofit organizations that will provide reports. Timing:  Data will be collected on an annual basis
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: As we have rolled out the Invest in Neighborhoods initiative we have expanded the geographic areas where we track vacancies. We are now tracking vacancies in 25 commercial districts (7 of which we had been tracking already). So while the actual vacancy rate has increased from 7.0% since the last reporting period, this number is representative of a different geographic area. Our figures now include a number of commercial districts with high vacancy rates, including Central Market (24%), Broad Street (22%), Larkin Street (13%), and Lombard Street (11%). These additions have increased the average vacancy rate. Several neighborhoods experienced a decrease in vacancy rate during the reporting period, including Leland Avenue (from 23% to 16%) and Taraval (from 12% to 7%).

Goal: To support and catalyze major City development projects, including public-private partnerships and military base conversions
Performance Measure: Number of public-private development projects proceeding on time and on budget
Description: Review of major public-private real estate development projects to determine if they are proceeding on time and on budget based upon preset targets. OEWD will also present this number as a percentage of all projects.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Information will be collected in a spreadsheet by the Director of the Base Reuse and Development. Timing:  Data will be updated on an quarterly basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: All projects are on time and budget.  Project timelines extend over multiple fiscal years.  The majority of projects began this year with pre-established budgets

Goal: Foster, promote and retain small businesses in San Francisco
Performance Measure: Number of ordinances, resolutions, motions and policies initiated by or reviewed by the Small Business Commission
Description: Pieces of legislation and policy items addressed by the Office of Small Business.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected by OSB staff. Timing: Data will be updated and available on an ongoing basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The amount of legislation did not increase, but the amount of policy matters the Commission reviewed did. The Commission started meeting 2 times a month starting in June of 2012.

Goal: Foster, promote and retain small businesses in San Francisco
Performance Measure: Number of outreach events
Description: Increase visibility and public relations exposure with small business customers
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected by OSB staff. Timing: Data will be updated and available on an ongoing basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Of the 41 Outreach Events: 27 covered ADA information, 23 covered Enterprise Zone, 21 Jobs Now 5 covered Mobile Foods. It was anticipated that around 11 SF Chamber Merchant Summits would occur, but only 2 were scheduled during the year.

Goal: Foster, promote and retain small businesses in San Francisco
Performance Measure: Number of small businesses assisted
Description: Number of small businesses assisted via phone/walk-in/appointments/sfbizinfo website and phone referrals, merchant walk contacts.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data will be collected by OSB staff. Timing: Data will be updated and available on an ongoing basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: May had an unusual high call volume due to the new business registration procedures.

Goal: Encourage the use of public transportation to improve air quality
Performance Measure: Number of CCSF employees using commuter benefits
Description: This metric replaces previous metric "Number of City employees participating in commuter check program."  New method for counting pariticpants is more accurate than previous method, which counted cumulative participation, rather than actual number of employees served within a calendar year.
Technical Description: Number of individaul employees that have taken advantage of commuter benefit program in calenday year, reported annually as FY year end measure. NOTE: IT MAY BE MORE REPRESENTATIVE OF PROGRAM PERFORMANCE TO CALCULATE AS PERCENTAGE OF CCSF EMPLOYEES USING COMMUTER BENEFITS, IF EMPLOYEE DATA CAN BE MADE EASILY AVAILABLE.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This number represents the number of employees participating in the Pre-Tax Commuter Benefits Program in June, 2013.  This year saw a steady increase of enrollments.

Goal: Increase the use of biofuels and/or other alternative fuels by the city fleet
Performance Measure: Percentage of CCSF fleet fuel usage that is biodiesel
Description: Pure biodiesel (B100) is blended with petroleum diesel to produce various grades of biodiesel (B5, B20, etc).  A variety of factors influences the blend of biodiesel used by department fleets.  Current City policy is to achieve B20 fleetwide.
Technical Description: Collect data on usage of transportation fuel  from reports currently provided under the Master Fueling Contract.  From this data, determine the amount of pure biodiesel (B100) used and the amount of petroleum diesel used by the fleet.  The ratio of B100 to petroleum diesel gives the average biodiesel blend for the fleet.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This number represents significant progress in the adoption of B20 by the City Fleet in the past 12 months.  We are currently using approximately 976,006 gallons of Neet Biodiesel (B100) annually.

Goal: Encourage the use of renewable energy and energy efficiency
Performance Measure: Megawatt reduction: SF Energy Watch program activities
Description: The SF Energy Watch program provides energy efficiency assessments in commercial and multifamily buildings together with financial incentives to help business and property owners invest in energy efficient retrofits.  The reductions in peak electric demand (Megawatts) will continue to have an impact throughout the life of the energy-saving products.  This measure was created in May 2013 and tracks the Actual data annually; it does NOT reflect the program's cumulative impact. One megawatt of electric demand powers 10,000 San Francisco homes.
Technical Description: Megawatts of peak electricty demand reduced through SF Energy Watch  energy efficiency programs.    Since 2010, data is tracked in SFE's Sugar CRM database used for Energy Watch projects. The projects are filtered by incentive payment dates for the desired period.  All  summary reports are updated monthly.   The program has set targets, which have been exceeded each year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: For both metrics, the total actual data came very close to  projected, and well ahead of target/contractual goals.

Goal: Encourage the use of renewable energy and energy efficiency
Performance Measure: Metric Tons of CO2 greenhouse gas reduced through SF Energy Watch program activities
Description: The SF Energy Watch program provides energy efficiency assessments in commercial and multifamily buildings together with financial incentives to help business and property owners invest in energy efficient retrofits (electricity and natural gas). The reductions in energy use will continue to save electricity or gas (and corresponding CO2) throughout the life of the energy-saving products.
Technical Description: Metric tons of CO2 emissions resulting from activities of the SF Energy Watch energy efficiency program electricity and natural gas).  Since 2010, data is tracked in SFE's Sugar CRM database used for Energy Watch projects. The projects are filtered by incentive payment dates for the desired period.  All  summary reports are updated monthly.  Conversions are: 0.6545 lbs of CO2 saved per kWh;  11.73 pounds of CO2 per therm saved;   2009 pounds of CO2 per metric ton of CO2.  To remove the equivalent of one car from the road would require 6.25  metric tons of CO2 reduction. The program has set targets, which have been exceeded each year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: For both metrics, the total actual data came very close to  projected, and well ahead of target/contractual goals.

Goal: Encourage the use of renewable energy and energy efficiency
Performance Measure: Solar Installations: MW of new capacity.
Description: The SFE renewable energy program works to support the City's greenhouse gas reduction goals, along with other health and environmental goals, and local economic development through renewable energy market development. To this end, SFE provides education and outreach to SF residents and businesses on renewable energy technologies, incentives, and financing options. SFE meaures progress in this area through increases in solar photovoltaic (PV) installations, in terms of number of installed capacity (in megawatts (MW) based on CEC alternating current accounting methodology (CEC AC)) in San Francisco.
Technical Description: Solar PV installed capacity in MW (CEC AC), as reported by PG&E interconnection services and SFPUC.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: PG&E has not provided April-June 2013 data yet. Data through March 31: 3.0 MW new capacity

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Departmental payroll staff generates quarterly report on performance evaluations completed and due in the next quarter; Program Managers get quarterly update and reminder. Timing:  Maintained on a quarterly basis by program managers and reported on annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Department is aiming to have all performance reviews up to date by the end of October 2013.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Departmental payroll staff generates quarterly report on performance evaluations completed and due in the next quarter; Program Managers get quarterly update and reminder. Timing:  Maintained on a quarterly basis by payroll staff and reported on annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Department is aiming to have all performance reviews up to date by the end of October 2013.

Goal: Ensure energy efficiency and environmental-friendly designed buildings
Performance Measure: Quantity of LEED and GPR certified private sector green building stock in San Francisco (square footage).
Description: Commercial building and residences that are designed and/or operated to meet rigorous green building standards can be certified under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, GreenPoint Rated, or ENERGY STAR programs. This evaluation and certification by a recognized third party provides credible verification that a building has met high standards for energy efficiency and sustainability. Note that in contrast to most other metrics in this list, SF Environment staff influence but do not entirely control this metric. For example, for there to be newly constructed certified green buildings, it is of course necessary for new buildings need to be constructed. The decision to build green must occur at the outset of design, and years may elapse before the new building is delivered to market and certified.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Green Building Staff maintain records of certified private sector properties (tracking compliance with San Francisco Building Code Chapter 13C). Timing: Annally report in July for the previous fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Reasonably close to target. SF policies do not directly control LEED certification volume in San Francisco. Volume will sometimes be greater or lesser than projections.

Goal: Ensure energy efficiency and environmental-friendly designed buildings
Performance Measure: Quantity of LEED certified municipal green building stock in San Francisco (square footage).
Description: Commercial building and residences that are designed and/or operated to meet rigorous green building standards can be certified under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, GreenPoint Rated, or ENERGY STAR programs. This evaluation and certification by a recognized third party provides credible verification that a building has met high standards for energy efficiency and sustainability. Note that in contrast to most other metrics in this list, SF Environment staff influence but do not entirely control this metric. For example, for there to be newly constructed certified green buildings, it is of course necessary for new buildings need to be constructed. The decision to build green must occur at the outset of design, and years may elapse before the new building is delivered to market and certified.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Green Building Staff maintain records of certified municipal properties (tracking compliance with Environment Code Chapter 7) Timing: Annally report in July for the previous fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Final LEED certification was expected for 4 additional municipal projects during FY 2013 totaling 309,425 square feet.   In the first 2 weeks of FY2014, 2 of these projects achieved certification totaling an additional 279,638 square feet.  This amount will be added during the next reporting period.  Future targets remain unchanged.

Goal: Increase energy efficiency in existing buildings.
Performance Measure: Quantity of commercial building stock in San Francisco which has submitted the required Annual Energy Benchmark Summary to Department of Environment, as required by Environment Code Chapter 20. (square footage)
Description: Environment Code Chapter 20 requires commercial buildings of 10,000 gross sq ft and larger to (1) track and annually publicly report total energy use, and (2) obtain a professional energy efficiency audit identifying cost-effective opportunities for improvement at least once every 5 years.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Green Building Staff track and enforce compliance with San Francisco Environment Code Chapter 20. Timing: Annally report in July for the previous calendar year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Target previously had typo that resulted in thousands reported instead of millions. Typo was corrected. Compliance is 80% for buildings >50k gross square feet, and outreach is increasing to buildings <50k gross square feet.

Goal: Increase energy efficiency in existing buildings.
Performance Measure: Quantity of floor space in San Francisco which earned the ENERGY STAR certification for energy efficient operations (square footage).
Description: Commercial building and residences that are designed and/or operated to meet rigorous green building standards can be certified under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, GreenPoint Rated, or ENERGY STAR programs. This evaluation and certification by a recognized third party provides credible verification that a building has met high standards for energy efficiency and sustainability. Note that in contrast to most other metrics in this list, SF Environment staff influence but do not entirely control this metric. For example, for there to be newly constructed certified green buildings, it is of course necessary for new buildings need to be constructed. The decision to build green must occur at the outset of design, and years may elapse before the new building is delivered to market and certified.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Green Building Staff maintain records of ENERGY STAR properties (tracking compliance with Environment Code Chapter 20). Timing: Annally report in July for the previous fiscal year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: On target.

Goal: Improve environmental quality and  reduce toxics
Performance Measure: Number of consultations to San Francisco businesses provided via phone, onsite consultations and training workshops.
Description: Includes total number of one hour phone consults, site visits, and public presentations conducted by Green Business Program with SF businesses.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Schedule of phone consults, site visits, and public presentations maintained in Coordinator and Associate Microsoft Outlook calendar. Timing:  Annual.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: "As part of the GB process, we require phone consults and site visits to business going through the process and are scheduled for their assistance.  Public presentations are varied based on requests from the public or available meetings to attend. Goal has been exceeded by 27% Target is to achieve 5% increase annually.

Goal: Improve environmental quality and  reduce toxics
Performance Measure: Number of Green Businesses certified through Green Business program
Description: Current number of Green Businesses certified through Green Business program, a collaborative program of Environment, DPH, and PUC.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Green business certification files will be maintained both at the Department of the Environment and the Department of Public Health. Timing:  Annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: "On average, 50 businesses are recognized each year, so try to target an average of 60 recognized businesses. with staffing changes, we had limited resources to meet the target

Goal: Improve environmental quality and  reduce toxics
Performance Measure: Number of San Francisco homes serviced for household hazardous waste  pickup
Description: Number of Home Haz Waste Pickup Appointments completed (weight adjusted visits).
Technical Description: "Equivalent Load" Data from RSF quarterly (see comment).
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: increase of 6.1%; goal was 10% increase

Goal: Improve environmental quality and  reduce toxics
Performance Measure: Pounds of household hazardous waste properly managed and recycled or disposed of.
Description: Total Pounds of household hazardous waste and [non-electronic] universal wastes managed through all City-sponsored programs and Recology SF Loadcheck Program.
Technical Description: "Data for HHW and non-electronic UW processed & shipped off-site or given away for reuse from ALL HHW Programs Non-oil data from RSF - oil data from CK (quarterly reports)"
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: decrease of 14.4%; goal was 5% increase – difference may be due to timing of off-site shipments and/or success in educating SF residents to use up/buy less toxic products.

Goal: Decrease landfill waste through recycling and other waste diversion
Performance Measure: Total tons disposed of in all landfills
Description: Tonnage of San Francisco generated materials sent to all landfills. Information available annualy at end of fiscal year.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data filed with the California Integrated Waste Management Board; documents maintained by Recycling staff at Department. Timing:  Annual.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Information available annualy at end of fiscal year

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy states that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  A performance appraisal is scheduled when the supervisor has provided a performance plan to the employee near the beginning of the fiscal year.  The supervisor has signed off on the plan and the employee may or may not have signed off on the plan.
Technical Description: Collection Method: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion. Timing: Performance evaluations are done on an annual fiscal year basis -- the Commissioners conduct the performance evaluation of the Executive Director; and supervisors conduct the evaluations of their subordinates at the end of the fiscal year.  The performance evaluations are conducted in accordance with the guidelines of DHR's performance plan and appraisal report.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the year, two employees left the Commission. The Commission has not yet been able to fill those positions.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The Ethics Commission expects to have 17 FTEs in 2012-2013; each FTE will have a scheduled performance appraisal.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  A performance appraisal is completed when both the supervisor and employee have met and discussed the performance appraisal.  The supervisor has signed off on the appraisal, and the employee may or may not have signed off on the appraisal.
Technical Description: Collection Method: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion. Timing: Performance evaluations are done on an annual fiscal year basis -- the Commissioners conduct the performance evaluation of the Executive Director; and supervisors conduct the evaluations of their subordinates at the end of the fiscal year.  The performance evaluations are conducted in accordance with the guidelines of DHR's performance plan and appraisal report.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the year, two employees left the Commission. The Commission has not yet been able to fill those positions.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The Ethics Commission expects to have 17 FTEs in 2012-2013; each FTE performance appraisal is expected to be completed by the end of the FY.

Goal: Investigate complaints of alleged violations of state and local law relating to campaign finance, governmental ethics, and conflicts of interest that are within the jurisdiction of the Commission
Performance Measure: Percentage of complaints resolved
Description: Measure Definition: The Ethics Commission has the authority to investigate complaints that allege violations of certain state and local laws that relate to campaign finance, conflicts of interests, lobbyists, campaign consultants, and governmental ethics. The investigation of complaints requires careful review of information and documents, as well as conducting interviews and legal research. Investigations lead to the full Commission making a determination whether the alleged violations or not occurred. As some witnesses and/or respondents are not cooperative with staff's investigation, it is extremely difficult to predict the time necessary to resolve a complaint.
Technical Description: Data Collection Method and Frequency: All complaints filed with the Ethics Commission are reviewed to ascertain whether the complaint is within the Commission's jurisdiction. Once staff determines that the complaints are within the Commission's jurisdiction and, after preliminary review, has reason to believe the violations of law occurred, staff inputs the complaint into a database that includes the following information: data complaint filed; complainant(s)' name (if available); respondent(s)' name; referral date to the City Attorney and/or District Attorney; and case status. Once a case is resolved, staff enters the date of resolution and the action taken by the Commission. For purposes for tracking performance measures, staff reviews data on a quarterly basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Out of 49 pending complaints, 28 complaints were  resolved during the 2012-2013 fiscal year.  Seven hearings were held in accordance with the newly adopted regulations for handling violations of the Sunshine Ordinance.

Goal: Promote and ensure compliance with state and local campaign reporting and disclosure laws
Performance Measure: Number of campaign committees and publicly financed candidate committees audited
Description: One of the Charter mandates of the Commission is to conduct audits of campaign committees.  Under the Campaign Finance Reform Ordinance, the Ethics Commission must audit all candidates who receive public financing.  In addition, the Commission audits committees (general purpose, ballot measure, and candidate committees) based on other criteria, such as random and targeted selections.  An audit is considered complete when the audit report is issued.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The general practice of the Ethics Commission has been to conduct a random selection of committees for audit.  After an election, the Commission audits all candidates who received public financing.  More recently, the Commission has begun to conduct targeted audits of committees whose campaign reports show activities that appear not to conform to the law. Timing: Ethics Commission staff conducts audits throughout the year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 54% of the projected audits were completed. This represents 15 audits out of 28 target audits. However, another 8 audits were near completion in FY 12 – 13 but are not counted because the audit reports were not released in FY 12 - 13. Also, the Ethics Commission lost one auditor at the end of FY 11 - 12, and the new auditor did not work the full fiscal year 12 - 13.  In addition to performing audits, auditors are responsible for other time consuming projects: the Statement of Economic Interest filings, the budget development and tracking for the department, the Campaign Consultant program and the Lobbyist program administration.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The target for this measure has significally increased by 45%. The target for FY 12 was 19 and the new target for FY 13 is 28 audits. The increase on the target is due to an addition of one more auditor to the audit unit.

Goal: Promote and ensure compliance with state and local campaign reporting and disclosure laws
Performance Measure: Percentage of expected campaign finance statements (Form 460) filed on time
Description: Under state law, the Commission serves as the filing officer for local candidates, ballot measure committees and general purpose committees. Commission staff processes both electronic and paper filings, including amendments, and logs them into a campaign database.  For the purpose of this performance measure, a statement is considered to be filed on time if a candidate/committee filed its statement on or before the statement deadline.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Commission keeps an electronic campaign log.  All paper statements submitted by campaign filers are kept in the Commission office. Timing: Active campaign committees generally file two semi-annual statements and, if they are involved in an election, two pre-election statements. There are other filing deadlines as well, such as quarterly deadlines that apply only to certain types of committees or committees that meet certain thresholds.   Timing: The data shown reflects campaign statements that are received by the filing deadlines that fall within the performance measure periods.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Ethics Staff continues to conduct outreach to candidates and committees, reminding them to file on-time.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The Ethics Commission projects it will stay on target.

Goal: Promote compliance with state and local filing requirements
Performance Measure: Percentage of identified campaign consultants who file quarterly reports on a timely basis
Description: According to the Campaign Consultant Ordinance, registered campaign consultants must file quarterly reports with the Ethics Commission.  Although not required to do so, Commission staff sends reminders to all registered campaign consultants before the quarterly report deadline.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Ethics Commission staff maintains a database of the quarterly reports filed by registered campaign consultants.  The quarterly reports are also available online on the Commission’s website.  The Commission staff maintains a dashboard of campaign consultant activity on the Commission’s website. Timing: The campaign consultant quarterly reports are due on March 15, June 15, September 15, and December 15 of each year.  The campaign consultant activity dashboard is updated as reports are filed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: A comprehensive audit of all FY 2012-2013 filings was undertaken. It was determined that 11 of 43 consultants had late or missing quarterly reports.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Staff anticipates that the rate will increase for the remainder of the fiscal year as there are no first-time consultants registered with the Ethics Commission at this time.

Goal: Promote compliance with state and local filing requirements
Performance Measure: Percentage of identified lobbyists filing reports on a timely basis
Description: Registered lobbyists are required to file reports with the Ethics Commission.  The Commission staff sends e-mail reminders to the lobbyists two weeks before the deadlines.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Registered lobbyists file their reports with the Ethics Commission.   Timing: Prior to January 1, 2010, lobbyist reports were due on a quarterly basis.  Since January 1, 2010, lobbyists reports have been due on a monthly basis on the 15th of each month.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: The lower projected rate reflects late filings that are the result of new lobbyists learning the filing system and establishing new filing habits.

Goal: Promote compliance with state and local filing requirements
Performance Measure: Percentage of Statements of Economic Interests due on April 1 that are filed
Description: Department heads and members of City boards and commissions are required to file annual Statements of Economic Interests (SEIs) on April 1 of each year.  This measure compares the number of individuals who have been identified by the Ethics Commission as being required to file annual statements with the number of filings that are received by the Commission.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Ethics Commission maintains a database of the SEIs filed by department heads, members of boards, and commissions.  The Commission maintains the SEIs.  The Commission posts the names of filers and non-filers on its website. The Commission calculates the percentage of compliance by dividing the number of forms 700 filed by the total of individuals required to file. Timing: Annual SEIs are due on April 1 of each year.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: City cost per visitor (All museums)

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of all school children and youth participating in education programs
Description: All San Francisco Bay Area schoolchildren and youth participating in Education Department programs, including tours, curriculum-supported visits, hands-on art making, and professional development/leadership building for teens.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data captured for all school groups who make a reservation and participate in one of our many programs. Timing: School programs are offered throughout the academic year. Compilation of education program participation completed every six months.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of de Young visitors
Description: Number of visitors to the de Young museum.  Museum was closed until Fall 2005.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Door count. Fine Arts Museums. Timing:  Daily, weekly, monthly, annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: While the final seven weeks of the Jean Paul Gaultier exhibition (which were part of FY13), the William S. Paley Collection exhibition, and Girl with a Pearl Earring exhibition all exceeded projections for visitors, the Rudolph Nureyev exhibition was not as successful as expected and accounts for the 41,000 less visitors.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of exhibitions
Description: Number of exhibitions opened during each FY.
Technical Description: Collection Method: FAM Exhibition Schedule. Timing:  Monthly as the exhibition schedule is revised.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This number reflects all exhibitions that opened as of July 1, 2012 at the de Young and the Legion of Honor, including special traveling exhibitions and those from the permanent collection.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of Legion of Honor visitors
Description: Number of visitors to the Legion of Honor.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Door count. Fine Arts Museums. Timing:  Daily, weekly, monthly, annually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The success of two special exhibitions, Man Ray/Lee Miller: Partners in Surrealism and Impressionists on the Water (only on display for one month during FY12-13), has enabled the Legion of Honor to exceed its goal.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of paid memberships
Description: Number of paid memberships.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Dues paid membership count. Paid membership section of Corporation of FAM. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Membership is very exhibition driven. We expected a higher response to the exhibitions during the first half of FY13 than was the case.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of participants in public programs
Description: Participants in Education Department public programs, including Friday Nights at the de Young, Artist Studio, concerts, lectures, films, symposia, and others.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Participant counts at each program tracked via clicker counts at the museum entrance. Timing: Public programs are offered throughout the year. Compilation of program attendance completed every six months.

Goal: Provide quality art and educational experiences to attract a large and diverse audience
Performance Measure: Number of San Francisco school children and youth participating in education programs
Description: San Francisco schoolchildren and youth participating in Education Department programs, including tours, curriculum-supported visits, hands-on art-making and professional development/leadership building for teens.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data captured for all school groups who make a reservation and participate in one of our programs. Timing: School programs are offered throughout the academic year. Compilation of education program participation completed every six months.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Source:  FAM Personnel Office Timing:  Annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 63 of 69 security guards received an appraisal; the remaining 6 were on leave. All 6 cashiers received an appraisal. 6 of 7 engineers received an appraisal; one position is open. 2 of 4 registrars received an appraisal; two started too late in the year to receive an appraisal. 0 of 1 tech received an appraisal; this individual started too late in the year to receive an appraisal. The Director of Museums started in June, and thus did not receive an appraisal. 2 of 2 curators and 1 of 1 Director of Human Resources received an appraisal. In FY13, the Museums are permanently down 7 positions.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Source:  FAM Personnel Office Timing:  Annual
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 63 of 69 security guards received an appraisal; the remaining 6 were on leave. All 6 cashiers received an appraisal. 6 of 7 engineers received an appraisal; one position is open. 2 of 4 registrars received an appraisal; two started too late in the year to receive an appraisal. 0 of 1 tech received an appraisal; this individual started too late in the year to receive an appraisal. The Director of Museums started in June, and thus did not receive an appraisal. 2 of 2 curators and 1 of 1 Director of Human Resources received an appraisal. In total, 80 of 91 employees received an appraisal. In FY13, the Museums are permanently down 7 positions.

Goal: Provide for collection growth through gifts, bequests and purchases
Performance Measure: Number of acquisitions through gifts, bequests and purchases
Description: Number of objects added to the permanent collection.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Acquisition Committee and Board of Trustees minutes.  Registration records. Timing:  Compiled every six months.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Includes 539 gifts, 45 purchases and 21 funded purchases.

Goal: Educate the public in handling emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of citizens trained in emergency techniques and procedures
Description: Defined by NFPA 1710.  Number of citizens trained in Neighborhood Emergency Response Team (NERT) and other programs such as CPR, Ham Radio censing, I.C.S., and Citywide drills.  This program contributes to victim prevention, community preparedness for disasters, and training the public in becoming an adjunct to City emergency services. This program clearly enhances services provided by the San Francisco Fire Department.
Technical Description: Collection Method: NERT volunteers sign a waiver of liability protecting the SFFD during training activities.  Documents are filed and stored at SFFD Headquarters, Room 118. Timing:  Data collected by NERT staff as classes occur in a database. NERT program produces information for mid-year and end-of-year reports.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Number of Citizens trained in emergency techniques and procedures
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Number of Citizens trained in emergency techniques and procedures

Goal: Educate the public in handling emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of public education presentations
Description: Public events, meetings, workshops and seminars where the Fire Department provided training, recommendations, advice, and printed materials about fire/earthquake safety and/or information about other Fire Department Community Based Programs.  This does not include Fire Station Open House days.  While NERT information is provided, these are not NERT classes.
Technical Description: Collection Method: A letter of request to the Chief of Department from the interested party is required for trainings and presentations.  After the request has been completed, a written report is made on Public Education Event Report Form 3350.  These letters and report forms are maintained at Fire Department Headquarters, 698 2nd Street, Room 313, Office of Community Affairs. Timing:  Information is collected as presentations occur and reported at mid-year and at year-end.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: number of public education presentations
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: number of public education presentations

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review shold be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  Timing: Performance evaluations are done on an annual fiscal year basis.  The performance evaluations are conducted in accordance with the guidelines of DHR's performance plan and appraisal report.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Completed Yearly
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Completed Yearly

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted amd completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The SFFD enters performance appraisals into its scheduling system for Firefighters (H2), Firefighter Paramedic (H3), Incident Support Specialist (H10), Lieutenant (H20) and Captain (H30) ranks. Performance appraisals for Rescue Captains (H33), Battalion Chief (H40), Assistant Chiefs (H50), Assistant Deputy Chief (H51), Fire Prevention and Investigation classes and all civilian classifications are completed using the DHR forms and stored in the personnel file at the Fire Department Headquarters. Timing:  Data for performance appraisals are available when completed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Completed Yearly
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Completed Yearly

Goal: Train fire and rescue personnel to effectively respond to emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of Battalion Based/In-Service training hours
Description: Total hours of training per member including Battalion Training and Paramedic Training Program.  Note: PTP Training was not included in original measure. The Battalion Based Training Program, introduced in July 2000, has proved to be an effective mechanism for delivery of formalized training.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Hours calculated via monthly reports. Timing:  Data available monthly from reports and combined to produce mid-year and annual figures.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of battalion based / in service training hours
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of battalion based / in service training hours

Goal: Train fire and rescue personnel to effectively respond to emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of new recruits trained
Description: Number of new recruits trained including H2 Recruits and H3 Laterals.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  Total number of new hires. Timing:  Data available monthly from reports and combined to produce mid-year and annual figures.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of new recruits trained.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of new recruits trained.

Goal: Train fire and rescue personnel to effectively respond to emergencies
Performance Measure: Number of probationary firefighter training hours
Description: Total Probationary training hours inclusive of H2 Recruits and H3 Laterals.  H1 to H3 cross training not included.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Hours calculated via monthly reports. Timing:  Data available monthly from reports and combined to produce mid-year and annual figures.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of probationary firefighter training hours
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of probationary firefighter training hours

Goal: Determine the causes of fire in an effective and efficient manner
Performance Measure: Number of fires investigated
Description: The Bureau of Fire Investigation (BFI) responds to service calls, investigates the origin and cause of (suspicious) fires, and processes documentation and litigation of incidents.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data and statistics are compiled from the National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) data collection system.  Other statistics are provided by the District Attorney's Office and the San Francisco Police Department. Timing:  Data is collected daily and reported on monthly and biannually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Total number of fires investigated.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Total number of fires investigated.

Goal: Determine the causes of fire in an effective and efficient manner
Performance Measure: Total arson arrests
Description: Total adults arrested for arson.  Measure does not include juvenile fire setters, who are sentenced differently and often admitted into community service/rehabilitation programs.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Accounting of Fire Investigation reporting factors, from Bureau of Fire Investigation, SFPD and District Attorney records.  Verified by the Captain of the Bureau of Fire Inspection. Timing:  Data is collected daily and reported on monthly and biannually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of arson arrests.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of arson arrests.

Goal: Determine the causes of fire in an effective and efficient manner
Performance Measure: Total number of arson incidents
Description: NEW in Budget FY07.    Total number of arson incidents.  Arson investigators respond to every greater alarm (2nd Alarm Fire or Higher) and all suspicious fires. After an examination of the evidence on the scene and appropriate additional investigative work, the investigator will determine whether it is arson.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Recorded by Arson Investigators located at Evans street. Timing:  Data is collected daily and reported on monthly and biannually.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of arson incidents.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of arson incidents.

Goal: Prevent fire through inspection and permit services
Performance Measure: Number of inspections made
Description: Number of inspections completed.  Inspections include referrals, complaints, violation re-inspections, permit approval, school inspections, and high-rise building annual inspections.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Inspections tracked in Fire Prevention Database located at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Inspections are processed daily. Database reports are available as needed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of inspections made.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of inspections made.

Goal: Prevent fire through inspection and permit services
Performance Measure: Number of inspections resulting in violation
Description: The BFP Inspection Team during the course of its various inspections may issue a Notice of Violation when a violation of the fire code and other related codes, standards, or ordinances has been disclosed.  A reinspection of the violation, which is charged against the property owner or violator, will be conducted until such time that the violation has been abated.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Tracked in database at Fire HQ Timing:  Information is processed daily. Database reports are available as needed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of inspections resulting in violation.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of inspections resulting in violation.

Goal: Prevent fire through inspection and permit services
Performance Measure: Number of new fire permits issued
Description: The BFP's Permit Section is responsible for inspecting special occupancies and reviewing plans for events prior to issuance of a fire permit .  In cooperation with the Dept. of Public Health, the Section also inspects installation and removal of underground or aboveground fuel tanks.  The Section also conducts annual inspection of renewal permits collected for the SFFD by the License Bureau of the Tax Collector's Office.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Permit Section's secretary monitors and maintains records of all new permits issued by the Section.  The 4 inspectors assigned to the Section submits inspection reports that are entered into the inspection database. Timing:  Permits are processed daily. Database reports are available as needed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of new fire permits issued.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of new fire permits issued.

Goal: Prevent fire through inspection and permit services
Performance Measure: Number of plans reviewed and approved
Description: The BFP's Plan Check Section is assigned to check plans for alterations and new construction of buildings for compliance with the law and ordinances related to egress, fire protection, and fire spread control.  The Section also provides technical information to the public, conducts water flow tests, and attends pre-application meetings for input.  The processing of construction plans produces inspection for the BFP Inspection Team, which in return generates revenue.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The Plan Check Section has an office at Dept. of Building Inspection on Mission Street and shares a database with DBI on plans.  The DBI collects fees for the SFFD.  The SFFD also collects additional fees (when needed) for the required inspection of the job. Timing:  Permits are processed daily. Database reports are available as needed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of plans reviewed and approved.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of plans reviewed and approved.

Goal: Prevent fire through inspection and permit services
Performance Measure: Number of violation re-inspections made
Description: The BFP Inspection Team during the course of its various inspections may issue a Notice of Violation when a violation of the fire code and other related codes, standards, or ordinances has been disclosed.  A reinspection of the violation, which is charged against the property owner or violator, will be conducted until such time that the violation has been abated.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The BFP Inspection Team submits inspection reports of the Notice of Violation issued and the follow-up inspections that were entered into a database.  The Program's secretary monitors and processes bills/notices to the violators or property owners. Timing:  Inspection reports are processed daily. Database reports are available as needed.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of violations re-inspected.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of violations re-inspected.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Number of Code 2 (Non Emergency) Incidents
Description: All  incidents responded to with the flow of traffic, without lights and sirens.  These calls include medical, fire and service calls.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 (Computer Aided Dispatch) CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Number of Code 3 (Emergency) Incidents
Description: All emergency incidents that are responded to with lights and sirens.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD).  Raw Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD) data is transferred from the ECD and stored at SFFD Headquarters.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of code 3 incidents.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of code 3 incidents.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Number of fires extinguished
Description: Number of fires encountered by units when arriving on scene.  Measures all fires.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Department's  National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) Record Management System.  Raw  data is stored at the ECD.  NFIRS data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: total number of fires extinguished.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: total number of fires extinguished.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Roll time of first ALS-capable company to Code 3  incidents requiring possible medical care, in seconds - 90th Percentile
Description: SFFD EMS first ALS response time is measured from the time the PSAP (Public Safety Answering Point) notifies the first response unit until the first arriving Advanced Life Support engine or medic unit arrives on the scene.  Turnout time (to get gear and get on rig) is  included in these measurements.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for first ALS - capable company (Roll Time) responding code 3 requiring possible medical care.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: 90th percentile value for first ALS - capable company (Roll Time) responding code 3 requiring possible medical care.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Roll time of first defibrillation-capable company to Code 3  incidents requiring possible medical care, in seconds - 90th percentile
Description: SFFD EMS first unit response time is measured from the time the PSAP (Public Safety Answering Point) notifies the first response unit until the first arriving engine, truck or rescue company arrives on the scene.  Turnout time (to get gear and get on rig) is included in these measurements.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for first - defibrillation capable company (Roll Time) requiring possible medical care.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: 90th percentile value for first - defibrillation capable company (Roll Time) requiring possible medical care.

Performance Measure: Roll time of first transport-capable company to Code 3  incidents requiring possible medical care, in seconds - 90th Percentile
Description: SFFD EMS first transport response time is measured from the time the PSAP (Public Safety Answering Point) notifies the first response unit until the first arriving medic unit or ambulance arrives on the scene.  Turnout time (to get gear and get on rig) is  included in these measurements.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for fist transport - capable company responding code 3 requiring possible medical care.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: 90th percentile value for fist transport - capable company responding code 3 requiring possible medical care.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Roll time of first unit to respond to Code 3 incidents, in seconds - 90th percentile
Description: All calls dispatched to fire suppression staff, code 3 (emergency), measured from dispatch time the PSAP (Public Safety Answering Point) notifies the first response unit until the first arriving unit arrives on the scene.  Roll Time includes turnout time as a component of overall response time. 90th Percentile.  Measure of the total response that the Department controls.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for Roll time of first unit responding code 3.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: 90th percentile value for Roll time of first unit responding code 3.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Roll-time of first unit to respond to possible non-medical Code 3 incidents, in seconds - 90th percentile
Description: Response time is measured from the time the PSAP (Public Safety Answering Point) notifies the first response unit until the first arriving unit arrives on the scene.  Turnout time (to get gear and get on rig) is included in these measurements.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for first unit (Roll time) responding code 3 to a possible non - medical incident.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: 90th percentile value for first unit (Roll time) responding code 3 to a possible non - medical incident.

Description: All Code 3 calls dispatched requiring possible medical care,  measured from call entry (when the fire/EMS call taker answers the call) to arrival on scene by the first responding unit (CRI). Description: All calls dispatched to fire suppression staff, code 3 (emergency) measured from call entry (when the fire/EMS call taker answers the call) to arrival on scene by the first responding unit (CRI).  (CRI="Critical Response Interval")  Includes turnout time as a component of overall response time.  90th percentile.  Measure represents response of emergency services from the prespective of the public.

FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 90th percentile value for first unit response time (CRI) to Code 3 Incident.

Performance Measure: Total response time (CRI) of first unit to possible non-medical Code 3 incidents, in seconds - 90th percentile

Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is collected from the Emergency Communications Department's (ECD) 911 CAD.  Raw CAD data is stored at the ECD.  CAD data analysis reports are stored at SFFD Headquarters. Timing:  Data is available daiily. Information is reported on twice a year.

Goal: Performance Appraisals

Description: This number represents the total number of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled

Goal: Address complaints of discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodations within the City and County of San Francisco
Performance Measure: Total Inquiries & Intakes
Description: This number represents the total number of inquiries and intakes, regardless of outcome, processed by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division.
Technical Description: Enter the total number of inquiries and intakes, regardless of outcome, processed by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division during each fiscal quarter beginning on the first day of each quarter and ending on the last day of the quarter

Performance Measure: Total Number of Complaints Filed
Description: This number represents the total number of inquiries and intakes that led to a filing of a formal complaint by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division on behalf of a complainant.
Technical Description: Enter the total number of inquiries and intakes that led to the filing of a formal complaint by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division during each fiscal quarter beginning on the first day of each quarter and ending on the last day of the quarter.

Goal: Address complaints of discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodations within the City and County of San Francisco
Performance Measure: Total Number of Complaints Filed and Settled
Description: This number of represents the total number of complaints filed by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division on behalf of a complainant which HRC mediated and settled to the satisfaction of all parties to the complaint during each fiscal quarter beginning on the first day of each quarter and ending on the last day of the quarter.
Technical Description: Enter the total number of complaints filed by the Human Rights Commission Discrimination Division on behalf of a complainant which HRC mediated and settled to the satisfaction of all parties to the complaint during each fiscal quarter beginning on the first day of each quarter and ending on the last day of the quarter.
