FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Actual is based on actual number of clients represented by the PD Mental Health Unit.

Goal: Represent defendants effectively
Performance Measure: Number of misdemeanor matters handled
Description: Number of misdemeanor cases in which the PDR appeared in court at least once. A misdemeanor is an offense carrying a possible sentence of one year or less local confinement in the county jail.  (examples: prostitution, driving under the influence, vandalism).
Technical Description: Collection Method: CCSF CMS Report #5029 Timing:  Upon request to CMS
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The department receives this data from Superior Court CMS (Case Management System). The actual is based on actual number of clients represented by the PD Misdemeanor Unit. Total is from CMS report.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion. Timing:  Evaluations are done yearly and available by the end of the fiscal.   New employees are provided 90 day and 6 month evaluations.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 2 employees retired, 1 employee transferred , 4 employees separated.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The department's unit managers are responsible for completing performance evaluations for all employees in their units. The Chief Attorney oversees the evaluation process.  All evaluations are maintained in the employee's personnel file. Timing:  Refer to previous measure.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 2 employees retired, 1 employee transferred , 4 employees separated.

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: Percentage of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: Collection Method: For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.  Timing:  There is no system currently in place to track the submission of performance appraisals.  Until 2000, the Staff Inspection Unit had the task of ensuring compliance with completion and tracking of the PIP binders and PAR forms.  We anticipate using the new HRMS system to monitor compliance.  The new Early Intervention System will also be implemented to address OCC concerns in this area.  For Civilian personnel, Department of Human Resources notifies the SFPD when a performance evaluation is due.  Permanent employees are scheduled for evaluation on a yearly basis.  the completed evaluation is placed in the individual's personnel file.
Technical Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent employees must have an annual appraisal.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The SFPD has a policy that requires performance appraisals twice per year. For FY2013, 100% of the 2,554 employees were scheduled for performance appraisals, equaling the FY2013 Target.

Goal: All city employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: Percentage of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: Collection Method:  SFPD sworn personnel are evaluated by their supervisor every six month period; March -  August and September - February.  An Officer's (Q2's) Performance Appraisal Report (PAR) is placed in their Performance Improvement Program (PIP) Binder which is kept at their Unit under lock and key.  When an officer transfers to a new assignment the PIP Binder also is transferred.  Probationary Officers are evaluated once every month.  Inspectors, Sergeants (Q50's), Lieutenants (Q60's) and Captains (Q80's) PARs are kept in their personnel file.  For civil personnel, Department of Human Resources notifies the SFPD when a performance evaluation is due.  Permanent employees are scheduled for evaluation on a yearly basis.  The completed evaluation is placed in the individual's personnel file.  Timing:  There is no system currently in place to track the submission of Performance Appraisals.  Each District Captain monitors compliance of the completion of Performance Appraisels.
Technical Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/2005.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled accordingto their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.  Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: In FY2013, 90% of all scheduled performance appraisals (2,301 employees) were completed. Throughout the year employees may be on Disability Paid Leave (DP), Catastrophic Illness, or a variety of extended approved leaves of absence. To that end, performance appraisals for those employees can't accurately be done and, thus, are not completed within the departmental semi-annual cycle.  The total falls short of the FY2013 Target but is an improvement over the FY2012 total of 89%.

Goal: Ensure safety of officers and the public
Performance Measure: Number of collisions where the officer is at fault
Description: A count of the number of officer involved vehicle collisions where the officer was determined to be at fault. Collisions are reviewed by Dept. Accident Board of Review to determine training or discipline required.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is selected from traffic collision reports and entered into the Department Accident Board of review (DABOR ) database, maintained at SFPD Traffic Division.  Officer Sally Foster (553-1198) maintains statistics on DABOR dispositions. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The FY2013 total of 72 at-fault incidents is 4% below the Target, and is the same as in FY2012 (0%).  The Department Accident Board of Review (DABOR) is a panel which holds officers accountable. Repeat officer offenders will be given additional training and progressive discipline.  The severity of the collision may be considered in the discipline process.

Goal: Arrest perpetrators of crimes
Performance Measure: Number of adult arrests for Part I property crimes
Description: Number of adult arrests for Part 1 property crimes UCR = Uniform Crime Reporting, a program of the FBI.   UCR Part I property crimes are burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft and arson.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Arrests are recorded by the Sheriff's Office at time of booking, captured by the Court Management System (CMS), and forwarded monthly by mag-tape to the California Department of Justice (DOJ), Sacramento. At SFPD request, DOJ Criminal Justice Statistics Center produces a monthly report, "Adult and Juvenile Arrests Reported" which provide these stats. Timing:  This data is not available in the SFPD automated system. As stated above, arrest information is obtained through special requests from DOJ, and provided in aggregate form to the Department. (DOJ Report AR3311)

Goal: Arrest perpetrators of crimes
Performance Measure: Number of adult arrests for UCR Part I violent crimes
Description: Number of adult arrests for Part 1 violent crimes. Uniform Crime Report (UCR) violent crimes are: homicide, forcible rape, robbery and aggravated assault. Adult is age 18 years and older.
Technical Description: Collection Method: This data is collected by the Sheriff Office. Arrests are recorded by Sheriff at time of booking, captured by Court Management System (CMS), and forwarded monthly by mag-tape to the California Department of Justice (DOJ), Sacramento. At SFPD request, DOJ Criminal Justice Statistics Center produces a monthly report, "Adult and Juvenile Arrests Reported" which provide these stats. Timing:  This data is not available in the SFPD automated system. As stated above, arrest information is obtained through special requests from DOJ, and provided in aggregate form to the Department. (DOJ Report AR3311)

Goal: Arrest perpetrators of crimes
Performance Measure: Number of juvenile arrests for Part I property crimes
Description: Number of Juvenile arrests for Part 1 property crimes. UCR = Uniform Crime Reporting, a program of the FBI.   UCR Part I property crimes are burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Arrests are recorded by Youth Guidance Center (YGC) at time of booking, captured by the Court Management System (CMS), and forwarded monthly by mag-tape to the California Department of Justice (DOJ), Sacramento. At SFPD request, the DOJ Criminal Justice Statistics Center produces a monthly report, "Adult and Juvenile Arrests Reported" which provide these stats. Timing:  This data is not available in the SFPD automated system. As stated above, arrest information is obtained through special requests from DOJ, and provided in aggregate form to the Department (DOJ Report AR3311)

Goal: Arrest perpetrators of crimes
Performance Measure: Number of juvenile arrests for UCR Part I violent crimes
Description: Number of juvenile arrests for Part 1 violent crimes. UCR violent crimes are: homicide, forcible rape, robbery and aggravated assault. Juveniles are under 18 years of age. UCR = Uniform Crime Reporting, a program of the FBI.
Technical Description: Collection Method: This data is collected by the Sheriff's Office. Arrests are recorded by the Youth Guidance Center (YGC) at time of booking, captured by the Court Management System (CMS), and forwarded monthly by mag-tape to the California Department of Justice (DOJ), Sacramento. At SFPD request, DOJ Criminal Justice Statistics Center produces a monthly report, "Adult and Juvenile Arrests Reported" which provide these stats. Timing:  This data is not available in the SFPD automated system. As stated above, arrest information is obtained through special requests from DOJ, and provided in aggregate form to the Department (DOJ Report AR3311).

Goal: Ensure the safety of citizens
Performance Measure: Ensure the safety of persons riding public transportation (MUNI)  in the City; offenses reported as per 1,000 riders
Description: Number of crimes committed on a MUNI bus or at a MUNI facility, as a percentage of MUNI ridership (per 1000 riders), via the SFPD Incident file.  All incidents related to public transportation are coded as such and retrievable.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The proposed figures are obtained via a CrimeMAPS search using Premise Codes associated with Muni. Timing:  Data is obtained monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Offenses are based on a daily ridership of 734,000.  The popularity of personal electronic devices (cell phones, tablets, etc.) has contributed to an increase in Robbery and Theft as many riders use them while in transit.  We will continue to work with partners on public awareness and education campaigns. Directed patrols will be regularly evaluated and adjusted based on crime patterns.                                                                                                                Note, beginning Jan. 1, 2013, at the direction of new MTA Lieutenant Joe Engler, the MTA database began including more bus stop premises, which considerably raises the number of monthly incidents (therefore, comparisons with FY2012 and FY2013 Target and Projected values should not be made).  Also note, beginning with FY2012 there was a change in database systems (from SFPD's CrimeMaps/CABLE to MTA's Muni Response Team Oracle Incident Reporting System) and data collection methods. The FY2012 rate and offenses were recalculated using the MTA database for comparing with FY2013; the FY2013 Target and Projection values were previously entered into COGNOS, therefore were not revised.

Goal: Reduce crime; Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) numbers
Performance Measure: UCR:  Number of UCR homicides per 100,000 population
Description: Number of UCR Homicides per 100,000 Population. UCR Homicide definition: The willful and non-negligent killing of one human being by another = murder and non-negligent manslaughter.  This does not include:  fetal deaths, traffic fatalities, accidental deaths, assaults to murder, attempts to murder.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Number of Homicides divided by current San Francisco population and multiplied by 100,000.  Population FY 2008: 829,848, FY 2009 & FY 2010: 842,265 (Source: CA Department of Finance E-2 Report).
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The rate decreased from 7.4 (FY2012) to 6.2 (FY2013). With a total of 52 incidents for FY2013, the homicide rate is very low for a major city.  The current homicide rate is significantly lower than for the period 2004-2009. Note, due to the nature of this crime, no Target or Projection will be provided.

Goal: Reduce crime; Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) numbers
Performance Measure: UCR:  Number of UCR Part I property offenses reported
Description: UCR Part I property crimes are burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson. UCR = Uniform Crime Reporting, a program of the FBI.  UCR reports are of OFFENSES, not CRIMES.
Technical Description: Collection Method:  Data is obtained from an Access database system which was developed by SFPD and allows us to capture a more current set of data. Data provided for this fiscal year (beginning June 2010) is from our Microsoft Access-based Incident Report System (IRS) which extracts incidents as they are entered by police officers. Each Monday, the COMPSTAT officers prepare a hybrid database, including data from IRS and the hand counts. This data is also used for UCR Reporting to the FBI. Timing:  Monthly, by the 10th of the month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The increase in the use of in-home and personal electronic devices has created more targets of opportunity for property crime. Property crimes are up FY2012 to FY2013 by 19%, from 35,317 to 42,108 offenses but are slightly below the Projected value. We are urging private retailers to increase their security efforts and the Department continues to work on education programs regarding crime prevention and intervention.

Goal: Reduce crime; Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) numbers
Performance Measure: UCR: Number of UCR Part I property offenses reported per 100,000 population
Description: Number of crimes divided by 100,000 population.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Number of Part I Property crimes divided by current San Francisco population and multiplied by 100,000.  Population FY 2008: 829,848, FY2009 & FY2010: 842,625 (Source: CA Department of Finance, E-2 Report).  Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The FY2013 Property rate is based on 42,108 property offenses and a population of 824,625. A Property Crime rate increase of 19% occurred from FY2012 to FY2013 (from 4,191.4 to 4,997.2).  The rate is 26% above the Target but slightly below the Projected value. The popularity of in-home and personal electronic devices has caused an increase in robberies and thefts, both Part I Crimes.   We are urging private retailers to increase their security efforts and the Department continues to work on education programs regarding crime prevention and intervention.

Goal: Reduce crime; Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) numbers
Performance Measure: UCR: Number of UCR Part I violent offenses reported per 100,000 population
Description: Number of offenses divided by 100,000 population.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Number of UCR Violent Part I crimes divided by current San Francisco population and multiplied by 100,000.  Population FY 2008: 829,848, FY 2009 & FY 2010: 842,625 (CA Dept of Finance E-2 Report).  Population:  842,625. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The FY2013 Violent rate is based on 7,386 offenses and a population of 842,625. A Violent Crime rate increase of 8% occurred from FY2012 to FY2013 (from 810.3 to 876.5).  The rate is 11% above the Target but only slightly above the Projected value.  The popularity of personal electronic devices has caused an increase in robberies. Field Operations Bureau has been addressing this issue with public service advisories.  Also, the continuing efforts of the VIOLENCE REDUCTION TEAM and ROBBERY TASK FORCE are designed to impact violent crimes.

Goal: Reduce crime; Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) numbers
Performance Measure: UCR: Number UCR Part I violent offenses reported
Description: UCR = Uniform Crime Reporting, a program of the FBI.   UCR Part I violent crimes are:  homicide, forcible rape, robbery and aggravated assault. For violent crimes only, offenses are crimes multiplied by the number of victims. UCR reports are of OFFENSES, not CRIMES.
Technical Description: Collection Method:   Data is obtained from an Access database system which was developed by SFPD and allows us to capture a more current set of data. Data provided for this fiscal year (beginning June 2010) is from our Microsoft Access-based Incident Report System (IRS) which extracts incidents as they are entered by police officers. Homicide and Rape crime statistics are hand counted. Each Monday, the COMPSTAT officers prepare a hybrid database, including data from IRS and the hand counts. This data is also used for UCR Reporting to the FBI. Timing:  Monthly, by the 10th of the month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: There was an 8% increase in Part I Violent crimes from FY2012 to FY2013 (from 6,827 to 7,386 offenses); this total is 11% above the Target but only slightly above the Projected value.  The popularity of personal electronic devices has caused an increase in robberies. Field Operations Bureau has been addressing this issue with public service advisories.  Also, the continuing efforts of the VIOLENCE REDUCTION TEAM and ROBBERY TASK FORCE are designed to impact violent crimes.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Response time:  Priority A calls (in seconds)
Description: Average time from dispatch of Priority A call to arrival on scene, in seconds. Priority "A" calls are those emergency / in-progress requests for service received by the Department of Emergency Management (DEM) and dispatched to police officers.  Time from dispatch of the call to the officer's notification of arrival on scene is computed.  An average time in seconds is computed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Several time stamps are placed into the dispatch file.  The Department of Emergency Management (DEM) dispatcher stamps the time when the call is dispatched over the air;  the dispatcher also stamps the time the officer notifies dispatch of arrival on the scene.  Delays may occur between officer's arrival on scene and time stamp of arrival. Timing:  DEM updates this data in real time. DEM produces reports for SFPD  monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: An 20-second increase from FY2012 to FY2013 is minimal (from 255 to 275 seconds).  Officers are responding in as timely and safely a manner as possible.

Goal: Respond timely to calls for emergency assistance
Performance Measure: Response time:  Priority B calls (in seconds)
Description: Average time from dispatch of Priority B call to arrival on scene, in minutes and seconds Priority "B" calls are those " just occurred" or urgent requests for service received by the Department of Emergency Management (DEM) and dispatched to police officers. Time from dispatch of the call to the officer's notification of arrival on scene is computed.  An average time in minutes and seconds is computed.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Several time stamps are placed into the dispatch file.  The Department of Emergency Management (DEM) dispatcher stamps the time when the call is dispatched over the air;  the dispatcher also stamps the time the officer notifies dispatch of arrival on the scene.  Delays may occur between officer's arrival on scene and time stamp of arrival. Timing:  DEM updates this data in real time. DEM produces reports for SFPD  monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: A 18-second increase (from 485 to 503 seconds) from FY2012 to FY2013 is minimal for Priority B Calls. Officers are responding in a timely manner.

Goal: Reduce the amount of violence in San Francisco
Performance Measure: Firearm seizures
Description: The number of firearms collected by SFPD.  A major goal of SFPD is to remove all firearms off the street.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Every firearm seized is collected, tracked, and recorded by Crime Scene Investigation (CSI).  Paper forms are used for this record keeping. Timing:  Crime Scene Investigation prepares a monthly spreadsheet , by District, displaying the types of firearms seized.  Data is available at the end of each month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY2013 Firearm Seizures were up 34 percent from FY2012, and above the FY2013 Target by 29 percent.  We believe this is due to our partnership with both the FBI and ATF to prosecute, in Federal Court, felons arrested in possession of firearms.  Known felons are now less likely to carry guns when faced with the prospect of a long prison sentence under the Federal system.

Goal: Reduce traffic collisions and ensure pedestrian safety
Performance Measure: Number of 'driving under the influence' arrests
Description: This is the number of arrests made for "driving under the influence" ( this includes DUI-Alcohol or Drugs, as primary or subsequent charge)..
Technical Description: Collection Method: Traffic Company hand-counts  reports and maintains a master file involving DUI charges. Timing:  Aggregate data is available at the end of each month.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: FY2012 DUI arrests totaled 546; FY2013 totaled 534, well below the Target but just above the Projected value. DUI arrests are down due to an aggressive Public Awareness campaign.

Goal: Reduce traffic collisions and ensure pedestrian safety
Performance Measure: Number of moving citations issued
Description: Number of moving citations issued.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data is hand counted .  A summary report is received from each district station counting issuances for a given period by selected violations and entered into a master worksheet maintained by traffic company. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The number of citations written has decreased due to reductions in overall staffing levels and within the Traffic Company.  No FY2013 Projection was provided due to incomplete data received in FY2012.

Goal: Reduce traffic collisions and ensure pedestrian safety
Performance Measure: Number of traffic collisions that result in fatalities
Description: The number of traffic collisions that result in fatalities.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Selective data from traffic collision reports are entered into an Accident Record Management System (RMS) database maintained by the Traffic Company. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: There was a Fiscal-Year decrease of 11% in fatal traffic accidents (from 35 in FY2012 to 31 in FY2013). Note, due to the nature of this crime, no Target will be provided.  This total is far below the FY2013 Projection.

Goal: Reduce traffic collisions and ensure pedestrian safety
Performance Measure: Number of traffic collisions that result in injuries
Description: The number of traffic collisions that result in injuries.
Technical Description: Collection Method: All traffic collision reports are hand counted by Traffic Company.  Selective data from traffic collision reports are entered into an Accident Record Management System (RMS) database maintained by the SFPD Traffic Company. Timing:  Monthly.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: In any major city, traffic accidents are difficult to measure because every incident involving a complaint of pain is considered an injury accident. There was a 16% increase from FY2012 (2,709 incidents) to FY2013 (3,150 incidents) and 8% more than the Target but this is less than the FY2013 Projection.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Number of Cases Closed During the Reporting Period
Description: The measure identifies the number of cases closed, including those cases that were mediated, during the relevant time period. Section 3304 of the California Government Code dictates that all investigations of police misconduct should be completed within one calendar year.
Technical Description: The OCC maintains statistics and provides quarterly reports on the number of cases closed. The reports are presented to the San Francisco Police Commission and are a matter of public record. The OCC's quarterly and annual statistical reports are on file with the OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets. SF 94102. Timing: Public reports are generated quarterly and annually, and can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The OCC's goal is to close as many or more cases than the number of new cases filed during a fiscal year.  During FY 2012-13, the OCC opened 694 cases and closed 723 cases, meeting our goal of closing more cases than the number of new cases filed during the fiscal year.  While the OCC was budgeted for 17 OCC investigators, the OCC operated with only 13 fully trained investigators due to vacancies and family leave of absences.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Number of Cases Closed During the Reporting Period per FTE Investigator
Description: The measure is calculated by dividing the total number of complaints closed by OCC in the relevant period by the number of fully trained 8124 investigators serving in the period.  The overall agency's objective is to close as many as or more complaints than the number of new complaints filed annually.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The OCC maintains statistics and provides quarterly reports on the number of complaints closed.  The reports are presented to the SF Police Commission and are a matter of public record.  OCC personnel rosters, including number of 8124 investigators employed in given time periods, are on record with OCC's Senior Account Clerk.  The OCC's quarterly and annual statistical reports, which also contain general staffing information, are on file with OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets., SF 94102. Timing:  The OCC generates public reports quarterly and annually.  The reports can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the second half of FY 2012-13, the OCC operated with 13 fully trained 8124 investigators.  During the measurement period, a fully trained investigator closed an average of 27 cases.  To close as many or more complaints than the number of new complaints filed annually and to adequately address the agency's backlog, OCC investigators are required to close 4 or more cases per month.  Proper case management, along with full investigative staffing, will ensure that investigators close an average of 4 or more cases per month.  Overall, a fully trained investigator closed an average of 54 cases during FY 2012-13, exceeding the target of 48 per investigator.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Number of Cases Mediated During the Reporting Period
Description: The measure identifies the number of cases mediated during the relevant time period. Mediation is an alternative way of resolving complaints about police conduct. The OCC identifies cases where the parties might benefit from a face to face discussion of their perspectives on the encounter that resulted in a complaint. If both the complainant and the officer agree, the case is taken out of the investigation process and scheduled for a mediation with our trained volunteer mediators.
Technical Description: The OCC maintains statistics and provides quarterly reports on the number of cases mediated. The reports are presented to the San Francisco Police Commission and are a matter of public record. OCC's quarterly and annual statistical reports are on file with the OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets. SF 94102. Timing: Public reports are generated quarterly and annually, and can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the second half of FY 2012-13, the OCC mediated 24 cases.  Overall, the OCC mediated a total of 50 cases or about 7% of the 723 cases that were closed during FY 2012-13.  In comparison, the OCC also mediated about 7% of the total number of cases that were closed from the previous fiscal year 2011-12.  OCC's mediation rate remains at 7%.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Number of Cases Sustained During the Reporting Period
Description: The measure identifies the number of completed investigations which contain at least one sustained allegation of police misconduct.  Sustained is one of ten findings that could be reached by the Office of Citizen Complaints.  A sustained finding is one in which a preponderance of the evidence proved that the conduct complained of did occur, and that using as a standard the applicable regulations of the San Francisco Police Department, the conduct was improper.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The OCC maintains statistics and provides reports (from OCC's database and from reports of OCC's staff attorneys) annually to the Police Commission pursuant to City Charter 4.127 and Police Commission Resolution 19-91, concerning numbers of sustained complaints submitted by OCC and dispositions of said complaints by SFPD, through the Chief and/or the SF Police Commission. The OCC's quarterly and annual statistical reports are on file with OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets. SF 94102. Timing:  Public reports are generated quarterly and annually, and can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The OCC closed 350 cases during the second half of FY 2012-13.  Of those, 15 cases had one or more sustained allegations of misconduct, resulting in a 4% sustained rate.  During the entire FY 2012-13, the OCC closed a total of 723 cases.  Of those, 39 cases had one or more sustained allegations of misconduct, resulting in a 5.4% sustained rate for FY 2012-13.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of Sustained Cases Completed within the One-Year Statute of Limitations Under Government Code 3304
Description: This measure is defined by dividing the total number of sustained cases sent by OCC to SFPD during the relevant period into the number of sustained complaints that are sent within Government Code section 3304's one-year limitation period or other time specified by Government Code Section 3304. A complaint may be against personnel, policy or procedure.  Sustained is one of ten findings that could be reached as a result of an investigation by the OCC.  A sustained finding is one in which a preponderance of the evidence proved that the conduct complained of did occur, and that using as a standard the applicable regulations of the Department, the conduct was improper.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The OCC maintains statistics and provides reports (from OCC's database and from reports of OCC's staff attorneys) annually to the Police Commission pursuant to City Charter 4.127 and Police Commission Resolution 19-91, concerning numbers of sustained complaints submitted by OCC and dispositions of said complaints by SFPD, via Chief and/or SF Police Commission.  OCC's quarterly and annual statistical reports are on file with OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public library, Larkin and Grove Streets. SF 94102. Timing:  Public reports are generated quarterly and annually, and are posted on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the second half of FY 2012-13, the OCC sustained 15 cases.  All of those cases were sent to the Department within Government Code Section 3304's one-year statue of limitation period or other time specified by Government Code Section 3304.  All of the 39 cases that were sustained during the entire FY 2012-13 were sent to the Department within Government Code Section 3304's one-year statue of limitation period or other time specified by Government Code Section 3304.

Goal: Address civilian complaints of police misconduct professionally and efficiently
Performance Measure: Percentage of Sustained Cases that Resulted in Corrective or Disciplinary Action by the Chief or Police Commission
Description: This measure is calculated by dividing the number of cases in which disciplinary action was imposed by the Chief of Police or Police Commission by the number of cases that were actually submitted by the OCC and were taken into consideration by the Chief or Police Commision.  This measure does not include those cases in which no action was taken by the SFPD because the officer was no longer within the jurisdiction of the SFPD or Police Commission (the officer resigned or retired) or in which no action was taken by the SFPD within the one-year statute of limitations period.
Technical Description: The OCC is notified by the SFPD of its adjudication and disposition of OCC sustained cases.  The OCC keeps records of those notices and generates a report of the adjudication of those cases.  The OCC presents a report of its sustained cases and their SFPD dispositions, with confidential information redacted, as part of its quarterly and annual reports to the Police Commission.  Those reports are on file with the OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, with the Police Commission office, 5th floor, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103, and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets. SF 94102. Timing: Public reports are generated quarterly and annually, and can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.  The Police Department also generates monthly reports on discipline imposed, and those reports can be found on www.sfgov.org/police.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Of the 14 cases considered by the SFPD for disciplinary action during the second half of FY 2012-13, discipline or other corrective action was imposed in 13 of the cases.  Note that these cases were not necessarily cases sent to the Chief's office or Police Commission for consideration during the measurement period.

Goal: Facilitate corrective action in response to complaints
Performance Measure: Number of Findings of Policy, Procedure, or Practice Failure Identified in the OCC Caseload During the Reporting Period
Description: The measure identifies the number of findings of policy, procedure, or practice failure identified in the OCC caseload during the relevant time period. The OCC's policy work is an essential aspect of its mission. The San Francisco City Charter requires the OCC to present quarterly recommendations concerning SFPD's policies or practices that enhance police-community relations while ensuring effective police services.
Technical Description: The OCC files statistical reports containing all policy recommendations made to SFPD and the Police Commission on a quarterly basis. Special reports are prepared by the OCC as warranted and presented to the SFPD and/or the Police Commission. The reports to the Police Commission are public record. OCC's reports containing policy recommendations are on file with the OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, on the OCC website: www.sfgov.org/occ, with the Police Commission, Room 505, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103 and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets., SF 94102. Timing: The Office of Citizen Complaints generates public reports quarterly and annually. The reports can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the second half of FY 2012-13, the OCC identified 3 policy findings in OCC's caseload.  Overall, the OCC identified a total of 7 policy findings in OCC's caseload during FY 2012-13.

Goal: Facilitate corrective action in response to complaints
Performance Measure: Number of Policy, Procedure, and Practice Findings Presented to SFPD or Police Commission During the Reporting Period
Description: The measure identifies the number of policy, procedure, and practice recommendations presented to the SFPD or the Police Commission during the report period.  The OCC's policy work is an essential aspect of its mission. The San Francisco City Charter requires the OCC to present quarterly recommendations concerning SFPD's policies or practices that enhance police-community relations while ensuring effective police services.
Technical Description: Collection Method: The OCC files statistical reports containing all policy recommendations made to SFPD and the Police Commission on a quarterly basis.  Special reports are prepared by the OCC as warranted and presented to the SFPD and/or the Police Commission.  The reports to the Police Commission are public record.  OCC's reports containing policy recommendations are on file with the OCC, 25 Van Ness Avenue, Suite 700, SF CA 94102, on the OCC website: www.sfgov.org/occ, with the Police Commission, Room 505, Hall of Justice, 850 Bryant St. SF 94103 and with the SF Public Library, Larkin and Grove Streets., SF 94102. Timing:  The OCC generates public reports quarterly and annually. The reports can be found on the agency's website: www.sfgov.org/occ.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: During the second half of FY 2012-13, the OCC presented 10 policy, procedure and/or practice recommendations to SFPD and/or the Police Commission.  Recommendations presented to the Police Commission and/or SFPD during the measurement period were not necessarily the same ones that were identified in the OCC caseload during the measurement period because of the agency's prioritization of policy issues and the agency's need to provide recommendations in response to policy issues raised by either the Police Commission or SFPD.

Goal: Economic Impact of Port Capital Program
Performance Measure: Annual Capital Budget
Description: Total Annual Budget
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data drawn from annual capital budget submission Timing:  Date is available on an annual basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The original FY 2012-13 budget included $10.2M in capital funding. In May 2013 the Board of Supervisors approved a $26.1M supplemental appropriation of new Port Revenue Bonds and interest earnings for use on the Pier 27 Cruise Terminal project and pier improvements in the northern waterfront.

Goal: Financial Stability - Maintain a strong financial postion
Performance Measure: Outstanding receivables as a percent of annual billed revenue
Description: Outstanding net receivables as percent of annual billed revenues.
Technical Description: Collection Method: As a result of Controller's PM review which could not validate this PM, staff recommends revising the denominator from "billed revenue" (which was manually calculated using varying methods over the years) to "total port revenue" (budget basis, not financial statement, and regularly reported and consistently calculated).    Net receivables data is collected in the Port's financial software, Oracle, and then reported in the Summary Aging Report. Then, the Port determines the percentage receivable by dividing the net receivables (numerator) by the total annual revenues (denominator).
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Collection efforts continue to improve delinquency rate.  Notably, Pier 38 is 67% of the net receivables at approx $2m.

Goal: Financial Stability - Maintain or improve the Port's access to the capital markets
Performance Measure: The Port's debt service coverage ratio
Description: Net revenues available for debt service divided by debt services for the 2004 refunding bonds.
Technical Description: Collection Method: From the Port's Audited Annual Financial Statements and other related financial documents from the Finance Department. Timing:  Data needed to calculate the debt service coverage ratio is available only annually.  Data is typically available by mid-October, after the completion of the Port's annual financial statement audit.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: This is just a placehold estimate until FY 2012-13 financial audit is complete. This high coverage ratio is the result of lower debt service than previously estimated due to delays in issuing planned debt.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom performance appraisals were scheduled
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal is to be conducted.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months. Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion. Timing:  Data collected throughout the year and is tracked by Port HR
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Performance appraisels were scheduled for employees that were not otherwise on leave.

Goal: All City employees have a current performance appraisal
Performance Measure: # of employees for whom scheduled performance appraisals were completed
Description: New measure requested by Mayor on 8/15/05.  This is the number of applicable employees in a department for whom a performance appraisal was conducted and completed during the fiscal year.  "Completed" means an appraisal form has been filled out and is in the employee's personnel file.  DHR policy is that all permanent and provisional employees must have an annual appraisal.  For new employees, the first review should be scheduled according to their applicable probationary period.  For other employees, reviews should be conducted every 12 months.   Departments can do appraisals for temporary employees at their discretion.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Supervisors and managers send the original performance appraisal document to the Port�s Human Resources Office where it is clocked in and recorded in DHRs PeopleSoft system that contains information about each Port employee, such as contact information, social security number, dates of services, etc.  After recording, the documents are filed at the front of the employee�s personnel folder. Timing:  Data collected throughout the year and is tracked by Port HR

Goal: Financial Stability - Improve utilization of maintenance resources
Performance Measure: Maintenance cost per square foot of Port facilities
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Increase in leased square footage during FY 2012-13 reduced rate compared to earlier projections.

Goal: Financial Stability - Improve utilization of maintenance resources
Performance Measure: Percentage of preventative maintenance of sewer pumps performed on schedule
Description: Percentage of routine scheduled preventative maintenance to be performed on sewer pumps and backflow devices.
Technical Description: Rate based on records maintained by the Port�s Maintenance Division
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Some of the sewage pumps at Pier 80 have been not been active (and not receiving preventative maintenance) due to ongoing repairs of the sewer line.

Goal: Financial Stability - Improve utilization of maintenance resources
Performance Measure: Reduce the number of unscheduled repairs of sewer pumps
Description: Total number of unscheduled sewer pump maintenance events.
Technical Description: Records maintained by the Port�s Maintenance Division
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Certain pump failures were due to tenant misuse such as: mop strings and rags being flushed down sink,  incorrect re-wiring by contractor, dumping of outhouse waste that would not clear pump station, and salt water effluent from tenant operation.

Goal: Economic Impact - Increase cruise volume
Performance Measure: Total number of cruise ship calls
Description: Total number of cruise ship calls
Technical Description: Collection Method: Projected is based on passenger cruise schedule.  Actuals are based on the Port's billing system Timing:  Bookings 6 - 12 months in advance but are subject to change
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Strong demand in cruise ship calling San Francisco.  This is clearly a sign of economic recovery as well as San Francisco as an attractive destination.  Cruise calls booked for next fiscal year is 75.

Goal: Economic Impact - Increase cruise volume
Performance Measure: Total number of cruise ship passengers
Description: Combined total of embark, transit and debark passengers
Technical Description: Collection Method: Projected is based on passenger cruise schedule.  Actuals are based on the Port's billing system Timing:  Monthly on the 30th of the following month

Goal: Economic Impact - Increase the volume of cargo shipping
Performance Measure: Total cargo tonnage - Breakbulk
Description: Total cargo tonnage from breakbulk cargo.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data collected and maintained by Maritime division staff. Timing:  Monthly on the 30th of the following month
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Still experiencing low demand in breakbulk.  Cargo volume decreased significantly in the second half of the year, which billable metric tonnage of 3,524 in the second half of the year.

Goal: Economic Impact - Increase the volume of cargo shipping
Performance Measure: Total cargo tonnage - Bulk
Description: Total cargo tonnage from bulk cargo. Cargo tonnage is the total mass of actual cargo transported through the port. Bulk cargo can be in liquid or dry form, but the Port is specifically tracking dry cargo. It is transported unpackaged in large quantities and then is usually dropped or poured, with a spout or shovel bucket into a bulk carrier ship's hold, railroad car, or tanker truck/trailer/semi-trailer body.
Technical Description: Collection Method: On the monthly basis, the Port receives  Excel spreadsheets identifying the tonnage by month from customers, including Hanson, Cemex and Darling. Maritime staff then save the spreadsheets on the Port's network.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Demand in both sand and aggregate are experiencing upward trend, 17% and 9% increase respectively compared to prior year.

Goal: Economic Impact - Track ferry passenger volume
Performance Measure: Total number of ferry passengers transiting though Port managed facilities.
Description: Total number of ferry passengers transiting though Port managed facilities. (includes China Basin terminal, excludes Golden Gate Ferries)
Technical Description: Collection Method: Data depends on reporting from ferry operations Timing:  Presently finalizing new ferry operator agreement by the end of FY 06/07, and expect this agreement  to  include a monthly or quarterly reporting requirement.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The ferry ridership increased 7.7% compared to previous year.  This is primarily due to South San Francisco service started in April 2013.   Also, all ferry services except Tiburon are now under the management of WETA, which invest more marketing effort to increase ridership.

Goal: Economic Impact - Enhance Economic Activity on Waterfront
Performance Measure: Total number of projects in defined development process
Description: Total number of projects currently in development process on Port property. A project is deemed to be in the development process only after Port Commission and/or the Board of Supervisor action designating it as such; for example, Commission approval to release development request for proposal or authorization for Port staff to manage development project in-house.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Commission Resolutions or other relevant documentation available at Pier 1. Timing:  Data maintained in project files on continuous basis; reporting will be as of January 1 each year
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: As of the end of June 2013 ongoing Port development projects include: 1) Seawall Lot 351 ('8 Washington'); 2) Piers 30-32 Arena & Seawall Lot 330 (Golden State Warriors); 3) Downtown Ferry Terminal Expansion (WETA); 4) Soutthern Waterfront Gateway Site; 5) Pier 38 Rehabilitation; 6) Seawall Lot 337/Pier 48 ('Mission Rock'); 7) Pier 70 Waterfront Site (Forest City); 8) 20th Street Historic Buildings (Orton Development Inc.); 9) Crane Cove Park; and 10) Phase 2 of the Pier 27 Cruise Terminal/Northeast Wharf Plaza.

Goal: Quality of Life - Public participation in implementation of Waterfront Land Use Plan
Performance Measure: Total number of community meetings held to discuss ongoing Port projects and programs
Description: Each of the Port's major planning projects and programs is vetted through a community process, which requires significant staff support. The community planning process typically uses the Port's existing advisory groups as the primary community outreach venue. Additionally, there are advisory groups that are administered by other divisions at the Port, such as the Fisherman’s Wharf Advisory Group and the Maritime Commerce Advisory Committee, both of which are administered by the Maritime Division. These standing committees, along with public meetings of the Port Commission, provide the primary forum for public outreach regarding Port projects and programs. Additionally, the Port relies upon other community forums, including groups such as SPUR, San Francisco Architectural Heritage, BCDC Design Review Board, and special, ad-hoc meetings such as “Town Hall” meetings, planning charettes, etc., to conduct public outreach.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Advisory Group/Committee meeting notices, agendas, and minutes available at Pier 1 provide details about community meetings. Planning & Development Division staff reach out to project managers to ensure that all meetings are captured and recorded in a master tracking spreadsheet. Timing:  Data on advisory group/committee meetings, including meeting notices, agendas, and minutes, are maintained in project files located at Pier 1 on continuous basis.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The Port exceeded the projection due to the formation of several sub-committees to the Piers 30-32 Citizens Advisory Committee (CAC)

Goal: Economic Impact - Achieve maximum revenue from leasing activities
Performance Measure: Net Revenue (Gross Revenues minus Gross Expenditures)
Description: Collected revenues in commercial/industrial and parking revenue, less Real Estate Division expenditures
Technical Description: Collection Method: Port Revenue Budget (for target reports) and Accounts Receivables records (for projected and actual reports), less Real Estate Division expenditure budget (for target) and actual expenses (for projection and actual reports). Timing:  Accounting generates the Statement of Revenues report on the monthly basis and the Port performs a Six Month Report for revenues and expenditures that can inform the mid-year update. Actuals will need to be reported after fiscal year-end close.

Goal: Economic Impact - Achieve maximum revenue from leasing activities
Performance Measure: Net Revenue Growth Over Prior Year
Description: Percentage growth of net revenues year over year. Annual percentage increase is typically between 2.5-3%. Goal will be approximately 5% to achieve growth in resources to invest in other mission-driven fundings such as maritime and preservation of the waterfront for the citizens of California.
Technical Description: Collection Method: Determine net revenues (Port Revenue Budget (for target reports) and Accounts Receivables records (for projected and actual reports), less Real Estate Division expenditure budget (for target) and actual expenses (for projection and actual reports)) and estimate percentage change year over year. Timing:  Accounting generates the Statement of Revenues report on the monthly basis and the Port performs a Six Month Report for revenues and expenditures that can inform the mid-year update. Actuals will need to be reported after fiscal year-end close.

Goal: Economic Impact - Achieve maximum revenue from leasing activities
Performance Measure: Overall Port Vacancy Rate
Description: Vacant property that is ready and available to lease.
Technical Description: Data is derived from Rent Roll Report and Vacancy Report, which are prepared as requested. Rent rolls are generated by the Port’s property management software “Propworks”.  Those statements are then manually reviewed by Property Management staff to correct for any errors or include any space that is under a pending lease negotiation.  The combination of data and analysis creates the Vacancy report. Both files are saved on the Real Estate Division network drive. Vacancy is defined as square footage of office and shed space which is actively available to lease, divided by total square footage of office and shed space port wide.  Office and shed properties are the only types included because they represent more traditional real estate space, and are thus loosely comparable to other private sector vacancy calculations.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Economic recovery coupled with America's Cup occupancy has driven demand for Port property above expectations, therefore the vacancy rate is lower than expected.

Goal: Economic Impact - Achieve maximum revenue from leasing activities
Performance Measure: Revenue per square foot of rentable space
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Change in the mix of lease types drove down overall value per square foot, however both the area leased and the overall revenue increased.

Goal: Economic Impact - Achieve maximum revenue from leasing activities
Performance Measure: Revenue to Expense Ratio
Description: Collected revenues in commercial/industrial and parking revenue
Technical Description: Collection Method: Port Revenue Budget (for target reports) and Accounts Receivables records (for projected and actual reports), divided by Real Estate Division expenditure budget (for target) and actual expenses (for projection and actual reports). Timing:  Accounting generates the Statement of Revenues report on the monthly basis and the Port performs a Six Month Report for revenues and expenditures that can inform the mid-year update. Actuals will need to be reported after fiscal year-end close.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CR3.1 Billing Accuracy (water/wastewater/power)= Billing Error Rate (Number of error-driven billing adjustments per 10,000 bills)
Description: Billing accuracy using the number of error-driven billing adjustments during reporting period / number of bills generated during reporting, multiply by 10,000 = error rate
Technical Description: Data Source: SFPUC Customer Care and Billing System How: SQL Query of cancelled and rebilled bills Calculation: Number of error-driven billing adjustments during reporting period divided by the number of bills generated during reporting, multiply by 10,000 = number of adjustments per 10,000 bills.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CR3.4  Water meter reading accuracy (Number of errors per 1,000 reads)
Description: Number of errrors divided by total number of meter reads multiplied by 1,000 = water meter reading errors per 1,000 water meter reads
Technical Description: Data Source: SFPUC Customer Care and Billing System How: SQL Query for meter reads not used on bill Calculation: Need meter reading error divided by number of meter readings completed multiplied by 1,000 = # errors per 1,000 meters read

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CR6.3a  Percent of water rate and fee structure that reflects cost of service (including funding capital investment, O&M, and contribution to reserve)
Description: Report water, wastewater, and power separately. For water, wastewater and power: weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent. Weighted average price should consider quantity supplied at differet price levels. Full cost to deliver should reflect full cost of service, including funding capital investment, O&M and contribution to reserve. Indicators for water , wastewater, and power should be calculated seperately.
Technical Description: Data Source: Rate studies How: Periodic independent rate studies determine cost of service by customer class, and rates set accordingly - apply weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CR6.3b  Percent of wastewater rate and fee structure that reflects cost of service (including funding capital investment, O&M, and contribution to reserve)
Description: Report water, wastewater, and power separately. For water, wastewater and power: weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent. Weighted average price should consider quantity supplied at differet price levels. Full cost to deliver should reflect full cost of service, including funding capital investment, O&M and contribution to reserve. Indicators for water , wastewater, and power should be calculated seperately.
Technical Description: Data Source: Rate studies How: Periodic independent rate studies determine cost of service by customer class, and rates set accordingly - apply weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CR6.3c  Percent of power rate and fee structure that reflects cost of service (including funding capital investment, O&M, and contribution to reserve)
Description: Report water, wastewater, and power separately. For water, wastewater and power: weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent. Weighted average price should consider quantity supplied at differet price levels. Full cost to deliver should reflect full cost of service, including funding capital investment, O&M and contribution to reserve. Indicators for water , wastewater, and power should be calculated seperately.
Technical Description: Data Source: Rate studies How: Periodic independent rate studies determine cost of service by customer class, and rates set accordingly - apply weighted average retail price charged divided by full retail cost to deliver. Multiply result by 100 to get percent.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CY3.1a Percent labor hours worked by SFPUC Service Territory Residents as a percent of all hours worked
Description: The Project Labor Agreement of March 2007, governing the Water System Improvement Program, provides for labor stability on all covered construction projects and has set a goal of 50% of Total Hours and 50% of Total Apprentice Hours to be performed by SFPUC Service Territory Residents (includes SF residents).
Technical Description: Data Source: All SFPUC construction projects, including those covered by the WSIP PLA, utilize San Francisco's web-based labor compliance program, "Elation Systems, Inc." The online software and database allows contractors to submit their weekly certified payroll reports electronically. Elation Systems' electronic payrolls are used to produce the employment data included in this report. How: Data is collated from Elation reports, including hours, wages, crafts, and worker residence. Calculation: (a) Service Territory Resident Hours (includes 267 zip codes within the SFPUC service territory) is divided by Total Hours, and then converted to a percentage.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Calculation: Through June 2013: 2,515,878, divided by 5,037,779, multiplied by 100.    9/3/13

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CY3.1b Percent apprentice labor hours worked by WSIP PLA Service Territory Residents Apprentices as a percent of all Apprentice hours worked.
Description: The Project Labor Agreement of March 2007, governing the Water System Improvement Program, provides for labor stability on all covered construction projects and has set a goal of 50% of Total Hours and 50% of Total Apprentice Hours to be performed by SFPUC Service Territory Residents (includes SF residents).
Technical Description: Data Source: All SFPUC construction projects, including those covered by the WSIP PLA, utilize San Francisco's web-based labor compliance program, "Elation Systems, Inc." The online software and database allows contractors to submit their weekly certified payroll reports electronically. Elation Systems' electronic payrolls are used to produce the employment data included in this report. How: Data is collated from Elation reports, including hours, wages, crafts, and worker residence. Calculation: Service Territory Resident Apprentice Hours is divided by Total Apprentice Hours.

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CY3.2a Labor hours worked by local residents as percent of all hours worked
Description: The City and County of San Francisco passed an ordinance in 2010[1] requiring public work or improvement contracts over $400k to hire employees local to the project beginning with a 20% requirement and increasing by 5% each year* until it reaches the maximum threshold of 50%. The ordinance took effect in 2011 (Year 1*). Per the ordinance, Year 1 or FY2011-12 projects must meet the 20% requirement. Year 2 or FY2012-13 projects must meet the 25% requirement. And so on, so forth up to 50%. *Note: Each year runs from March 25th to March 24th; therefore, this is used as a proxy for the fiscal year.
Technical Description: Data Source: Data is captured using the Elation Systems' certified payroll database. Calculation: The SFPUC works closely with the City's Office of Economic and Workforce Development (OEWD) to track and monitor all workforce compliance requirements. For purposes of this report, and to keep in alignment with OEWD's annually published results, the numbers provided here are found in the San Francisco's Local Hiring Policy for Construction Annual Report.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Requirement is 25%. 9/3/13 updated to 29% based on SSP --updated 2/13/13

Goal: Invest in Customers/Community
Performance Measure: CY3.2b Labor hours worked by local resident apprectices as a percent of all aprectice hours worked.
Description: The City and County of San Francisco passed an ordinance in 2010[1] requiring public work or improvement contracts over $400k to hire employees local to the project beginning with a 20% requirement and increasing by 5% each year* until it reaches the maximum threshold of 50%. The ordinance took effect in 2011 (Year 1*). Per the ordinance, Year 1 or FY2011-12 projects must meet the 20% requirement. Year 2 or FY2012-13 projects must meet the 25% requirement. And so on, so forth up to 50%. *Note: Each year runs from March 25th to March 24th; therefore, this is used as a proxy for the fiscal year.
Technical Description: Data Source: Data is captured using the Elation Systems' certified payroll database. Calculation: The SFPUC works closely with the City's Office of Economic and Workforce Development (OEWD) to track and monitor all workforce compliance requirements. For purposes of this report, and to keep in alignment with OEWD's annually published results, the numbers provided here are found in the San Francisco's Local Hiring Policy for Construction Annual Report.

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN 12.2b Total electricity reduction achieved by customers (in MWh)
Description: Total MWh electricity reduction resulting from customers' efforts and/or SFPUC audits.
Technical Description: Data Source:On annual fiscal year basis: Power/ EES Project records: Tally savings for individual EE projects. Note:  Impact of LED streetlight conversions reported elsewhere. How: Savings for individual EE projects are tallied Calculation: Sum of estimated kWh savings for projects completed in the six month period.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Target swings are due to large funded projects already in the pipeline. The trend from 2014 is down, consistent with the 10 year plan.    9/3/13

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN 12.2c Total gas reduction achieved by customers (in therms)
Description: Total gas reductions (therms) that have resulted from customers' efforts and/or SFPUC audits
Technical Description: Data Source: Power/ EES Project records: Savings for individual EE projects are tallied. Note: Any impact from LED streetlight conversions reported separately. How: Savings for individual EE projects are tallied Calculation: Sum of estimated natural gas (therms) savings for projects completed in the six month period.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Target swings are due to large funded projects already in the pipeline. The trend from 2014 is down, consistent with the 10 year plan.    9/3/13

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN10.1 Number of unauthorized discharges from the combined sewer system
Description: Provide the number of unauthorized discharges from the combined sewer system.
Technical Description: Data Source: Unauthorized discharges reported to the EPA or Regional Board: Permit reporting requirements How: Report or none Calculation: Number of discharges reported
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Though target is zero, there is a potential unauthorized discharge from Balboa Street manhole from November 21-22, 2012; investigations and corrective measures underway.

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN10.2 Percent of annual wet and dry weather flow treated before discharged per year (by level of quality)
Description: Divide quantity of wet and dry weather flows that receive at least primary treatment by total wet and dry  weather flows for each facility (Oceanside and Southeast), multiply by 100. Divide quantity of wet and dry weather flows that receive secondary treatment by total wet and dry weather flows for each facility (Oceanside and Southeast), multiply by 100.
Technical Description: Calculation: All outflows receive primary treatment. Secondary treatment NPDS permitted October through April (wet season) and reported annually in July.
FY 2013 Yr End Dept Comment: Projected year end total: 100% recieving at least primary treatment: 90% Secondary and primary treatment and 10% primary treatment only. -George Engel/Jeff Yee -2/13

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN12.1b Average monthly electricity used per SFPUC street light (in kWh)
Description: Enter average monthly energy use per SFPUC street light (in killowatt hours).
Technical Description: Data Source: Power Enterprise Meter Data Management System (MDMS) & Streetlight Inventory How: Calculated using spreadsheet sum of monthly energy from streetlights divided by total number of streetlights Calculation: Enter average monthly electricity use per sfpuc street light (in kilowatt hours).
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: The conversion of 18,600 cobra head-type, high pressure sodium to light emitting diode (LED) luminaires was delayed. The project has a projected completion date of June 30, 2015.

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN12.2a  Annual peak load reduction (in kW)
Description: Enter reductions in annual peak load for electricity and gas that have resulted from customers' efforts and/or SFPUC audits. If peak load data is not available, provide total reduction in consumption and indicate this in your response.
Technical Description: Data Source:On annual fiscal year basis: Power/ EES Project records: Savings for individual EE projects are tallied. Note:  Impact of LED streetlight conversions reported elsewhere. How: Savings for individual EE projects are tallied Calculation: Sum of estimated kW savings for projects completed in the six month period.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: Peak load expected to be less in 2014-15 due to different mix of EE project types.    9/3/13

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN16.1a  SFPUC's electricty and/or natural gas consumption for provision of all SFPUC services (metric tons)
Description: Total direct and indirect greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (metric tons of carbon equivalent) for electricity and natural gas consumption per year using CCAR protocol or other protocal as determined by SFE/Departmental Climate Action Plan requirements. Indirect GHG emissions are defined as GHG emissions from consumption of purchased electricity, heat, or steam. For purposes of this reporting, use Scope 1 and Scope 2.
Technical Description: Data Source: SFPUC DepCap report as submitted to SFE annually in spring of the fiscal year for, and following the end of, the prior fiscal year. How: Used  methodology as contained in SFPUC spring DepCap report for prior fiscal year as required by SFE. Calculation: Used SFPUC DepCap report results (including fleet) for prior fiscal year. *Note that a draft third party verification of SFE's 2010 community-wide ghg inventory was completed,  but does not include the emissions factor used for the various sources of GHG emissions. Note that beginning with FY2011/12 reporting (for 2010/11 DepCAP report), natural gas emissions exclude Treasure Island. Previous years' reports are artificially inflated due to inclusion of TI  natural gas consumption, which is not part of SFPUC's carbon footprint as a City Agency/Department.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 2,581 metric tons CO2 emissions for electricity and natural gas consumption. From FY2011-12 DepCAP report (submitted in spring 2013). Electricity = 0 metric tons CO2 Natural Gas = 2,581 metric tons CO2 9/3/13 Note that beginning with FY2011/12 reporting (for 2010/11 DepCAP report), natural gas emissions exclude Treasure Island. Previous years' reports are artificially inflated due to inclusion of TI  natural gas consumption, which is not part of SFPUC's carbon footprint as a City Department.  Additionally, beginning in 2011, SFPUC began buying only renewable energy to offset any deficiencies in its hydro electric power supply; as a result, its electricity GHG emissions are zero (hydro electric and renewewable forms of power produce zero GHG emissions).  This accounts for a reduction of 2,188 metric tons eCO2 from the 2010/2011 reporting year.   Target: Identify opportunities for direct and indirect GHG reductions; implement where cost effective and feasible.

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN16.1b  Annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions due to fleet fuel consumption (metric tons)
Description: Total direct and indirect greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (metric tons of carbon equivalent) due to fleet fuel consumption per year using CCAR protocol. Indirect GHG emissions are defined as GHG emissions from consumption of purchased electricity, heat, or steam. For purposes of this reporting, use Scope 1 and Scope 2 reporting
Technical Description: Data Source: SFPUC DepCap report as submitted to SFE annually in spring of the fiscal year for, and following the end of, the prior fiscal year. How: Used  methodology as contained in SFPUC spring DepCap report for prior fiscal year as required by SFE. Calculation: Used SFPUC DepCap report results (including fleet) for prior fiscal year. *Note that a draft third party verification of SFE's 2010 community-wide ghg inventory was completed,  but does not include the emissions factor used for the various sources of GHG emissions. Note that beginning with FY2011/12 reporting (for 2010/11 DepCAP report), natural gas emissions exclude Treasure Island. Previous years' reports are artificially inflated due to inclusion of TI  natural gas consumption, which is not part of SFPUC's carbon footprint as a City Agency/Department.
FY 2013 Yr End Actual Explanation: 4,976 metric tons CO2 emissions for fleet fuel consumption. From FY2011-12 DepCAP report (submitted in spring 2013). 9/3/13 Note that beginning with FY2011/12 reporting (for 2010/11 DepCAP report), natural gas emissions exclude Treasure Island. Previous years' reports are artificially inflated due to inclusion of TI  natural gas consumption, which is not part of SFPUC's carbon footprint as a City Department.  Additionally, beginning in 2011, SFPUC began buying only renewable energy to offset any deficiencies in its hydro electric power supply; as a result, its electricity GHG emissions are zero (hydro electric and renewewable forms of power produce zero GHG emissions).  This accounts for a reduction of 2,188 metric tons eCO2 from the 2010/2011 reporting year.   Target: Identify opportunities for GHG reductions; implement where cost effective and feasible.

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN17.1a Direct energy consumption broken down by source = Energy Intensity (EI metric): MWh energy used per million gallons of water delivered (In-City Retail Water)
Description: Total annual MWh used by Water Enterprise per million gallons (MG) In-City Retail Water delivered. These are commonly referred to as energy intensity (EI) metrics.
Technical Description: Data Source:Use County meters (Water) & MDMS Meter Data & Management System(Power) How: Report two energy intensities 1) wholesale and 2)retail (within City Limits): these are defined by: Energy Intensity (EI) retail = EI wholesale + CDD energy use (City deliveries) -

Goal: Steward the Environment
Performance Measure: EN17.1c Direct energy consumption broken down by source = Energy Intensity (EI metric): MWh energy used per million gallons wastewater treated
Description: Total annual MWh used by Wastewater Enterprise divided by million gallons wastewater treated per year
Technical Description: Data Source:MWh  and MG from WWE How:MWh from the Power enterprise, MG from WWE SCADA: MWh divided by  MG treated = EI

Calculation: Divide the number of laptops, desktops, and monitors that meet the EPEAT Gold standard by the total number of laptops, desktops, and monitors. Multiply by 100
